An awesome continuation of Kiryu's story. I played 0 and 1 before this this. So far, this is my favorite. The combat is better, ditching the multiple stances and using a comprehensive upgrade system. The story is more grounded. I think if you haven't played 0 and/or 1, you could jump into 2. But you'd likely miss quite a bit of "why this matters" or "it's really cool that we see this character because in the previous games..." Also, it's gorgeous and just pretty to look at. On to the next!

I feel like the story is better than in Kiwami 1, it keeps your interest and you want to finish the game. Locations and characters are mostly the same, you explore Kamurocho and Sotenbori. If we talk about main supportive characters then I should mention Kaoru, I enjoyed her interacting with Kiryu, this is something that I didn't get in Kiwami 1, you can say that their interaction shows a little bit more of Kiryu gentle side. The engine shows better picture overall, not much to say. There is also a "Majima Saga" addon which gives you an 1-1.5 hour gameplay for Majima and tells what happened to him between Kiwami 1 and Kiwami 2, it also concludes one of the storylines that was started in Yakuza Zero, I really liked that.

Some things gave me mixed feelings though. Throughout the story there are moments that feel like being taken from Kiwami 1, sometimes they even occur in the same places they occured in Kiwami, it gives the feeling like the story repeats itself a little and I can't say this is good. In terms of combat, there are no styles anymore like in previous games, you only have one style and some parts of previous styles are incorporated in it.

Ok, it took me 20 hours less to get all the achievements for this game than 7's and a whopping 55 hours less than 0's and this one felt 10 times more tedious than those two. 

Now, the story in general, with the main and side missions, I believe this is the funniest yakuza game I've played, it's just that I'm not sure if all of it was on porpuse, wins the award for dumbest ending in the series hands down though. 

On the completionist side you have the two big side games that are the cabaret club which is always awesome, and Majima constructions side story which I love absolutely everything about it... with the exception of the actual minigame you have to play to complete it, the minigame is so tedious and boring, though I love it's story and the recruitment aspect of the minigame.

The completion list is the usual, I'm sincerely starting to believe that the batting cages and mahjong are the actual final bosses of these games but to that they added the whole Bouncer missions a whole more than 70 of them to complete, you get great rewards from them but I was just so DONE with them by the half way point.

Also I would feel bad because I brought it up on my yakuza 7 review... is the dragon engine what's messing up the UFO catcher? The games with that engine that I've played the UFO catcher feels AWFUL and of course there is a submission tied to it, heck, the camera doesn't change angle when you start moving the crane backwards in ONE location, which means that it's also probably glitched (and yes, the submission takes place on the venue where the camera doesn't move), I sincerely hope that the camera problem I had was something on my end and not on the game. 

Other than that, yeah, it's a good yakuza game and since almost nobody goes the 100% route in these games I can't judge it too harshly for something I brought on myself but yeah, it felt way more tedios than any other game on this series. 

A big shout out to Ryuji though, while I think the community overhyped him a tad for me, he IS the most efective antagonist on the series that I've seen so far, just for the fact that he was usually in the fray and he was a creadible threat in every sense of the word.

[h1] "A real man.. Oughta be a little stupid.." [/h1]

[h3] General Thoughts [/h3]
Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a great game overall. It has good combat, great story, and amazing visuals. Personally, it took me a while to get invested in the game, and at first it seemed quite bland compared to the immense content in Yakuza 0. However, once I got into the gist of things I started to really enjoy the dragon engine style gameplay a lot more.

[h3] The Story [/h3]
The story is essentially the same as the original Yakuza 2 with a few minor tweaks and adjustments. Kiryu Kazuma returns to the Tojo once more to aid in an upcoming war between the Tojo Clan and Omi Alliance and attempts to stop it before too much blood is shed, whilst also dealing with the Korean Jingweon Mafia. Although enjoyable to play through, the story is a lot less complex and dynamic than later games due to being one of the first entries into the franchise. However, this doesn't deduct from the quality of the story especially towards the end-game.

[h3] The Gameplay [/h3]
Yakuza Kiwami 2 was the first game where I experienced the dragon engine fighting style for Kiryu. Although not as dynamic or interactive as Yakuza 0's style system, each movement and attack felt very smooth and satisfying making combat almost addicting to play through, especially once you unlock abilities that allow you to slam through enemies easily. The upgrade system is also improved from Yakuza 6's and is probably one of the best in the series, appearing in later games such as Judgment. The usual mini-games are present, as well as the return of the cabaret club mini-game which I somehow found a lot more enjoyable than in Yakuza 0, though that's just personal preference.

[h3] The Graphics [/h3]
The graphics in Yakuza Kiwami 2 are phenomenal. In some cases, it looks very life-like. Seeing the neon lights in Kamurocho with the dragon engine is truly a sight to behold. However, for some reason RGG studios decided to add a greenish filter for the entirety of the game which is questionable and in some cases ruins the stunning graphics, but can easily be ignored or removed with modding if it bothers you too much.

[h3] Final Thoughts [/h3]
Overall, a very good retelling of the original Yakuza 2. Would definitely recommend if you're into the Yakuza series or beat em up games in general.

On some level, it feels redundant to review [i]Yakuza Kiwami 2[/i]. The [i]Yakuza / Like a Dragon[/i] franchise follows a very lock-tight formula with heavily reused assets and environments, and so in some sense reviewing any of the middle entries in the franchise is equivocal to reviewing any other middle entry in the franchise. However, there are some ups and downs when transitioning from [i]Kiwami[/i] to [i]Kiwami 2[/i], which merit discussion.

[h2]At a Glance[/h2]
[i]Yakuza Kiwami 2[/i] is, like its predecessors, a gradual iteration on the same action-adventure beat-em-up that [i]Yakuza 1[/i] was. This means that broad reviews of gameplay systems and tone are applicable to each game. Here was my own description of [i]Yakuza Kiwami[/i], which applies to [i]Kiwami 2[/i] as well:

https://steamcommunity.com/id/Two_Dimensional/recommended/834530/

[quote=TwoDee][i][Yakuza is] a battle of violently-clashing tones that makes absolutely no concession to the concept of thematic consistency. [...] A gripping crime drama of skull-crushing violence and heart-wrenching betrayal [...] is punctuated, constantly, by slapstick comedy routines and colorful, childish minigames. [...] It is not unlike if Goodfellas and Caddyshack were the same movie, or if the climax of The Usual Suspects featured Keyser Soze tearing off his shirt in one smooth motion and suplexing Detective Kujan through the interrogation-room table so hard that the building collapses. [...]

It feels strange to frame it this way, but Yakuza is one of the most "video games" video games in all of video games; it embodies all of the medium's most absurd and clashing excesses, but also its potential as a vehicle for entertainment all in one package.[/i][/quote]

However, on top of my general impressions of the entire franchise, I have two additional observations unique to this game, regarding the upgraded engine and the story compared to other [i]Yakuza[/i] titles.

[h2]The Dragon Engine[/h2]
[i]Kiwami 2[/i] uses the Dragon Engine, an improved version of the engine that has powered the franchise since the original [i]Yakuza 1[/i] and [i]Yakuza 2[/i], and which is in particular a noticeable jump up in graphics and performance from [i]Yakuza Zero[/i] and [i]Kiwami[/i], this title's immediate predecessors.  The neighborhoods of Kamurocho and Sotenbori have never looked nearly as good as they have in this game, and it's ironically a noticeable graphical step down going from this remake of the second game of the franchise to the "later" games chronologically. More than a remaster, [i]Kiwami 2[/i] is a total upgrade of the original [i]Yakuza 2[/i] to the standards of a modern AAA beat-em-up title, and it doesn't feel dated in the way that remasters of old titles normally do. Alongside the engine change come a lot of quality-of-life features like seamless interiors and very short load times, which are welcome improvements.

However, I felt that the combat of [i]Kiwami 2[/i], while extremely smooth and 'flowy,' was a noticeable step down from [i]Zero[/i] and [i]Kiwami [/i]. Where those games had extremely intentional, pixel-perfect, "arcade game" style hitboxes, as well as multiple combat styles and stances, [i]Kiwami 2[/i] is considerably more forgiving and loosy-goosey with interpreting the player's inputs, giving it a gamefeel that's halfway between [i]Yakuza[/i] and something like [i]Batman: Arkham Asylum[/i]. Kiryu likewise only has one moveset, so although combat is flashier and nicer to look at overall, there also isn't as much gameplay variety.

I'm not a huge fan of the trade-off. [i]Kiwami 2[/i] is still an excellent game in the way that all [i]Yakuza[/i] titles are, but given the choice between having the very precise and depthy combat of [i]Kiwami[/i] versus the gorgeous and spectacular combat of [i]Kiwami 2[/i], I'd prefer the former.

[h2]The Story[/h2]
I'd described the state-of-the-art Dragon Engine as making [i]Kiwami 2[/i]'s gameplay feel fresh and not dated, but the same cannot be said of the game's story, which is definitely feeling the nearly 20 years of age since the release of [i]Yakuza 2[/i]. [i]Yakuza 2[/i]'s story is uniquely tone-deaf and messy in a way that the story of [i]Yakuza 1[/i] and its remake [i]Kiwami[/i] isn't, because it represents the awkward growing step where a clean, self-contained game with a satisfying beginning, middle and end got greenlit for a sequel and became a franchise, requiring a massive and frequently slipshod increase in narrative scope and complexity. [i]Yakuza 2[/i]'s "serious" story is ridiculous and meandering in a way that the very slick standalone first game isn't, and it particularly suffers in comparison to [i]Zero[/i], a title with one of the most sprawling and epic crime stories in contemporary video games and which represents nearly 10 years of the writers maturing and growing since [i]Yakuza 2[/i].  However, because [i]Zero[/i] was a prequel and the Kiwami titles are remakes of the very earliest games, it feels extremely jarring to go from a brilliant narrative masterpiece in [i]Zero[/i], to a good-for-a-video-game story in [i]Kiwami[/i], to the comparative train wreck that is [i]Kiwami 2[/i].

Loosely, the plot centers around two connecting stories: one is the protagonist-adjacent Tojo Clan, still smarting from the plot of the first game, desperately attempting to sign a ceasefire with the more-antagonistic Omi Alliance, when this agreement is suddenly interrupted by a coup d'etat of the Omi Alliance by an up-and-coming new underboss. The other is about the rebirth of the Korean "Jingweon" Mafia, a foreign mafia who were so cruel and so debased that the Tojo Clan and the police once cooperated to slaughter them all like rabid animals, long before the events of even [i]Yakuza Zero[/i]. As the plot thickens, these two stories are revealed to be connected, with the coup d'etat intimately connected to the reappearance of these bloodthirsty, subhuman Korean savages.

You may be noticing that I'm using some very loaded terms to describe the Koreans, and that's because [i]Yakuza 2[/i], and thus [i]Kiwami 2[/i], is appallingly and often hilariously racist in ways that you frankly just don't see in video games anymore. The Jingweon's tendrils of evil corrupt every secondary and tertiary character with even a drop of Korean blood in them, and previously-established sympathetic characters from the first [i]Yakuza[/i] veer wildly into villainy because their innate Korean evil has been activated. At one point two plot points arise, one about how Koreans insidiously blend into Japanese society and could be anyone, and another about how two Korean characters are impossible to tell apart because Koreans look alike, and these are both presented entirely at face value as equally true. A corrupt cop discloses that he extra-judicially shoots Koreans to death on principle, and this is presented as a grim necessity rather than a war crime.

At the story's denouement, it falls apart into a contrived conga line of the Omi betraying the Koreans, who planned for this and betrayed the Omi, who planned for this and betrayed the Koreans, to such a convoluted extent that it feels more like an episode of [i]Death Note[/i] than a crime drama.

[h2]In Conclusion[/h2]
[i]Kiwami 2[/i] is a flawed [i]Yakuza[/i] title, although it's mostly flawed in ways that a remaster of the imperfect second game was always going to be.  It's still a very fun game, but it sometimes smarts as an ultramodern, bells-and-whistles remake of a not-particularly-great story that didn't necessarily deserve to be remade the way that the first game did.  As a stepping stone to engage with the rest of the [i]Yakuza[/i] franchise, it still excels, and at the end of the day it's still Fun, which should be the barometer on which all Yakuza games are judged.

Just keep an eye over your shoulder. You never know where a [i]Korean[/i] could be hiding...

i have been reviewing the Yakuza games in series order (0, Kiwami 1, Kiwami 2, 3, 4, etc) so this review of Kiwami 2 is under the context of the two previous reviews.

Kiwami 2 does little to change the formula previously establish in the series. Playing as former Yakuza and former Chairman of the Tojo Clan Kazuma Kiryu, you will take part in high stakes crime thriller drama, while also fighting vicious thugs in the streets, eating at various restaurants for health and exp, collecting toys from the claw machine, sinking money into rounds of Virtua Fighter 2, gambling games, batting cages, or the golf center, and managing a cabaret club with near identical mechanics to Yakuza 0's own Cabaret Club Czar minigame. You will also oversee large scale battles as the foreman of Goro Majima's new construction company as they develop a new high-rise setup while avoiding the project being taken over by rival companies.

The biggest two changes relate to clearing the seams of the open world. Kamurocho and Sotenbori look and feel the same as ever but no longer will you have to wait for a loading screen when entering buildings. Most shops, restaurants, and buildings are seemlessly integrated into the street level. Kiryu will open doors walking through them, some will slide open for him, and now he can use elevators and stairs to explore upper floors, office spaces, and even the rooftops of some buildings. The other aspect thats been made more seamless is combat, with bouts on the street beginning and ending with no loads or cuts, and physics have been upgraded to allow for objects to get hit and fly around and enemies have been given ragdolls.

Combat feels very different despite being built off the same ideas. most combos and the base idea of light attacks followed by a heavy finisher is preserved, but moves that were once Head Actions are now simple combo actions, collision and such feels less "gamey" (fewer invincible frames and more animation based hits), and charged attacks have been added. New frustrations include not dodging an attack you were supposed to because hit detection is much different, throw moves getting interrupted by walls and objects in the way, and less overall variety, as the combat is built off the Brawler style, with some mechanics from other styles mixed in.

A few missing features stand out however. the Pocket Circuit is nowhere to be found, as well as the various variations of pool/billiards. MeSuKing/Japan Catfight Club is also gone. 

Story is as solid as ever in terms of the players and logistics: Terada, the Omi Alliance Captain Kiryu installed as the Tojo Clan's Fifth Chairman is assassinated right as the Omi Alliance is seemingly on the precipice of taking over Kamurocho and Kiryo must travel to Sotenbori in Kansai to meet with the Omi alongside Daigo Dojima, the son of Sohei Dojima and last seen in a Yakuza 0 substory. Also involved is Ryuji Goda, Patriarch of the Go-Ryu clan and also was last seen in a hilarious Yakuza 0 substory where he steals people's bontan pants. Meanwhile, Detective Makoto Date, Kiryu's ally in the police force and main character in the last game has discovered something involving Kazuki, the owner of Club Stardust, a key figure and location from the previous game. Osakan Detective Kaoru Saeyama, the "Yakuza Huntress" attaches herself to Kiryu to dig deeper into what's happening in the underworld and what follows is dense and thrilling as each piece slowly fits into the larger picture. Towards the end, it fails to keep up the mystique of its early chapters and the chaotic but emotional energy of 0 and 1's later chapters. You do, however, get to punch a tiger.

Graphically, the upgrade from Kiwami 1 is subtle but substantial. For starters, your new default move speed is walking, meaning you will inherently just be looking closer at things, and when looking at these things, textures are all clearly upgraded, the streets are more crowded, more particle effects are in use, and lighting is starkly better, however, by default, an ugly depth of field effect is applied to the game that makes it look very smeared and blurry. Also, they must have JJ Abrams involved somehow because the amount of unnecessary lens flare is off the charts.

I have a love-hate relationship with this game; It's one of the first games (in the 0 -> Kiwami 1 -> 2 play order) that majorly flipped the combat system on it's head. At first, it's kind of like a breath of fresh air. It's simplified, no more combat styles, one smooth fluid combat system that just works. As you progress in the game, you find that fights are both too easy and are super annoying. It seems as you rapidly approach the last quarter of the game, a lot of fights are there simply to serve as a way to lose health. Nothing more, nothing less. Looking at you "Man in Black" and random three dudes with an RPG and sliver of health in the final chapter :/

The boss fights are another thing that stood out to me as horrendous. In 0, they felt far more grand and elaborate. In 2 it just lost it's charm. Heat moves take out gigantic portions of the bosses health, to the point where some fights took me under a minute to complete, feeling like Kiryu's  really is the strongest Yakuza to walk the earth (aside from the Man in Black who seemingly has no issue wiping out your health).

By far, this is the most beautiful and scenic game that I've played. Devs did some major overhauling on the physics engine, which is certainly debatable if that's a good thing or not (ragdoll physics are insane now). Regardless, it's lighting is beautiful with not much more leaving to be desired in terms of graphics. When I first loaded into Kamurocho, I was speechless. I'm still amazed at how this game looks.

With all that said, the story is fantastic with unexpected twists and turns, and even some bonus content featuring Majima. The Majima ep really yanked at the heart strings quite a bit, much more than I expected it to. I'm glad Ryu Ga Gotoku added this. One of the games really needed this and I'm glad this one had it. This game didn't cause me to spontaneously combust in tears like previous games, but it's still a great game in the franchise despite it's janky combat system. I look forward to replaying it sometime in the distant future.

Kiwami 2 is like if they took Kiwami and just amped it up by 5. You cannot play this game if you have not played 0 or at least Kiwami, so dont go into this game as your first one. The game does have a recap of the story from the first game. However, you will still be missing out on a lot of context clues if you haven't played the previous 2 mentioned titles because there are a lot of returning characters and plot points that are not discussed in the recap.

I enjoyed this game much more than I did the first game. As a sequel, it excels and outperforms the first game in every way. The Dragon Engine aids in that because it makes this game feel much more different gameplay-wise than its predecessor in a very good way. The engine changes certain aspects of the core gameplay. For example, they took out the different fighting styles but now you can learn different moves that basically include what you could say were the strongest aspects of the old 4 fighting styles, so think of it as if they combined all the different styles and just put them all in 1 move set instead of it being split into 4. You're not locked in arenas when fighting enemies either, now you can just run around anywhere and pick up almost anything you see that you think you can use as a weapon and my favorite part of it all is how you can now fight inside shops and destroy them while you fight off the groups of baddies which makes for some fun situations. 

The Story of this game is also incredibly well written and dramatic with a great ending to it all. I cant really say if its better than the first game because I feel like both stories are very well made, intertwine with each other, and are emotionally driven with similar yet different plot points and themes. The Sub stories are also very fun with so many different situations and variety to them. I also really enjoy how this game concludes stories from 0 and Kiwami in a very nice fashion with returning characters just so we can see what happened 20 years after 0.

If you played 0, then you will be familiar with the Cabaret Club but this game does add a new miniature game that is like a base defense style unit management gameplay. I enjoyed this activity but I do think it went on for too long and as enjoyable as it was I didn't like it as much as I thought I would and only really finished it to see how the sub story concluded [spoiler] I also found it extremely annoying when you think you're done and the game throws a plot twist (which seems to be the theme of this whole game) and goes ACTUALLY THIS IS THE REAL FINAL BATTLE, after already making you believe you had your final battle. [/spoiler] 

My issues with this game are the same as all the other games. After a specific amount of time, it starts to feel repetitive (I think I was able to pinpoint when it happens and it was around the 30-40 hour mark). I avoided Combat in the later part of the game just because fighting groups of enemies was getting annoying when I was just trying to do Sub Stories or activities for fun and it felt like the game was spawning them more often than usual with enemies that had more health as well. There is also I believe 2 instances where the game essentially forces you to do a side mission as a main mission for no purpose other than to just give you a little backstory on some not-so-important characters. Harukos request are also back but I just found it aggravating that to complete some of them you have to do extremely well at certain gambling activities which requires you to put a lot of time into them especially if you decide to do it without items that help you cheat to get the results you want. You don't get these items for every activity either and they are not common, which in turn just makes the whole thing into a luck base grind that you are not always guaranteed to win. Me personally I don't enjoy it because I never engaged with the activities that are about gambling since I don't find it fun to play those games in a video game where I can do more interesting things. I also had a few problems with the new combat system, it is much faster-paced but oftentimes I felt like I did not have many options even after unlocking almost all of the upgrades. Especially when certain characters make you fight with no heat actions, it was very bare bone and did not have a lot of depth or variety to warrant you being able to pull some crazy combos. The combat was never complex but in this game it felt a little more simple than usual [spoiler] (The Majima sub story suffered the most from this since you only have like 5 moves). [/spoiler] Maybe it was a skill issue on my end but I did try to see how I can do more with less and in those situations I was never able to figure out how. The last thing that bothered me was NO POCKET CIRCUIT RACE, -1 for that.

In the end, I enjoyed this game much more, I liked the updated Dragon engine and I feel like it spoiled me because having to go back to the previous engine for the next few games is going to be something that I will have to get used to since the dragon engine seems like such a great upgrade gameplay-wise. Out of the first 3 modern remakes/games (0, Kiwami, Kiwami 2) this was my favorite to play combat-wise and felt the best all around. 0 is still my favorite though because it has Pocket Circuit Race and I like the atmosphere of the city as well. Although, this game does have an official release of Virtual-On which is one of my favorite arcade games so I guess it gets +1 for that.

In 2016, SEGA announced Sonic Forces; a game made by the people behind the most successful installments of the series, while also using a brand new game engine to elevate the experience. The game ultimately ended up as a disappointment, not living up to expectations.
Yakuza Kiwami 2 is the Sonic Forces of Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio. It uses a brand new engine, it had very talented developers working on it, yet the end result is nothing but a product that begs the question: "what happened here?"

[h2]Horrible first impressions[/h2]
Kiwami 2 has the most horrible opening hours among the first three Yakuza games (0, K1, K2). If you are coming from Yakuza 0 or Kiwami, which is a safe assumption for many, you will find the game very disappointing, and for a variety of reasons.
Kiwami 2 does away with the style switching system, mashes all of the previous battle styles into one, and starts you with basics. That means, for the first 7-8 hours of the game, you have no access to anything equivalent to rush and beast styles. You have a bunch of simple combos and heat actions that are nowhere as flashy and exciting to use as their counterparts in 0 and Kiwami, and many of the actually cool stuff are locked. For example, remember those furniture wielding enemies at the beginning of Yakuza 0 that you could counter with a heat action? They are in the beginning of this game as well, but you cannot use heat actions against them.
And the combat itself feels incredibly off too. Enemies and bosses feel like tanks that hit hard and take a lot of hits before going down. The most reliable way of dealing with enemies and especially the bosses, is to grab something and swing it around, or constantly refill the heat meter with consumables and spam heat actions; something the new battle system encourages as now you can carry way more items with the removal of your limited inventory, and also you can equip up to 3 weapons to switch between them in combat.
The situation gets worse after you get to the upgrade system, because instead of a exp meter or money, Kiwami 2 awards you with 6 different tokens after each successful mission, random battle encounter or eating in restaurants. And the last one is actively encouraged as eating food rewards you with a lot of tokens, and even more if you manage to eat a food combo. Then, you can use these tokens to upgrade your abilities. This makes the game incredibly tedious as you find yourself constantly entering the restaurants, just to eat everything and get upgrade points.
Last but not least, the substories of the first 8 hours of the game are downright awful. Aside from a few, they are mostly fetch quests, or follow the "short dialogue -> combat -> short dialogue" formula. Even those that can be something special, like the Overwhelming Affluence substory, get absolutely destroyed by bad pacing and putting its finale in the same chapter. Almost none of them feel dramatic humorous like that was available in 0 and Kiwami.

[h2]And the pain continues...[/h2]
Unfortunately, the situation doesn't get better. In fact, the only saving grace of the game which is the story, also starts getting tedious after some time as well. The antagonists never feel as intimidating or unlikable-for-good-reason as their counterparts from 0 and Kiwami. The game even goes way too overboard while explaining stuff with a cutscene. Don't believe me? The cutscene that introduces Majima Construction Company's bad guys, goes on for about 10 WHOLE MINUTES!
The story pacing is so poor, that by the time I got to the fifth act of the game, it really didn't feel like the progression was enough to get there. And don't you dare hit me with "but the original was like this too!". Kiwami added new main story cutscenes f that helped players understand what Nishikiyama went through. So, what's Kiwami 2's excuse?
The combat just doesn't get better either. People say it gets good after buying some upgrades and moves, but it really doesn't change much and the road you have to take to get there is so not worth it. You still have to constantly go and eat at the restaurants to get tokens and upgrade your abilities, so you can have a chance against the damage sponge enemies and bosses. And all of this grind is not fun.
And speaking of not fun, the minigames are botched too! Kiwami 2 has the lowest number of minigames when compared to 0 or even Kiwami, and what the game actually offers, is not fun. Instead of having normal, yet entertaining minigames such as pool or bowling, Kiwami 2 introduces a minigame called Toylets that makes you partake in competitive pissing which sounds hilarious, but is not fun. There's also a very big downgrade of fanservice-y activities, as stuff like MesuKing, Gandhara and collectible cards have given their place to Photoshoots, where you try to make sentences on a time limit to unlock videos. Now you might try and argue that some of these are because the original Yakuza 2 did not have them either. But the problem is, even Kiwami had a lot more in it compared to the original Yakuza 1. Which makes me wonder...

[h2]Did‚Ä¶ did they make this on a very limited time and budget?[/h2]
There's a bunch of stuff in the game that makes me question whether this game was made under tight deadlines and budget or not. The combat and upgrade systems both come from Yakuza 6. Club Four Shine's interior is almost identical to Club Sunshine from Yakuza 0. Even the cabaret minigame looks the same, despite getting small changes. There are a severe lack of minigames compared to 0 and Kiwami.
All of this, in addition to the tight release date of Kiwami 2 after Yakuza 6 (1 year), makes me believe this game was not a priority. There's no way in hell they got the same treatment, as one is the highly anticipated sequel to the series that acts as an epilogue to Kiryu's story as the main character, and the other is the remake of a PlayStation 2 game. Hell, even Judgment was also getting worked on to some extent in this time period. My guess is that they make Yakuza 6 first and then started using whatever asset they had to make Kiwami 2 in a short time period and with limited resources. And this can explain a lot of stuff with this game. Even the port quality.

[h2]Pretty on the surface, a mess on the inside[/h2]
Kiwami 2 is ported by QLOC, known for their great track record of porting a console game to PC. So clearly something has gone wrong if the port is such a hot mess, further suggesting the idea of time and money constraints.
For starters, the PC version's uncapped framerate actually breaks the game. If you set the game to run at anything other than 30 fps, the enemies start breaking out of combos that they are not supposed to, adding heaps of salt to the wound that is the combat system. Not only that, the ragdolls also get extreme and bodies and items get thrown around further and faster. The game may even refuse to run at a stable framerate and minigames might break or cause the game to crash due to frame pacing issues, requiring you to apply a community patch (SilentPatch) to fix them because SEGA sure didn't care.

[h2]A pretty good example of how to shoot yourself in the foot[/h2]
SEGA should have been more careful with Yakuza Kiwami 2. They should have either remastered the original or have done better work on this remake. People are going to play Kiwami 2 right after 0 and Kiwami. They know this is a new game with a new engine and not a remaster like Yakuza 3-4-5. They will have high expectations when they get to this game and will not forgive whatever flaws they see.
Alas, they didn't care. They just kept reusing stuff and didn't spend the needed amount of time and resources on it. The game is not fun, and I don't see why I have to keep playing what is not fun.


[h2]TL;DR[/h2]
An inferior product compared to Yakuza 0 or even Kiwami. If you're coming from those games, you're better off not playing this, as it feels like a downgrade to them in almost every way.

Finally, Ryuji is so far the best villain and the final boss in the series. 
There is also a few special chapters where you play as Majima. Which is largely a short bit of fan service that functions as a prequel, and resolves some of the story from Yakuza 0.

Review originally written on August 30, 2023.

--SPOILERS AHEAD--

I really like this game, but the last ~4 hours of it were... well, they sure were something!

I was really invested in pretty much all the new characters, the side content was great as always. I didn‚Äôt care for the story that much, but the characters were enough for me to keep playing. Ryuji was criminally underutilized, though, and hopefully he‚Äôll appear in other installments. Majima was incredibly silly. Kiryu gets some very good moments, too. I didn‚Äôt have high expectations for Sayama, considering the previous game, but she blew my expectations and then some. I was into the Kiryu and Sayama romance at the beginning, but after their first kiss scene it was all down hill, so much so that I kinda hate the idea of them possibly getting together. The part where Kiryu almost gets Haruka into the entertainment history was disastrous, I was literally yelling at Kiryu through the screen the whole. It was the only time I was genuinely angry at any of these characters, it was just so bad. The whole story had an air of anti-Korean xenophobic sentiment I didn‚Äôt really enjoy.

The ending was something else. Too many plot twists, way too ridiculous, by the time the credits rolled I was laughing my ass off, and I‚Äôm pretty sure I wasn't supposed to. I truly have no words for it, it‚Äôs something you have to experience for yourself.

Despite its flaws, I thoroughly enjoyed the Dragon Engine. Sure, the fights were a little boring, but they were not cumbersome, so I didn‚Äôt really mind it. The substories were TOO good, probably one of my favorites parts of this game if I have to be honest. It was straight up evil to have Haruka‚Äôs requests available during the story, I got stuck on Virtual On and the golfing mini-game for three days. Evil. Did I mention this has the Cabaret mini-game?

When it comes to the Majima Saga: I enjoyed it over all. The opening cutscenes made me expect more yakuza politics, which we really didn‚Äôt get. It was great to see how Majima left the Tojo clan and how he decided to start Majima Construction. I love all things Makoto, and even though I loved how both Majima and Makoto got some well deserved closure, the whole thing felt a little off. Mainly how I felt It was unrealistic that Makoto hadn't changed at all in 18 years, It‚Äôs almost like she was plucked straight from Majima‚Äôs memories, like she‚Äôs just an extension of Majima‚Äôs Tragic Backstory‚Ñ¢ and not her own person. Might just be me, though.

Being the perfect ending to a brilliant trilogy, Yakuza Kiwami 2 closes all story elements from Yakuza 0 and Yakuza Kiwami in a very satisfying way. The payoff is worth it.¬†

This game definitely has flaws, the combat system seems very nerfed from 0 and Kiwami. Although Dragon style is a combination of all previous styles in the other two games, it suffers quite a bit in it's lack of variety. Not very many heat actions too. But regardless, towards the mid point of the game, you will feel the heat! You will be unstoppable, once you work out the basics of this style. It's really satisfying in the end.¬†

Besides the combat, the substories are nice, but not many notable ones. Still worth your time. The Cabaret Club minigame was AWESOME. I got real engrossed in it. The dating sections were cool, i guess. But they were just a means to go through the main plot of this minigame. The effort and journey is definitely worth it and I HIGHLY RECOMMEND playing through it atleast once! Now on to the next major minigame, Clan Creator. It's as good as the cabaret club and introduces more memorable characters, GODDAMN! One thing I love about both these minigames is that the characters that you encounter in substories are recruitable in these games. It not only gives more use of them, besides just appearing once in the substories, it expands the world in a wonderful way. Feels like it all comes together! I LOVE IT!

Now, the story. I will admit that it took a while to get into at as in my opinion there weren't as many hard hitting moments. But the ones that hit, THEY HIT HARD. Some scenes are masterfully executed, with the perfect song (I used the licensed music mod which is MANDATORY AND YOU SHOULD NOT PLAY THIS GAME WITHOUT IT), the perfect premise, the right emotional beats and beautiful cinematography. Simply amazing. This is why I love Yakuza. This game, in particular, has one scene that instantly became one of my top 5 favourite scenes in a game (I SWEAR, GET THE MOD). On top of this, genuinely good writing with plenty of twists that will catch you off guard. But overall, Amazing story. I feel like I'll enjoy it even more with each playthrough. The ending is just perfect. The way the credits roll truly leaves a lasting impression. Just Bravo!! I love it! But the true ending (of sorts) is the Majima prequel chapters. These are too short, the combat is severely basic with a very noticeably lacking moveset and kinda drags sometimes. But despite these flaws, it has a few MAJOR memorable moments. It can be considered fan service. But in the grand scheme of things, it truly feels earned. It doesn't feel cheap. The ending to these chapters is what I consider the ending of the trilogy. Perfect closer. Nothing more, nothing less.

To be honest, one can stop the Yakuza story with this trilogy and still leave with a perfect and plenty satisfying ending, but alas, the show must go on...

See you in Yakuza 3.

9/10 for this individual game.¬†
10/10 for the trilogy.

PS - I did use the filterless mod also, so i can't comment on the infamous green filter.

[b]Standard price, AUD:[/b] $24.95

[b]Price paid, AUD:[/b] $7.86

[b]Time to finish:[/b] 55 hours for completion of Kiryu and Majima‚Äôs story. I completed all of the side quests that were available on the map, but didn‚Äôt go hunting for secrets or do much of the minigames.

[b]Difficulty setting:[/b] Normal.

[b]Graphics settings:[/b] Ultra at 3440x1440.

[b][u]PC specs[/u][/b]

Motherboard: ASUS ROG STRIX Z490-E
CPU: Intel i7 10700K @ 3.8GHz
GPU: NVIDIA RTX 3080 10GB
RAM: 32GB DDR4 1600MHz
Drive: Silicone Power 500GB M.2 PCIe SSD
OS: Windows 11

[b]Performance:[/b] Performance was great. No noticeable hitches.

[b]Graphics:[/b] Considerably improved over Y0 and YK graphics, the game is actually quite nice to look at now. I walked around the city quite a bit at first, just taking it all in. It really does look nice.

[b]Story:[/b] The first half or maybe even two thirds of the story was just okay. It didn‚Äôt really grab me. But then things started to ramp up near the final few chapters and it started pulling on the heart strings, and it ended up finishing really well. Overall, I‚Äôm very happy with the story and how things turned out.

The Majima Saga was short and sweet, filled with laughs and tears.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] Everything just feels better in YK2. Combat is more fluid, Kiryu‚Äôs animations are far more natural, and things are just generally more refined, whether that‚Äôs the in-game menu getting a facelift or being able to walk inside shops now without loading screens, or skills and EXP getting a more condensed and streamlined feel.

They seem to have done away with the 4 combat styles and instead opted for a singular combat style that incorporates parts of the old styles, like how the old ‚ÄòLegend‚Äô style used to work. It was a bit of a bummer at first, but once you get used to using it, it‚Äôs a great fighting style that just works and is very fluid. Really nice variations in moves when turning around mid-swing to hit someone behind you as well.

The combat difficulty in this game is not too difficult, while still being challenging enough at times. This is the first Yakuza game I‚Äôve played that hasn‚Äôt made me feel overly frustrated with certain boss fights.

Cabaret Club management makes a welcomed return. In general, it was quicker to level up your hostesses than in Y0. Things are largely unchanged in this minigame, which is great, because the original was so good and this version is equally as fun.

Ragdoll physics is hilarious.

[b]Bugs:[/b] Sometimes during cutscenes I noticed when a character would walk on/off screen, they would just stay frozen at the edge of the screen. This may have something to do with my ultrawide monitor, as I‚Äôd imagine this may have been hidden off-screen on a non-ultrawide monitor.

[b]Final thoughts:[/b] YK2 is a refined and beautiful rendition of the gameplay style, locations and characters that we‚Äôve come to love. With a story that doesn‚Äôt rely on its predecessors, and a heaping helping of the hilarious, this game is a fantastic addition to the Yakuza series.

[b]Do I recommend this game?[/b] Yes.

I really enjoyed playing with Dragon Engine. The game feels a lot more realistic and I was amused with the ragdolling. The Street Boss feature and Bouncer Missions were fun to do.
I noticed that a few of the sub stories now have cut scenes, I'm very satisfied with this because it gives spotlight into characters like Yuya.
I find the story line really well written, Ryuji Goda's character was written outstanding. I see Kiryu as a really good father figure after I finished the first Kiwami game.
All in all, Kiwami 2 was a great experience.

They removed a LOT of the tedium from the older games. faster animations (such as eating and elevators). Most stores and buildings you can enter seamlessly (witcher 3 style). Combat has less option than 0 or kiwami, but it's WAY more refined and feels a lot better. Enemies are no longer as spongy as in kiwami, infact they're probably too easy. It's still better though.

The bouncer missions are horrible. You get good items from them which help a lot, but they are some of the worst designed levels I've ever played. it seems like they exist to show you that the combat is actually very broken if it gets pushed to it's limits. They will put enemies with machine guns that insta stunlock you into an unavoidable death. like you will just be stunned and continuously shot for 1 min until you die. the "Solution" is the break a box which has a shield, which can block the bullets. If you use the shield to break the barrier that is blocking you right in front of it, the shield breaks and you die. If you drop the shield to break the barrier with your fists, it's impossible to pick the shield back up again and you die. If you break the barrier, then break the box to pick up the shield, you then get to enjoy 2 mins of slowly inching towards the three machine gunners, as when a  bullet hits the shield, you stop moving. And there is only 0.1 seconds of break in the 20 second chunks of fire. This is just one example of one mission out of like 30, and they are all like this. They are designed to be the most annoying things possible, I couldn't come up with worse levels if i tried. 

Majima construction is fun for the first 2 levels, then you realise it's the worst rts you've ever played. It's a really fun idea, but it's an rts with the worst controls every, the dumbest a.i, and most annoying enemies. It's just not worth doing. 

The hostess club is pretty much identical to yakuza 0, except the pacing is worse. You'll beat the champion ship, and then have to mindlessly grind about 10 more nights if you want to experience all the girl story lines. It's incredibly easy and tedious. Also, to complete all the CP missions for the club, you will have to grind out like 30 more days of it, to get money and fans that you will never have anything to spend on. it's more money than you'll ever need. 

Haruka holds your hand and is smarter than kiwami, and is genuinely very sweet at first. Her "requests" are broken though, as in you can do them and the game just won't count it. her requests can literally softlock you from 100%ing the game.

the coliseum is also really easy (on hard mode mind you) and makes you grind the same stages over and over again to rank up. so much grinding. It's still the best coliseum out of yakuza 0 and kiwami though. 

Good game, just don't bother trying to completionist anything, it's not worth it.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a true masterwork in every sense of the word. 

First and foremost, it should be mentioned that the combat, along with the engine, has been significantly changed and improved from Yakuza Kiwami and Yakuza 0. Initially, I was unsure how I felt about the changes and the more streamlined and fluid combat style. I felt frustrated and admittedly disappointed since I had grinded out the Majima Everywhere mechanic in Kiwami 1 and became quite proficient in the combat in that game only to have the engine and combat change so dramatically.  However, the longer I played and the more I practiced, the more I viewed the differences as improvements.

The sheer amount of content in this game is almost indescribable. Whether you find yourself grinding the mini-games, enjoying the hilarious substories, unlocking skills and heat actions, eating at all of the restaurants, or fighting in the endless structured battles, there is a little something for everyone to enjoy.

[h1]An absolute incredible story where starting the series really pays off[/h1]
Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a masterpiece of it's own, delivering a really deep story with a lot of drama, action and emotions. This is a real example of how to make a good and immersive story in a videogame.
They have improved everything in Kiwami 2 when compared to Kiwami 1. The graphics are really good and a huge upgrade when compared to the previous game, but not only that, the combat has been upgraded too and feels much better now with faster movement and more responsive controls. A lot of QoL improvements were also implemented like not having load screens when entering establishments.
I think Kiwami 2 is really when starting the series from Yakuza 0 starts to pay off. It feels like the story has reached its climax with excellent characters and a deep and complex story. Not to mention the Majima story that also made excellent connections to Yakuza 0.
It's really interesting how each game is interconnected. They have their own story contained within itself, but also makes connections to past games and even tease what's yet to come. A lot of things that happened in Yakuza 0 had their real consequences to the story now in Kiwami 2. It reminded me a lot of the Trails series, where a lot of these interconnections happen between each game while having a major plot that connects them all. Also pretty interesting that the directors of both Yakuza series and Trails series are named Toshihiro lol
The game took about 14 hours to beat focusing on the story mode. There's a ton of sidestories to do and minigames to enjoy on top of that, but the story was so good that I just wanted to see everything through and didn't want to stop for side content.
Yakuza Kiwami 2 delivered everything that I expected since I started the series with Yakuza 0. A deep and complex interconnected story with great characters that keeps getting deeper and deeper by each subsequent game you play. The more you learn, the more secrets are revealed as the story unfolds in a very satisfying and dramatic way. They also have improved everything over the previous game, especially the graphics, which are very photo-realistic and really good and the combat too feels a lot better.
The PC Port is also excellent and I was able to run it at 1440p 60fps High settings on a RTX 2060 Super without any issues. Very stable frame rate and zero issues during my entire playthough. Ran very smoothly and perfectly.
Can't wait to play the next game in the series, even though the transition may be a little bit harsh going from this excellent full modern remake to the old remastered games, but with an excellent story like this, I think we'll be fine going through.

[h1]Yakuza Kiwami 2[/h1]
This is the third part of the Yakuza series (in chronological order), and I think it's the best part for me (at least for now). The most noticeable change is the engine, the new engine gives better graphics, more detailed environments, and new gameplay mechanics (for example, fights feel different now). The story is also quite interesting and engaging, as always, lots of plot twists, tense moments and of course epic boss fights.

[i](There's a paragraph at the end of the review "In a nutshell" if you don't want to read the whole thing.)[/i]

 [b] [u]Storyline [/u] [/b] 

So, what is this game about?[b] Our protagonist as always, Kazuma Kiryu, a year after stepping away from the yakuza life, the chairman of the clan is assassinated. He was killed by a rival clan, and now that means war, which Kazuma wants to prevent, and to do that he needs to find the new chairman of the Tojo clan. On his way he meets the villain of the story, Ryuji Goda, the "Dragon Kansai" of the Omi Alliance. He wants to kill Kiryu because there can only be one dragon, and now it's a dragon confrontation.[/b]

[b]As I said before, the plot in this part is not bad.[/b] But not better than before, for example, in the first part we had two main characters and two big stories that merged at the end. Those stories were pretty epic, in the Kiriya line he wiped out most of the Tojo clan, which was pretty cool. In Kiwami, we were confronted with the changes in 10 years. A lot of people we knew changed, a lot of people died, and the ending was very powerful. 

But now the story starts a year later (which isn't a bad thing, though), and not much has changed. We meet new rivals from the clan we met before, but in my opinion they are not as interesting as the previous ones. But that doesn't mean the plot is bad, it's pretty cool, though not as epic as before (but the ending is pretty epic too, nonetheless).

[b] [u]Districts and the Atmosphere [/u] [/b]

As for the atmosphere, it's the same as in the previous part, so I guess I'll skip that topic and talk about the elaboration of details.

[b]Thanks to the new engine, the graphics are better than before and now there are no loading screens (at least on the streets). You can enter restaurants and entertainment places on your own, now you don't have to press the button and wait for loading.[/b] You can also enter unusual places, such as an office or other building, where there is no entertainment. The level of detail of these places is also increased, there are a lot of interior items that are lying around and can be picked up in fights (much more than before).
Although I said the atmosphere remained the same as the previous part, I was meaning the atmosphere of Japan in the 2000s, but with this level of detail, the districts became more alive and interesting to explore.

[b] [u]Additional assignments [/u] [/b]

[b]This part of the game is most similar to the one that was in the previous game.[/b] The quests are very similar in story (in general the plots are different, but on the same level), for example in the previous parts we had a hostess club and this one has one, and they are the same (or almost the same) in mechanics. Quests are not unusual, but they're not bad either, especially with the new graphics that make everything more beautiful.

[b] [u]Gameplay [/u] [/b] 

[b]For me, this is the best change. Foremost, the game got rid of 3 (+1) fighting styles, for some people this might not be very nice, but for me, it's pretty good.[/b] I always use one, my favorite style, and don't pay attention to the others. Usually halfway through the game, I upgrade that style to the last one. If I want to improve anything else (in this style), I have to do some secrets or silly quests, but now we only have one style and more upgrades to it (and secrets or silly quests remain). Because of this, you have a lot of upgrades, and you can use them as soon as you want. 

[b]Also, skills are now more interesting, or at least make more difference in combat or exploration.[/b] For example, you can get a skill that shows you all the side quests on the map, which is pretty handy. The improvements in combat have also gotten interesting, from parrying to cancel actions. [b]Thanks to this, you can actually dodge or parry attacks normally now. In the previous part, fighting multiple enemies was quite difficult and uncomfortable, now it has become much better.[/b]

[b]But with weapons and consumables, the game took a step backwards. Now you can have all types of consumables (food, first aid kits, etc.) within 5-10, it makes you invincible (if you can use them).[/b] That's pretty casual in my opinion.

[b]Also, weapons are now more consumable than before.[/b] You can't even repair it before completing some side quests (now it's not as obvious and not many people can repair weapons like before), I didn't repair any of my weapons because of this. And it's also too powerful, I wouldn't recommend using it on bosses (at least not on bosses without weapons).

[hr][/hr]
[b] [u]In a nutshell [/u] [/b]

[b]The plot is not bad, very dramatic and tense, but not as epic as in the previous parts. The game has a new engine, which fixed many problems: battles became more convenient and interesting, much less loading screens, quite beautiful graphics, more detailed locations and characters, more convenient exploration and the map (now it is possible to put marks). Side quests are on the same level, that's not bad. The atmosphere is also unchanged from the previous part.[/b]

[b] [u]Conclusion [/u][/b] 

[b]I can say that the game is much more comfortable to play now.[/b] I used to get tired of the fights by the end of the game, especially when the game gave a lot of enemies at once (it was quite uncomfortable). But now this has been fixed, and I really enjoyed the fights in this part. The story isn't bad either, the exploration, as I said, is made more interesting by the new engine. [b]All in all, for me, it's a great game with some minor flaws.[/b]

I enjoyed this game just like I have enjoyed all of the other Yakuza games. It has the same weak points as the other ones, which is that the story is just too convoluted and involves too many characters to keep up with. Also, having played a lot of these games now, I feel like the character of Haruka has been underutilized in a lot of ways so far. I wish she did more in the game. Kiryu is a good protagonist as always. I was also glad to see Majima make an appearance in this game and get his own side story. The ‚ÄúMajima Saga‚Äù was not very long lasting, but was enjoyable. I do wish that they had made it more like Yakuza 0 where you could play as Majima on the same level and with the same amount of options as Kiryu. A lot of the side elements in this game were fun, but they lasted too long or had too many parts. After a while, anything gets repetitive and boring and that was the case here with a lot of the side elements. The cabaret club missions were fine, but it took a long time to build up relationships with the hostesses and complete their side stories. The bouncer missions were an interesting addition and they offered nice prizes but there were way too many of them and the last couple were needlessly difficult. The clan creator missions lasted for too many rounds. Each one should have been 6 rounds max. There were ones that lasted 10 or 12 or even 17 rounds, which was just way too many and felt kind of boring after a while. Satisfying Haruki‚Äôs requests was fine, but again, there were way too many of them to satisfy. Also, the poker request was abnormally difficult. The karaoke request was also a pain for me personally. Karaoke in Yakuza Kiwami 2 is just so much harder than it should be. But overall, this game was enjoyable. I am still holding out hope that they will make ‚ÄúKiwami‚Äù remakes of Yakuza 3, 4, & 5. I will definitely play those if or when they do.

A pretty good follow up to Kiwami 1. There's, once again, a ton to do and I could probably spend another 10-15 hours if I wanted to complete the game. I won't though, since that would include doing all the boring/annoying activities that I don't want to do. 

While the dragon engine looks fantastic, overall I kinda feel like condensing fighting styles into just one was a step down. You'll pretty much just be using the same handful of combos the entire game. There's also a lot of jank that comes with the new engine. Sometimes it's hilarious ragdolling of the enemies, but there were a couple serious bugs I ran into:

-later in the game you can hang out with Haruka and fulfilling her requests would almost freeze the game. Her affection meter would start to increase EXTREMELY slowly to the point that I thought I was soft-locked. Apparently if you just pause and un-pause the game repeatedly until it's done, that fixes it. Later on this stopped happening.

-The "Fists of Fury" technique seems to be bugged to the point where it's less an upgrade and more a fatal downgrade. You're SUPPOSED to be able to chain 3 charge attacks together but when charging the 2nd, Kiryu never finishes charging and is just stuck in a charging state until you reset the game or the enemy kills him. I think it has something to do with the higher frame rate afforded by the PC version. Kinda crazy this hasn't been patched.

Other than those few issues and some tedium, which is mostly skipable (I refuse to learn how to play shogi or majhong and no one can convince me otherwise), the game is a lot of fun. 

TL;DR:
Game is good. If you've played other Yakuza games, you'll like it. If you like bizarre Japanese humor, you'll like it. If you like beat-em-up games with RPG elements added for good measure, you'll like it. There are some annoyances and if you set out for 100% completion, you'll probably hate it, but I found it very fun to just do what I wanted and leave the rest.

[h1]This isn't actually a game, it's a collection of plot twists.[/h1]

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is the newest remake in the Yakuza series from SEGA, bringing over the 2006 PS2 game to modern consoles. This one will be a real treat for Yakuza fans, considering it's been long-regarded as the best game in the Yakuza series. That claim might be a little more contested with newer releases like Yakuza 0, but there's still no denying that Yakuza 2 is a fantastic game, and this Kiwami remake only improves the overall experience.

The story for Yakuza Kiwami 2 picks up not long after the events of the first game. If for some reason this is your first entry in the series, the game provides a decent enough recap of the events prior, so it isn't that difficult to get caught up. One thing that really stands out with Yakuza Kiwami 2 when compared to the later games in the series, is that series protagonist Kazuma Kiryu hasn't completely given up on his Yakuza background and the Tojo Clan, which makes for a more intriguing crime story overall. The introduction of the Division Four police, Korean Mafia, and other elements make for a fun ride. Everything about the story holds up well, which I was happy to see.

There's a whole host of new elements found in Yakuza Kiwami 2, like the use of the Dragon engine from Yakuza 6, new mini-games, side-stories, and even plot elements that help tie Yakuza 2 more into the existing games in the series. Majima has his own side-story via the Majima Construction plotline, the Host Club mini-game from Yakuza 0 shows up here, and you'll get even more New Japan Pro wrestlers via the Clan mode that was introduced in Yakuza 6. There is a ton of side activities packed into the game, the majority of which feel worthwhile. There's several other games to play, found in other Yakuza titles, like Mahjong, SEGA arcade titles such as Virtua Fighter 2.1, and even a, uh, urinal mini-game.

Along with the plethora of side activities, Yakuza Kiwami 2 adopts the combat and experience system of Yakuza 6. Kiryu will encounter enemies on the map highlighted by red icons that patrol the streets. If they spot Kiryu, they'll run up to him and initiate a seamless combat transition. Defeating enemies will earn Kiryu experience, which can be even further advanced by visiting the various restaurants and consuming food to heal up and gain experience bonuses. Kiryu has access to a ton of skills, some of which are combat based, while others are designed to boost experience gains, your hunger meter, or aid in the various mini-games like the Host Club or the Majima Construction scenario.

Like other Yakuza titles, combat is essentially a beat 'em up, wherein you'll use punches and kicks to take down enemies with varying combo attacks. The system seems basic on the surface, but as you unlock additional abilities for Kiryu, you'll gain access to additional heat moves for disabling foes, improved dodge and parry attacks, and even team-up abilities that depend on where you are in town, allowing an NPC to join the fray if you've already completed his or her quest. It's a pretty dynamic system overall, and while not new to the series, the frantic action keeps the constant encounters feel fresh and exciting.

I really, really enjoyed my time with Yakuza Kiwami 2, and as a fan of the series, I'd certainly urge you to check it out. It has very few flaws, outside of some minor animation issues and the occasional cumbersome combat sequence. It also feels like a much stronger remake than even Yakuza Kiwami, which was no slouch to begin with. It also has some solid ties to both Yakuza 0 via the new elements, and pre-existing story beats that feed into the more recent Yakuza 6. So check this one out when you get a chance, you will not be disappointed.

I'd say this is one of the series best games. If Zero is a 100/100, this is 95/100 IMO. It's story is so good, its perfect. It has the best villain in the entire series in my opinion. The music is great, especially the final boss theme. The combat feels great and feels like hits actually connect with enemies, unlike past games where it kind of felt like 2 characters doing canned animations while standing next to each other. 

The ragdolls and physics are too over the top though, such as how far enemies can be flung. It looks janky and can interrupt combos, such as when enemies get flung too far away to follow up with a heat move before they get back up. Walking into certain objects will cause the object to totally get destroyed and Kiryu kind of spazzes out. The majority of the time the physics aren't really that bad.

(it's weird that Low/Medium/High settings all run at ~45, and Ultra gets 30) I have a GTX 970 and Intel i5 processor.

edit: I upgraded to a RTX 3080 TI and Ryzen 7 and now the game runs flawlessly at 1440p 120+ fps.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 took me a long time to beat. As with the last two games, the story here is top-notch - a little better than both of them, if I'm being perfectly honest. The graphics here are prettier than ever, and while seeing Kamurocho one more year into the future was cool, it was Sotenbori that caught my attention this time around. Of course, much of this is made up of reused assets, polished up for the new engine. No, what's new here is the combat. With revamped animations and a brand new engine, Yakuza Kiwami 2 was poised to blow me away with an improvement on the combat system. Unfortunately, the improvements present in the rest of the game were lacking from the combat, leaving it simple, button-mashey, and downright unfun. The only things carrying it were the fight music in Sotenbori and the flashy animations. Beyond that, the upgrade system of 0 and Kiwami, unlocking new moves as you progress to make combat skill-based, is gone too - in favour of flat stat upgrades to a set-in-stone moveset. Compounding the issue is how unbalanced the game is. By the end of the game, I was past fully leveled - and I went out of my way to avoid combat for the whole game. All in all, Yakuza Kiwami 2 presents the best experience in the series so far, provided you stay out of fights. That's hard to do though, as almost every sub story in this game ends in combat, with all the exceptions being the best sub stories (go figure). I like this game, but I probably won't replay it. Yakuza Kiwami 2 gets a 7/10 from me.

Pros : 
- New Dragon Engine looks gorgeous. Being able to just walk in and out of the stores/restaurants/game centers looks and feels good.
- Larger inventory is pretty cool. Not so much a fan of the 10 recovery item cap after being able to take 20 Staminan Royales in previous entries, but items didn't stack in 0 or Kiwami 1.
- Combat is nice. I don't mind the shift away from the stance system, I quite like Dragon style and it makes sense not to have the other styles here.
- If you didn't like not being able to play as Majima in the previous Kiwami, you'll enjoy the Majima Saga side content!
- Glad to see 0's cabaret club side story make a reappearance.

Cons :
- Heat actions feel more scarce this time around and some are location-locked (and are ultimately the same heat action of An Ally Tosses You A One-Time Use Item With Different Animation).
- Not a fan of the levelling system here. Before, you either had to invest actual in-game cash to level up (0), or allocate experience in whatever skill you required (Kiwami 1). Here, you essentially have 5 types of experience, and each skill requires some amount of each, whether that's just one type or a combination of them. On the plus side it gives AppStims use here; the best way to get experience is to eat at restaurants. 
- Tied to previous, also not a fan of having to seek out some of the requisite items/activities in order to unlock all of Kiryu's abilities.
- Majima's side content is rather short at 3 chapters long and there's not as much to do aside from go from plot point to plot point.
- Not personally a fan of the Kamurocho Hills side story game (but I'm not good at strategy in the first place).
- Kept running into a crash during Chapter 8's midpoint cutscene.

Nitpicky garbage:
- UFO catcher physics are kinda weird this time around, the prizes feel heavier than they should be.
- The Toylets minigame doesn't work properly due to framerate issues. There's apparently a patch that works for it but I couldn't figure it out. Completionists are gonna have a harder time with this one.

I liked this one a lot better than Kiwami 1 now that I'm aware the story gets very grim at points, but this seems to be where the series also gets a bit goofier and hard to take seriously. This feels like a crime drama directed by M. Night Shyamalan and I love it. (3/5)

Yakuza Kiwami 2, developed and published by Sega, is a stunning remake of the classic 2006 PlayStation 2 game, Yakuza 2. As a part of the acclaimed Yakuza series, this installment combines an engaging narrative, intense combat, and a richly detailed open-world setting. With improved graphics, enhanced gameplay mechanics, and additional content, Yakuza Kiwami 2 delivers a memorable and satisfying experience for both newcomers and longtime fans.

Storyline:
Yakuza Kiwami 2 plunges players into the gripping tale of Kazuma Kiryu, a former yakuza member turned restaurateur. The story takes place in the fictional city of Kamurocho, a bustling urban environment that serves as the backdrop for political intrigue, power struggles, and deep-seated conflicts within the criminal underworld. The narrative is filled with intricate plot twists, memorable characters, and intense emotional moments, weaving a complex web that keeps players invested from start to finish.

Gameplay:
The gameplay in Yakuza Kiwami 2 offers a seamless blend of exploration, combat, and side activities. Kamurocho is beautifully recreated, capturing the essence of Japan's vibrant city streets. Players can freely roam the city, interact with its inhabitants, and engage in a variety of side quests and mini-games. Whether it's hitting up a karaoke bar, playing arcade games, or managing a cabaret club, the wealth of distractions in the game world is truly impressive.

Combat is the heart of Yakuza Kiwami 2, featuring intense brawls and brutal finishing moves. Kiryu's combat abilities have been refined, allowing for fluid combos, powerful heat actions, and the ability to wield weapons found in the environment. The combat system strikes a satisfying balance between complexity and accessibility, providing an exhilarating experience that keeps players on their toes.

Visuals and Sound:
Yakuza Kiwami 2 benefits from a significant graphical overhaul, making the streets of Kamurocho more vibrant and lifelike than ever before. The character models are highly detailed, showcasing meticulous facial animations and expressive gestures that enhance the emotional impact of the story. The game's attention to detail extends to its sound design, with a stellar voice cast delivering exceptional performances and a captivating soundtrack that effortlessly sets the tone for each scene.

Improvements and Additions:
The remake of Yakuza 2 not only enhances the visuals but also includes new story content that further fleshes out the game's world. The "Majima Saga" is a separate campaign featuring fan-favorite character Goro Majima, providing valuable insights into his motivations and actions. This addition adds significant value to the overall package, giving players a deeper appreciation for the narrative and its characters.

Conclusion:
Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a testament to the incredible craftsmanship of the Yakuza series. Its gripping story, engaging gameplay, and immersive world make it a standout title in the action-adventure genre. Whether you're a fan of the original Yakuza 2 or a newcomer to the series, this remake offers an exceptional experience that shouldn't be missed. Step into the shoes of Kazuma Kiryu once again and prepare yourself for a journey through the heart of the criminal underworld. Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a must-play for anyone seeking an unforgettable gaming experience.

The game is great as always. It's Yakuza. It's fun and you should play it.

However, there are some adjustments you will have to make when coming from Y0-5 or Kiwami. The fighting and combat are more "dynamic" and make use of the environment, but aside from that the combat has been super-simplified. Say goodbye to fighting styles or the classic intricate beat-em-up gameplay. Fights are now pretty janky and have been simplified into what is basically 2 buttons. This becomes especially apparent in the Majima DLC when you compare him to Y0's Mad Dog style.

The graphics are 10 steps forward and 1 step back. Everything looks higher-quality and the environments are [i]BEAUTIFUL[/i], but the rendering techniques they adopted makes hair, beards and eyebrows look weird. It also loses a lot of fidelity with transparent surfaces like glass and water, making the developers opt to make most of these opaque mirrors instead of see-through. It's clear the game was developed with nighttime in mind, because during daytime the environments look pretty bland, only coming to life during the absolutely stunning nighttimes.

This game is a solid recommendation if you're into Yakuza, but if you're new to the series please play 0 and Kiwami first. If the combat in those games is the main thing that got you hooked and not the story, environments, characters or side-activities then skip Yakuza 6 and skip this one.

[h1] It's great and different, maybe a little bit too different [/h1]

[b] General Things [/b]

First, I will talk about the graphics, the open world, and just basic general things. Oh my god, the step up from quality is incredible and it fulfilled the expectations that I had for Kiwami 1. It's so cool that you don't have to transition scenes when doing things, like getting in and out of fights, getting inside building, you can even FIGHT in buildings. I think it's so cool that you can be more interactive with the area unlike the 2 previous games. The soundtrack is amazing as always. The story and characters were pretty nice, it didn't have enough time to flesh out all of them so I understand that, you will have to play the other games to get the characters and story more which is a common theme for Yakuza and other games I guess. 

[b] The Gameplay and The New Engine[/b]

The gameplay is so different from the previous 2, I'm gonna talk about the movement first. The movement, it's pretty smooth I guess? The only complain I could have is that you move out of the way way too much to avoid collision, I have no particular qualms about there not being a jog, it gives you a better feel of the human world of this game I guess, but gameplay wise I can see how people would dislike that. The New Engine is extremely goofy man it affects the combat too. For the open world experience with the engine, literally everything falls over the moment you slightly brush it everything felt way too fragile. Everyone flies around too much and I can't get the feel of caving in their faces in with them literally ascending after I punch them like 4 times the engine and the new ragdoll mechanics do not compliment each other unless you like goofy physics. The Combat was extremely underwhelming with that, all of the attacks felt really weak. The new sounds they use when you hit someone is way too "tame" I guess? 

[b] Difficulty [/b]

This game is so easy, when I was fighting one of the last boss: [Spoiler]Ryuji[/spoiler], he had a katana so I thought it would be cool to match him with my own, but all it took was the same rush attacks, and SPAMMED heat actions(I think I used a heat action at least 10 times in that fight), it was ridiculously easy that I was about to be extremely disappointed, but when the real last fight showed up it made up for it sort of. Speaking of the combat, I have a complaint with the new unlocking moves system. It was extremely limited and when I was gonna unlock heat actions, all you would see is coop moves and stuff. It was extremely disappointing when I just first started playing, not only was everyone was flying around in a single hit, now I barely even have any moves to do that? I think this specific entry more emphasizes on the weapons, because I barely even needed to use the infamous tiger drop, it was nerfed to hell so there was no specific reason to even use it. The early game fights were extremely limited and disappointing that I had to google specific things I CAN do just to make myself less bored. But it's all mostly fine when you level up to have more moves and heat actions. 

[b] Final Rating and thoughts [/b]

9/10. It's still Yakuza overall. The combat was just a little bit of a downgrade.

A bipolar mix of deadly serious and insanely silly. This game is both a gritty gangster sim of brutal violence and grim acceptance of fate- and - a game where your character sings karaoke, fights Yakuza dressed in diapers, and models for a photographer in a banana hammock, Thru the use of exclusively Japanese dialog, the realism of the city areas on the map, and even the cultural quirks of Japan to western eyes- the game is very immersive. Excellent voice acting that largely avoids the more extreme 'anime' type deliveries makes the world feel real enough to forgive the acts of murder you will dole out fully in public. Roaming gangs of bad guys mean that you will essentially achieve serial killer numbers just walking down the block with no one caring a bit. 
There are a large number of mechanics at work but none of it slows the pace of the game. Likewise, there are more novelty and side activities to enjoy that it puts GTA to shame. But none of them take very long or are difficult to complete with a controller. With so many things to do, just wandering the map at walking pace never feels slow and gives the fairly small maps a much bigger presence than sheer square footage. 
The story is deep, involved, and frankly convoluted as is common with Japanese serials. Despite the array of over the top crazy characters involved, the story itself is a familiar tale of the young turks rejecting tradition versus the old school gangsters that hold to a code. 
At times Kiwami 2 is more of an interactive move with long cutscenes where the player has no control, and to my knowledge no way to skip the scene. These can take long enough to go make a sandwich before control is handed back to the player. 
Combat is an absolute joy of senseless violence. Animations look fine at full speed but there are tons of close up and slow motion 'kill cam' moments that push the brutality envelope. Environmental kills also exist with suitably gory results. Side quests are often very brief and easy but can result in an 'ally' that will intervene on your behalf if a fight occurs close enough to them. While on the easy difficulty you can basically button mash thru most of the game, on harder difficulties you will need to bring a bit more skill to the party. However it only feels punishing when some enemies seem to magically block attacks endlessly. These fights drag on as you chip away at the boss then back off while he attacks, rinse and repeat. Weapons are rather limited in uses before they require repair and often I simply rely on fists and overwhelming violence to carry the day. 
The mix of comedy and serious story works well. Left fully to either the story and game would feel plodding or the comedy would wear itself out quickly. Together they balance the experience for the long haul. 
This was my introduction to the series and while it is part of an ongoing series, the story is self-contained enough to stand on it's own. There are constant references (and an entire re-cap movie if you choose) to the earlier games but you don't have to have played them to enjoy this one. 
Recommend just for the sheer depth of story, fun combat, and moments of utter insanity that make the game difficult to classify in any one genre.
