The pacing of the story is almost too fast, not in that it's short (it's definitely not), but in that it usually wouldn't make sense for Kiryu to be doing anything but continuing the plot. I think it actually does that for more of the runtime than Yakuza 0 does.
It's a fantastic game, sequel, and entry in this series.

Yakuza KIWAMI 2 still has all these things, except the actual GAME part is HORRIFIC (in comparison to Yakuza 2).
I'm not a big fan of Kiwami 1 either, but in that case there is WAY more reason to play that one over the original. The first game had a forced English dub on PS2 when localized. The gameplay was pretty stiff. Majima wasn't everywhere (I actually prefer that, but whatever). So, as annoying and occasionally rushed as Kiwami is for me, I completely understand why people would play it over the original, and I can recommend it.

Kiwami 2 is not a game I can recommend over the original. The gameplay is decently fast, but it's an unforgiving chore. Not in that it's super difficult to win fights. More in that it wastes your time constantly. The only way to feel like you're having fun on a consistent basis is by picking up every weapon you see, which admittedly is something I wish I could do in the other games sometimes. The physics of the Dragon Engine are obnoxious and remove most of the weight from the combat. I have this same complaint in Judgment and Like a Dragon as well, but it's way less upsetting in those games. In this (and Yakuza 6 as well, I assume), taking out an enemy in brutal fashion feels a lot less satisfying than it should because their model bounces and floats around like a balloon. It's funny out of context, but for a whole game it just gets old. Kiryu also flies around like a balloon a lot, and that's really annoying as well. The newer Dragon Engine games keep these physics, but they're toned down a bit. Most of the ridiculous stuff happens with environments rather than characters themselves now. More importantly though, the gameplay just isn't very fun in this game compared to many of the others. I would say this and Yakuza 6 probably have the least enjoyable combat in the series, and since that's the main gameplay, it's just a chore as a result.

Performance-wise, it's a very demanding game, to the point where it's now the ONLY Yakuza game on modern consoles that you can't run at 60fps under any circumstances. My laptop (9th gen i7 and GTX 1650 with 16GB RAM) could barely run the thing over 30fps at very low settings in 720p. My current rig (i7-12700k, RX 6650 XT, 32GB DDR5) also struggles with the game at 4k, but admittedly conquers it at 1080p. I don't have any other Dragon Engine games on PC, so I can't really compare against them at the moment. My biggest technical complaints are that you can't remove the green tint over everything, and that ONLY ONE SETTING in the ENTIRE MENU changes the frame-rate at all (Render Scale). Not even V-Sync or Anti-Aliasing changes anything. It's all about render scale or just resolution. Very odd way to optimize a game in my opinion.

I could also go into a lot of other stuff like Kiryu not having a jog, the AWFUL upgrade system, the weird hunger stuff, licensing issues with music, etc.

It's not like it's a horrible game overall. There's good stuff in there. In fact, I'd even say it's a pretty good game. It's just that most of the good is from the original, which I would argue has some of the best gameplay in the series.

So, I can't really recommend you play this game, at least, not over the original.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is the remake of the second Yakuza game. In this game, Kiryu Kazuma takes an early retirement as Tojo Clan Chairman, in the hopes that he can finally have a normal life after being a yakuza has taken so much from him. Unfortunately, he'll get sucked back into the yakuza life, as the Omi Alliance and other major clans from China and Korea threaten to absorb the Tojo Clan entirely into their fold. Additionally, a new Dragon rises to the fight, as Ryuji Goda challenges Kiryu to find out who will be the one and only Dragon of Dojima.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 may be a contender for my favorite Yakuza game so far in the series. The game took so many improvements from 0 and Kiwami 1 and made a truly stellar Yakuza experience out of it. While your fighting styles have been reduced from four to one, the one being the Dragon of Dojima style, combat has never felt better. Your punches and kicks feel like they carry so much explosive impact with them and despite having no styles with unique actions you still retain a lot of those actions, which are now just usable at all times, such as Rush's Quickstep or Beast's lethality with various bicycles. The story is just as exciting as previous entries, with plenty of intense action and serious yakuza tension piled on top of your regular dose of goofy as heck side missions. The boss fights (most of them, I fucking *hate* Man in Black) are super fun to play and yet again show how Yakuza games know how to do quicktime events right. Kiwami 2 feels like such a great example of all the things a Yakuza game can be.

In terms of downsides, there aren't a tremendous amount. There are some framerate issues on some of the minigames, most notably karaoke. In karaoke, the framerate of the lyrics doesn't match the words which doesn't match the background which doesn't match the notes, which makes playing it a headache, which SUCKS because there are some banger songs in this game. The XP and skill system in this game is a little cumbersome to navigate through. XP is separated into categories that aren't the most intuitive as to what you need to do to gain XP in a specific category, and gaining XP from meals is gated behind a hunger gauge that incentivizes eating healthier or more expensive food, but often just means eating food can lead to wasted money sometimes. 

Minor gripes aside, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a stellar Yakuza game that fans of Yakuza 0 and Kiwami will absolutely adore. I cannot recommend this game enough to those who enjoyed the previous entries, a 9/10 entry in the series for me.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a fantastic game that successfully builds upon the already solid foundation of the original Yakuza 2 game. As a remake, it features updated graphics, new gameplay mechanics, and expanded story content that makes it an excellent addition to the series.

The game follows the story of Kazuma Kiryu, a former yakuza who is drawn back into the criminal underworld of Kamurocho, Tokyo. The game features a well-crafted narrative that blends intense action and drama with moments of humor and heartwarming character development. The voice acting and localization are excellent, which helps to bring the story and characters to life.

In terms of gameplay, Yakuza Kiwami 2 offers a mix of open-world exploration, side missions, and fast-paced combat. The combat system is fluid and engaging, with a wide variety of fighting styles and special moves to master, but it's a shame that in this series they turned the concept into one fighting style. The game also features several minigames and side activities, including hostess clubs, karaoke, and arcade games, which provide a nice change of pace from the main storyline.

One of the standout features of Yakuza Kiwami 2 is its stunning graphics and attention to detail. The game's environments are beautifully rendered, and the character models are incredibly detailed and lifelike. The soundtrack is also excellent, with a mix of upbeat and emotional tracks that enhance the game's atmosphere.

However, there are a few minor drawbacks to the game. One of the main issues is that the game can feel a bit repetitive at times, especially during the side missions and minigames. Some players may also find the characters expression a little bit off in some scenes.

Overall, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is an excellent game that offers a great mix of action, story, and gameplay. While it has a few minor flaws, the game's strengths far outweigh its weaknesses, making it a must-play for anyone who enjoys action-adventure games. If you're a fan of the series or just looking for a great game to play, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is definitely worth checking out.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is the remake of the second game in the Franchise Yakuza 2, being remade with the newest engine at the time the Dragon Engine in mind. 

The story follows Kazuma Kiryu as he tries to live his life outside of the Yakuza, as expected this does not go well for him as he is thrust back in the seriousness/wackiness of that world. You follow Kiryu as he tries to prevent a war from upheaving his life.

Combat: The combat in the game is closer to the play-style of Yakuza 6 Song of Life then it is to Yakuza 0 or Kiwami 1. This being the case makes more sense since they were make on the same engine and honestly this was a bit pleasing to me in the end because of the changes to the combat and the upgrading system for the game. Upgrading your skills in this game are more enjoyable to me at least from the previous games, Kiwami 1 being experience gain from battles in the world and from missions. Yakuza 0 upgrade system being the use of the massive amount of yen that you will acquire in your gameplay. Yakuza Kiwami 2 goes off the system of experience as well but specific types of it that you get from eating different foods around the worlds along with combat, some of these upgrades can give you boosts on your dodging or devastating skills that kill enemies instantly.

Minigames: Like many games in the franchise you can play a menagerie of different minigames spanning from Karaoke, full arcade cabinets from Sega's past, several different types of gambling(all in-game money, so not outside funds can be used for it.). But my favorite had to the Caberet Club and the Construction minigame. In the end there will be at least one minigame that you will really like as I found the ones that I really liked.

Combat: Combat is your standard beat em up for the most part, the fun part with it comes with upgrades that you get through the game. Like a lot of the games it is just fun with the combat though, through the use of weapons that you can just pick up in action or the fact that engine for the game is just wacky fun with the rag doll physics. Of you course you cannot talk about a Yakuza game without the heat actions, which I can say or enjoyable and painful to sometimes watch.

Sound and Music: Sound design for the game is top notch from just walking around the cities to the sounds of combat with the local ruffians of the cities you explore. All of this being complimented by the amazing soundtrack made for the game with most of the music fitting where it has been placed in the game.

Visuals/bugs: The game looks amazing right off the bat when you start the game, from the specks of water droplets on the character's skin to the lights reflecting off the water of rivers. Thanks to the Dragon Engine this is possible for the game. In the time that I spent playing the game I came across one instant where my game had crashed after a long gaming session, but it never happened after that one time so I do not think it was a fault of the game at all.

Overall: I enjoyed the game from start to finish, the story keeping me intrigued and dedicated throughout it's run, In the end I would recommend the game to anyone that wants to play the game for themselves or have people that want to play the game.

So why do I recommend it? Because it's just my opinion of the combat, and installing some mods from nexusmods helped with most of my issues, tho dogshit AI behaviour not. Install 'Style Switching" (adds the styles from Kiwami 1), "no player hit bounce" and if you want "yakuza kiwami licensed music restoration" as it adds the original japanese music (which is dope).

This game is a mess! But it's our mess. It's a good game that is worth investing in, but don't expect the same experience that you had in 0 and Kiwami. These are the reasons this game is quite different, not always to its benefit.

Firstly, it's extremely easy. An easy mode game for easy mode normies and game journalists. The majority of enemies are not difficult to fight, especially once you level up. It's just a grind to beat some of them, that's all. Compared to earlier games, it's much easier to achieve a high completion percentage. That's partially because there aren't that many activities to do, which is a shame.

Secondly, the story is incredibly inconsistent in its quality. Sometimes it's quite cool, at other points it's resident sleeper. Starts off really strong, then it slows down and picks up again, with various unrelated plot points thrown around. A lot of generic characters in this game, like the men in black. The main antagonists, the Koreans were ridiculously underdeveloped. The coolest character, Ryuji Goda is underused to a criminal extent, with too much focus in this game's story being on a few characters. Most of whom are not interesting! This story is super generic and doesn't make a lot of sense. That's all I can say without spoiling the details. [spoiler] FUCK THE ENDING, RETARDS ARGUING ABOUT NOTHING WHILE THE BOMB GOES OFF, PREPARED TO DIE OVER PETTY MACHISMO BULLSHIT. MAKES NO SENSE AT ALL!  [/spoiler]

Now for the good parts (and their drawbacks).

The side content is good, but kinda limited. The substories are decent, but most aren't memorable. The mini-games are fun. Virtua Fighter 2 is playable, which is awesome and kinda frustrating. Harder than all of Kiwami 2. Majima's construction is a breath of fresh air. Interesting story and the gameplay itself is awesome. It's quite tactical and interactive. The best part of it is that the characters you can hire are from substories and the coliseum, which encourages you to play the rest of the game. The cabaret club is fun, but I prefer 0's version. The best mini game is for us men of culture, if you know, you know. Komaki's training is awesome, being on the receiving end of Tiger Drop is funny. The coliseum is easy mode but fun, though I don't know what's with the annoying tigers and lions. An out of nowhere inclusion.

The soundtrack is awesome and really gives each area its own atmosphere. Outlaws' Lullaby is a classic among classics! The boss themes are epic, even though most of the bosses themselves aren't. Those being: Bad Fortune, Not Bad, Break Off, Ceiling of Needles, The Omerta, A Scattered Eternal Moment, Update With Gunfire. Being able to enter and exit many interiors without loading screens is great, and so is gaining access to rooftops. Combined with being able to run around in first person, this makes the game probably the most immersive in the series. The graphics are incredible, everything looks beri beri priti.

Bought the whole Yakuza series during Lunar New Year's sale and after that, it was my first time playing Yakuza games. Began with the Yakuza 0, followed by the Yakuza Kiwami 1. Both those games were great especially Yakuza 0 mostly because of the high-quality cinematics, that for me are the most important part of the story. 
When I thought it couldn't be any better, the Yakuza Kiwami 2 surprised me. 
Yakuza Kiwami 2 was made as a remake of the Yakuza 2 game on the new Dragon Engine, enhancing the gaming experience for this game. Not only in the cut scenes but overall the Kamurocho and Sotenbori look amazing in Dragon Engine, however, it may be a little demanding on the GPU.
So for the graphic processing, I would give this game 10/10 because it is for me so far the best-looking game in the Yakuza series.
The story is great and it fits with the previous games, but it may feel a little bit too complicated with so many unnecessary twists, but I guess that is just how the original Yakuza 2 was made, so it can't be improved much. 
This game for me was somehow special. I enjoyed the story, the graphics, the fighting system, and the upgrading system, and all of the minigames and substories were well-made thanks to the Dragon Engine that moves this game to a completely new level compared to the previous games. Plan to complete all of the side content for this one. 

Overall I would rate this game 9/10 and I wonder if there will be a better Yakuza game than this one. 
This one is in my opinion worth buying not just in bundles and during a sale but it is definitely worth the full price.

Realizing I finished 100%ing this game months ago and forgot to write a review... here goes.

[b]Yakuza Kiwami 2[/b] is a REMAKE of the [b]second[/b] game in the series, originally on PS2 (in the same way that YK1 is a remake of the first PS2 game).
I started the series with [i]Zero[/i], and have been playing them in order since (0-K1-K2 so far, waiting for a Kiwami 3 for the time being because I am [i]not[/i] suffering through Yakuza 3)

[i]Yakuza Kiwami 1 is an absolute fucking travesty to the series taking a game that already wasn't all that good and then adding every possible feature and mechanic designed to frustrate you and waste your time to the nth degree. And its story still blows despite their flimsy band-aid attempts at fixing it.[/i]

[b]You have no idea how HAPPY I am that I can't say the same for this one though.[/b]



Being made on Yakuza 6's Dragon Engine (instead of the Kiwami engine used by 0,5 and K1) you can [i]immediately[/i] tell the difference, if you're playing them in order like I am. This game is genuinely [b]gorgeous[/b], and is programmed in such a way that there are (almost) no loading screens in the game; actively exploring the city, areas and the inside of buildings will seamlessly load in with no transition. The entire areas of Kamurocho and Sotenbori are a BLAST to explore and just walk around to bask in the environment, and it helps that there's a very generous amount of collectibles to gather and general things to do, as is series tradition by now.

...I will say though, that comes with the unfortunate side effect of this PC port specifically having some shit-ass optimization issues, and a couple of things that break on the transition from console-ridden-30FPS to 60 and beyond.
Funnily enough the biggest issue, the microstuttering, is caused by a single section of code.
Either way all of that can be fixed by installing the fanmade [b]Yakuza Kiwami 2 SilentPatch[/b] (that's what it's called), which reimplements those things in a less headass way and adjusts the framerate automatically on the fly for the few minigames and things that would otherwise break on higher ones.
[strike]You really shouldn't HAVE to get a fan patch to fix the goddamn game in the first place but it's still nice that you can pretty much fix all the issues the port has with little effort[/strike]



Anyway onto the other things.
The story, while you can still tell it's a bit old, is a MASSIVE INSANE improvement over the weird bullshit the first game's story was, with its 50% filler, asspulls, deus ex machinas and terrible Hollywood-ass villain of the week that pops out of nowhere and kills what was already a kind of mediocre plot.

This time it deals with the topic of foreign mafias (and not just the pathetic Snake Flower Triad, I mean an actual-ass Korean mafia), their association with a rival local clan, a multi-generational clan-wide grudge, an entire borderline mutiny that's going to screw over an attempted alliance with said local clan, and the absolutely [i]dire[/i] consequences for both clans that come from that.
The stakes are really high this time around, you [i]see[/i] things actually going down.
Also 2 introduces Daigo who [i]immediately[/I] became one of my favorite characters by a good margin... He's so level-headed compared to a lot of other characters around him.
[spoiler]I LOVE that Daigo notices the dumbass protagonists just left a perfectly usable gun next to the villain they just non-lethally beat up, and instead of just standing there and letting an important character die because of it (like in YAKUZA 1!!!!!!!!!!), he just ACTUALLY jumps in and shoots the guy himself, it's goddamn INSANE that nobody else had bothered doing that until now.[/spoiler]
Granted, Date is still the useless drag that he was in 1, and only holds everyone else back, but that's what comes with being a character from 1. Haruka is also unfortunately still present, but she plays a much lesser role here, being instead replaced by Sayama, a policewoman who tags along with you semi-early on and can actually mostly fend for herself for a change.

That said. As much as I appreciate most of this game's story.

...That stuff aside, the rest of of it, right?
The music, the cutscenes, the overall mood and atmosphere of the game.
It's good, it's just good, it's REALLY good in fact, I can't really hold anything against it. It's just a bit of a shame the story ends like that.



The Dragon Engine makes combat [i]ridiculously[/i] fun to play around with, especially with the sheer amount of things you can upgrade and unlock to beef up your moveset. And I don't mean just stat boosts and Heat Actions (i.e. glorified cutscenes that deal damage), I mean extra moves, charged attacks which are genuinely really fun to play around with and melt enemy guards like butter, running variants of your attacks, entire COUNTER-type moves that put the Tiger Drop to shame and let you absolutely destroy people.
Of course, the ragdoll physics are just a nice cherry on top, it makes dropkicking a guy and sending him flying across the street THAT much funnier.

[i]Some people have said that the physics "make the combat less realistic so it's bad" but honestly
[b]shut up LMAO this is the same game where a guy punches a tiger head-on and knocks it out instantly, i'll take a more FUN game over a more realistic one that I can get a pointless "grown-up gamer" ego boost from playing or whatever[/b][/i]

My only real gripe with the combat system is that having your attacks blocked by an enemy briefly "stuns" you based on the strength of the attack you were performing.
But even then you can circumvent that by just using a charged attack to dropkick their figurative and literal ass and break their guard, THEN you can beat them up to your heart's content. It's just fun.

Got a lot of side content for that too in the bouncer missions; it's like they wanted to still HAVE "climax battles" but actually letting you access your inventory/gear/weapons so they moved that into the game/savefile itself and you do them from there.
It's only [i]slightly[/i] annoying in the way it has 3 difficulties for every mission so you're expected to play them all thrice by extension.




[b]TLDR:[/b] Good game, VERY good game. Get it on a sale, and for the love of GOD don't spend money on the stupid DLC that literally just gives you overpowered weapons and minigame advantages.
But definitely get it, and play it.
Just remember to download the fanmade SilentPatch to fix the odd issues this port has.

Having recently finished Kiwami and being disappointed with it after how great Yakuza 0 was, I'm glad to say that this sequel improves upon its predecessor in every single way, and surpasses Yakuza 0 in some aspects too.

The visuals are the most notable improvement in this game, running on the engine that was first introduced in Yakuza 6. Kamurocho and Sotenbori both look great and the character models are noticeably better too. Perhaps the best part about the new engine is that there are far less loading screens in the open world; you can enter and exist most buildings seamlessly and the random fights initiate much faster too. In addition to this, the interactivity with the city during the fights is greatly improved, allowing you to throw opponents through shop windows and knock items flying off shelves in the convenience stores (among other things).

The main story is also good, though not quite on par with the excellent story that Yakuza 0 had. Though as this is a remake of the second game, it can't really be held against the team who made Kiwami 2.

The minigames are what truly make this game one of the best in the series however. All of the classic minigames like Karaoke, Mahjong and the Sega arcade make a return and are as good as ever and the cabaret club and construction company games are excellent for the most part.

I haven't talked about the fighting system at all in this review, and that's because its not much different to how it was in the previous games, bar the removal of multiple fighting stances. It also isn't the main reason why I play these games. All I'll say is that if you liked the fighting in Kiwami or 0, you'll probably enjoy this too.

Overall, Kiwami 2 is an excellent sequel and well worth playing for anyone who enjoys this series.

Yakuza Kiwami 2, the remake of the original Yakuza 2 for the PS2. It came out on Steam on May 9th 2019, and amen for that. Having those games on PC, to me, is something amazing.


Gameplay: To talk about the gameplay of any of the game on this series is to talk about a lot of different things. The main loop involves walking around a district of Japan, usually Kamurocho, and finding things to do. In-between said things, you might stumble on some people who are looking for a fight.
	
	Fighting: The fighting in this game is more simplified than the other games on this series, like Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1, having no style switching, but it is still fun. The main combat attacks consist of pressing Light Attack to chain moves and Heavy Attack to end the combo altogether, like those Dragonball Budokai Tenkaichi games. Light -> Heavy is one thing, while Light -> Light -> Heavy is another. You can also hold the buttons of each attack to charge an different move. But the big thing on any Yakuza game are the Heat Attacks. Below your Health, there is a Heat gauge, which fills as you land hits and depletes as you take them. This back and forth encourages the player to be very careful on their moves. Having enough, you can unleash an Heat Attack, which are contextual moves that deal a lot of damage. Being near an enemy alone can trigger one Heat Attack, while having them attacking you and pressing the button before they make contact is another. The sheer variety of those attack are so cool and makes the game very enterteining. After winning a bout, you get 5 different types of XP, which are used to purchase new abilities, from being able to do new heat attacks, to beat able to run for more time. Each type of XP is associated with different aspects of Kiryu, and you can get more of one when doing specific things. Each skill requires a certain number of points from each type to be purchased, or just a lot of one type, and so forth. The funny thing, a great way to get those points is to eat.
	
When not fighting, there are a ton of minigames. From karaoke, to golfing, to mahjong, or shogi, the fact that there are so many things to do makes the game very hard to categorize. Yes, combat it what you do the most, but some of the best things about this game is being able to feel how lively Kamurocho, and Sotenbori in this case, are. Besides those, there are main story missions, and substories missions. Which mostly consists of watching cutscenes, running somewhere, or fighting. The story itself is interesting enough that you are motived to keep going, with amazing characters, specially the protagonist, Kiryu. Substories are more up in the air about what they will ask to do, but they usually are the main source of fun of the game, and some of its most memorable parts. Either emotional or laugh out loud funny, you will enjoy yourself.

Another important thing is the hunger system. When hungry, you can visit a restaurant and eat the food they serve. Doing so will give you Health, and more importantly XP depeding on the dish, and eating the entire menu of a restaurant will give you a little bit more, as well as eating specific combinations of food. However, eating when not hungry will just refill your health. You will need to wait for Kiryu to get hungry again to get XP.

Story:

	Kiwami 2's story takes place about a year after the events of the first Kiwami game, which is just the first game in the series remastered. It is an interesting crime drama about a conspiracy to start a major war between two yakuza clans. While Yakuza 0's story still is, to me at least, the beast, this one is also good, having great characters who are well utilized and great moments.

Visuals and Sounds:

	The fabled Dragon Engine used for Yakuza 6 is used here too, and it looks very beautiful. While facial expressions are serviceable to today's standards, the models and lighting looks very good. I remember playing it for the first time fresh out of Kiwami 1 and being blown away by the amount of detail that Kamurocho had to offer now. The district itself is a character in those games, and seeing this beautiful is very fulfilling.
	
	Sound design is also good. See, I've never payed active atenttion to sound design, but I plan to change that in future reviews. But suffice to say that every sound is exactly what you spec on a game this beautiful.
	
	The mixture of both these elements lends itself perfect to of the games best aspects, the action. Every impact has a satisfying feel, both in game and cutscenes. And when a punch has no effect on a cutscenes, it's on purpose and really, really funny.

After Kiwami 1 re-used practically everything from Yakuza 0, I expected Kiwami 2 to do the same. To my surprise, Kiwami 2 looks and plays nothing like its predecessors. It's a new coat of paint with a refreshed gameplay loop and absolutely astounding and surprising seamlessness that you would normally only see in a first-party Sony blockbuster title.
10/10 Yakuza great as always

TLDR: Definitely a huge downgrade from the previous games. Seems like the introduction of the Dragon Engine took priority, leaving the game with lackluster resources.

Graphics:
About the same as Yakuza Kiwami, but everything is reflective now? I'm not exactly sure why.

Storyline:
Still really good overall, but very predictable. Every plot twist can be seen a mile away. Some parts were very odd though... like the age gap between the 2 lovers in the story.
I really hate the changes they made to the substories. Substories now become available at like 2 points in the game, meaning if you clear all the available ones at those points you won't have any more to look forwards to.

Price:
Get it on sale. Please don't pay full price.

Difficulty:
It's as hard as you make it (your choices effect the difficulty).

AI:
Not brilliant, but not dumb

Cutscenes:
Largely downgraded from Yakuza Kiwami. Many are back to the text-based ones of Yakuza 0 and the ones present have a noticeable lack of quality. Characters will teleport from position to position, breaking immersion.

Fun:
Exploring the world and seeing everything new added was a blast! Kamurocho is almost exactly the same as in the previous game, but Sotenbori is back with a near complete remaster!
Combat has been heavily downgraded. All movesets are combined into one in a very clunky and awkward system. Majima is still not a playable character (even less important to the story now), meaning his amazing moves are still missing.
The new physics engine really makes the game annoying. Certain moves can only be performed when enemies are in certain states - but it's a gamble whether they'll just teleport to their feet or fall in a position which makes it impossible to interact with them. It really makes the game more annoying.
Bonding with Haruka is just atrocious. I don't want to have to play the miserable Sega arcade games or ace every Karaoke song to progress the story. Just... why?

Sounds/Music:
Not bad, not good. Very strange audio mixing, especially in cutscenes. Sounds will start, last for a second, and stop. It's strange.

Replayability:
Imagine a 30 hour movie... would you want to rewatch it over and over?

Controls:
Use a controller. Do not try to use a keyboard, it will not end well for you. Feels great on controllers though.

Performance:
The new Dragon Engine gobbles up system resources. I had to lower the game setting to Medium to get it to run at a solid 60 fps (PC: i7-7700, 16GB ram, GTX 1060 6GB).

Modding:
None

Selling Out:
There is now a DLC which makes the Clan Creator business extremely easy. It's essentially Sega selling pay to win items in a singleplayer game.

Similar Games:
- Any other Yakuza game.
- Combat feels like arcade brawlers, like Mortal Combat.

Bugs:
- Audio cuts in and out
- Physics is just unreliable
Please finish Yakuza 0 before you play Majima Saga.

My opinion of this game is heavily colored by my opinions on Y0 and YK1, so take that into consideration when reading this review. 

As a whole, I think Kiwami 2 did a good job changing up the formula of 0 and 1, but has its own share of rough patches not present in either. The combat and progression systems are heavily revamped in a way that keeps things fresh for people who just played the previous two titles, and the minigames are overall pretty solid. The story is stronger than K1's story but still frequently feels like Kiryu lacks agency. Also, the casting of yet another foreign (to japan) ethnic mob as a villain faction plus the inability to get a coherent message across regarding the role of the police in the criminal underworld reminds me of K1's story in a bad way. 


Overall, you can see that an effort was made to keep things interesting, and to make side content that wasn't a complete chore. But this is at the expense of the main story's quality, and there's a lot of polish missing compared to 0 and K1 (like how almost no side content is voice-acted). But it's more Kiryu, so if you're coming off the previous games and want to find out how the funny yakuza man continues to suffer then you'll get your fix.

Amongst the highest peak of the Yakuza series, now spaning over 10 games and nearly 20 years since I first touched it on my old pirated PS2 copy. Plus, it goes on pretty cheap during sales! It has flaws, both in of itself and in artistic choices, mainly due to the latest engine being different in parts from the old PS2 and PS3 engines. It also started to peek its head into predatory DLCs with the minigame focused ones that add characters to an otherwise fairly simple and fun (in a grindy way) minigame, all to lure people that like throwing money at every DLC on the store. 

Of note, you should have a controller for the complete experience, trying to play on the keyboard isn't just heavily disadvised, I am pretty sure the devs make it clear that they never gave it a thought. Hell, the first thing you see is a warning telling you that "real Yakuza use a gamepad". Also of note, it's a direct continuation of Yakuza Kiwami 1, not to mention the amazing prequel Yakuza 0. So you should probably start with those, but the combat system is based on the original Yakuza 2, so no rush, brawler or beast styles. I say you wait and buy those three during Steam's themed sales, when you get cards and stuff, while also checking on SteamDB to see if the price really is at its lowest historically. 

Believe me, this trilogy from 0 to Kiwami 2 is like a holy trilogy, which introduced PC players to the series, breathing new life into it and making SEGA start remastering, remaking and releasing games on the West. Even previously unreleased titles, like the legendary Ishin which is being remade and going to release soon, not to mention the older rough ones like Yakuza 3 to 5. If you like brawlers this is a great game, even if you suck at it you can usually just focus on other stuff and use the myriad of items to cheat your way out of even the toughest fights on the highest difficulty. Meanwhile, you could also try a legendary no hit run and so on.

As my first experience with the Dragon Engine, as well as coming from playthroughs of both Yakuza 0 and Kiwami, I've been left a little disappointed, The game is beautiful and the seamless transitions between battles and even entering stores is great and all, but the sacrifices made to the actual combat I believe were misguided.

Firstly, the addition of ragdoll physics on downed enemies simply removes all sense of seriousness from any encounter, as well as messes with certain actions that can only be applied to enemies in downed states, as now you have to rely on the ragdolls to work with you instead of having actual, properly implemented states as seen in previous games. Furthermore, the "Fighting Stance" previously known for it's reliable lock-on, is now mostly lacking that lock-on, allowing to you easily aim attacks completely off course from your target simply because you were moving in the wrong direction. All of these culminate in my feeling of disappointment towards the growth of the series into the Dragon Engine, after having already experienced the excellent combat of previous entries.

I still recommend this game to anyone looking into getting into the Yakuza/Ryu ga Gotoku series, as the main story is most certianly worth experiencing. It's just a shame I can't appreciate the combat like I could with entries lacking the Dragon Engine.

Part Final Fight, part soap opera, part Saints Row, I'm not sure what genre this really is, actually.

It's fun, though.

The best parts are upgrading stats, eating to get experience, and fighting. That core game loop works (mostly) well here. And it gets interrupted just enough by all the mini games. Eat, mini game, fight thugs, eat, repeat. The fighting itself is good but has a spot or two where it becomes a tad clunky, especially in terms of using props/items/weapons, and the control is either too sensitive or too sluggish for me (the settings don't have a true slider, just a few notches to choose from in how sensitive the movement is). 

The only real problems are mostly movement/interface. Moving around when not fighting is bizarre... unlike the more arcade controls during fighting, while exploring it's possible to run up and press against buildings, vault over guardrails (which happens just by walking up to them even), and get too close to things to have the camera pan. It's a sort of throwback issue to the N-64 days that the camera doesn't pan well near walls. Further, as already mentioned, in the fighting itself, picking objects up and some of the context-specific moves are not at all intuitive. An instruction sometimes flashes to press this or that button, but it really is a *flash*, as in it might be up for tenths of a second. Which is something Arkham Asylum and the batman games did so much better, where the warning/indicator comes up with enough time to actually react *before* the exact moment the button needs to be pressed.

And the controls for mini-games... I get that some games vary greatly enough that they need other controls, but I feel like literally every mini-game has just completely different controls. Even the karaoke suddenly jumps to using the arrow keys rather than the WASD keys that could easily be used instead. I feel like the mini-games could have had some more controls in common between each one at times.

Ultimately a good game, and no need to play other entries in the series to enjoy it (this is the first Yakuza game I've played). 

But the camera/interface and controls are sometimes a slight hindrance, even when just roaming around.

This game is amazing, and I can easily recommend it, even if there were also aspects which dragged to me. I've had this game on my list for a long time, and have had a save in it for probably over 6 years at this point. Now, I've finally beaten it. I had previously played Yakuza 0 en the first Kiwami, as well as playing the original Yakuza way back when on the Playstation 2. 

Yakuza 0 is the best one of these games I've played so far, so when in doubt, I would go with that one over this. It is after all the first game in the story, chronologically speaking. But other than that, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is probably one of the best entries to play. It has the graphics, the modern combat engine, and it also benefits from a pretty good amount of focus on the core of the story that mostly allows it to keep things moving.

I'll start by talking about what this game does absolutely fantasically. It does many things very well. All the Yakuza games do an absolutely incredible job evoking the experience of walking through a Japanese street. From the design of the vending machines and the chairs in restaurants to the flashy neon signs of some of the bigger busy-roads: it is all incredibly true to life. The loving reenactment Tokyo and Osaka in this game is a joy to behold.

The production values on the cutscenes are also very good (unless you count the Majima side-story, in which they clearly ran out of budget to animate the characters), and the story does a good job being one of those typical yakuza flicks, which is a genre that I love. It's an adoring homage to those types of stories, and the voice acting and writing for the most part just absolutely nail that vibe. 

Furthermore, some of the set pieces are incredible. Chapter 13 in particular features a final set piece that had me roaring with laughter and glee. The mixture of the serious and the absolutely ludicrous in these games is what makes them special, much in the same way Kojima games are. There are times in this game where Kiryu's infinitely badass attitude unironically had me pumped. Some of the combat scenes in which people think they someone can be mean while Kiryu is around, that then have you beat the ever living shit out of them, are incredibly satisfying. For all of these factors, this game is supremely easy to recommend.

However, there are also a few fundamental things that I kind of dislike about this game. The first is that the combat is good, but not that good. You can do some pretty awesome stuff in this game, and the combat often looks great, and has an enormous amount of weight behind it, in a good way. But on the other hand, there are instances where it felt very stiff to me as well. Specifically, there is an enemy later on (who luckily only appears a few times) with knives on his shoes, who really highlighted to me just how clunky the combat can be at its worst. In the final 5 hours of my playthrough, the combat finally clicked for me, but this is only because I got the double dash and the best block parry move unlocked. I could have gotten them sooner, but they're still pretty late-game upgrades by virtue of being very expensive, and so either way I feel like one has to be patient in order to get them. Getting those moves finally made me feel somewhat like Kiryu was fluid. Before, the tiny dash move seemingly just did nothing to help me dodge attacks, and I would often end up just having to exchange blows with enemy and win by attrition. There is probably something fundamental I'm not getting about the combat, but if there is, it doesn't teach you it very intuitively, I feel. This despite me being someone who loves character action games and is decently good at them. 

Another thing I kind of dislike is a fundamental aspect of the characterization of Kiryu. Why do they insist on having Kiryu be sort of a saint, when his character is one of being a literal gangster? The dissonance sometimes just doesn't work for me. I'm not even talking about them pretending that he somehow doesn't kill people; I'm talking about the story contorting itself in ways in order to make sure that Kiryu is always blameless for everything. The story is a real soap opera, for better or worse. Every characters is connected to every other character in a million ridiculous ways (everyone has always met, or saved everyone else's grandfather during the war, or was in the room where the mother was giving birth to the other character by chance). Kiryu is a cool vigilante who crushes people's skulls in the streets, and takes them for hundreds of thousands of yen, but the game still unabashedly wants to convince me he's a great guy who helps grannies cross the road (which he sort of really does.)  The writers seem to think Kiryu must be seen as doing no wrong, and there are a few times in the story when that tendency deflates the impact of situations utterly. 

The final thing is that the game is still paced like a Yakuza game at the end of the day. Random encounters in the streets no longer have a cutscene (thank the lord), but there is still this awkward pauze as the game puts you into the fighting arena mode. The substories are cool (and sometimes genuinely great), but they still use that typical tap-tap-tap dialogue box style without spoken dialogue, and sometimes things just last far too long. And I personally think all of the mini-games are superfluous, and I have no desire to engage with them.

With that said! This game is really great, and I am very grateful to it for the lovely time it gave me. My weird personal complaints aside, this game is an awesome labor of love that is easy to recommend.

If Yakuza Kiwami 2 was just an instance of a sequel tightening the bolts of the foundation of the first game then this would be way easier to make any sort of broader statements on, but both fortunately and unfortunately, this is very far from the case, both with Kiwami specifically, and with Yakuza 2 as a whole. The game is very much a give and take affair in a much more prominent way compared to the first, trading in a more consistent sense of being just decent to being an experience with towering highs and absolutely miserable lows. This was something that pervaded the majority of the game both mechanically and with its presentation. Despite that however, I'd also still say that I preferred this one over Kiwami 1, as the constant roughness that paves the way for some truly glorious heights makes for something that feels far more compelling and funnily enough also way more in line with the style of the games that so often fall back on the themes of stark juxtaposition as a lot of their appeal.

With this said however, there are a few aspects of the game that just feel strictly better to me, most of all the narrative. The way Kiryu's perspective has been so warped as a continuation of the previous game's events is really compelling to follow, showing the player someone who has become entirely disillusioned with the life that they'd devoted everything to for so long after tragedies upon tragedies began piling up. The theme of attempting to come to terms one's past further solidifies this along with being a constant driving force of basically every character featured prominently, with the attitudes they take on in regards to this largely being the deciding factor of their own sense of morality. This just happens to be especially compelling with Kiryu due to the way that it even seeps into a lot of the substories featured throughout, with him feeling far more frustrated and done with all the nonsense that he gets put through in them, very rarely feeling like someone who actually wants to go along with the absurdity and instead is just strung along time and time again. It ultimately adds a further sense of cohesion and consistency to his character that has always made him so great to follow along and see the way he feels the same regardless of how stupid or intense the moment happens to be.

It's really once you get to the pure gameplay side of things where the seams really start showing here, seemingly especially with the way the Dragon Engine is set up, though it's not all bad. The way the engine allows the player to seamlessly walk into stores and even up into certain other buildings adds a lot to the sense of liveliness to the locations that you explore, which works fantastically given how much time you'll obviously be spending in them, easily being my favourite thing about the engine on the whole. The light RPG mechanics added certainly have their positive qualities, especially with the way they reward you for messing about and eating at restaurants etc. to further encourage actually interacting with the world instead of approaching everything in the most "video gamey" way possible because of its comparative efficiency. With that said, the RPG elements also come with a problem when so many basic abilities that make the combat any fun whatsoever are now locked behind having to level them up with the exp points. So many of your capabilities feel absolutely pathetic for the first half of the game or so, with a lot of the more gradual upgrades not really doing enough to actually feel worthwhile a lot of the time, most notably the early quickstep being so horrifically bad that I genuinely thought it was a bug.

Mechanical progression issues aside, I also just think that the combat here sucks in general for the most part, particularly with the way that heat actions felt far less engaging to mess about with thanks to the far lower amount of fun contextual stuff to do. It all feels far more homogenous in here, with a lot of interactions being stripped back and replaced with more generic actions which ultimately takes away a bit from the world as a whole when it's no longer some strange, twisted playground of brutality. There's also just a certain overarching sense of the game lacking its visceral edge, with a lot of the basic attacks having utterly pitiful feelings of impact regardless of how much damage they actually can do. It leads to a very repetitive experience in a lot of places that's only really alleviated by the fact that the game is incredibly easy so you can at least breeze through it relatively painlessly.

The side content is something that I feel did take a pretty big step up here however, as while there are still quite a lot of them that are very dry and not even really a jazzed up objective to just beat up a bunch of guys, there's some really insane stuff that goes on too. There's some truly ridiculous and hysterical stuff that goes on here, but my favourite has to be the minigame that sees Kiryu having to piss with precise and variable amounts of force, which in itself is already pretty silly and out there, but when combined with the absolutely unhinged amount of determination he has to win at this pissing contest, it's just the perfect recipe to something that almost justifies the game in its own right. One other think that bothers me a bit is the decision to provide a little minimap icon to display where substories are so early into the game.

While it's an undeniable quality of life improvement to have, giving it to the player almost immediately has a tendency to cause these little side stories to feel closer to a bunch of boxes that the player needs to tick off rather than adding to the spontaneous nature of the world. A huge draw of these originally was the way it provided this chaotic quality to the world, where some weird, random nonsense could spring out at you at every turn, and while I do admit that the feature of being able to actually see where side quests are is a good one for being able to get through the content without a guide, adding it either in the premium adventure or near the end of the story would be a far more effective way of being able to provide atmosphere while still ultimately allowing you to pinpoint them on the map.

One other problem I really have with this is how much of the side content has the idea of repetition and tedium baked into it. There are a ton of neat ideas floating around, such as the top down tower defence construction game or the missions where you act as a bouncer and take out hordes of enemies, but a lot of them get bogged down by how often you need to go through basically the exact same motions to actually properly complete them. With a lot of bits and pieces being tweaked, so much of the tedium of exploring some of the side content would be solved and really go a long way in not having these absolutely painful stretches of nothingness. Overall though, despite the game sometimes having utterly cavernous low points of boredom and frustration, I still think this is a pretty cool game that once again embraces its absurdity in a lot of glorious ways. Definitely going to have to play the original at some point because I get the distinct feeling that this took some stylistic liberties that I wouldn't really agree with, but even with that lingering thought, this is still a cool game in its own right even with the way it ends up being pretty frustratingly messy in places.

Another Yakuza game finished, with another to start shortly after.

To start things off, I was initially a little conflicted going into the combat in this game. If you played Kiwami 1 (as you should) and (optionally) Yakuza 0, you will immediately recognise that everything has been overhauled radically, no more fighting styles to change between, only one that is some amalgamation of the four styles we've seen in the last two games.

It works of course, there are a few times I found it a little clunky as there are now charged attacks, light and heavy bound to (in my case) X and Y respectively. I play counters on occasion, and though it might just be me still learning the timings, but I feel the game doesn't register them as well as it did in Kiwami.

Feedback in fights are a bit more over the top if you will, as Kiwami 2 uses the same engine as Y6, it seems, bodies seem to have that Payday 2 style of just flying away as soon as they become a ragdoll state from throws and assorted kicks and hits, plus they just glide on the floor when they do so, assuming you didn't throw them into the river while in Sotenbori when the opportunity presents itself.

The story as always is enjoyable, I got invested in the characters as I did before with previous titles.

Graphics... yeah it's a major improvement, mostly. (TL;DR for 40GB or so, in short. Yes, it's quite detailed.)

Why do I say that? Well, there were some small bits here and there where character models of non-story NPCs looked suspiciously like they were ported from Kiwami 1 or Y0 and don't fit in with the level of detail that the entire world and other non-/player character(s) are at.

That being said though, if you don't look too close in certain areas like I did (check the Don Quijote store in Kamurocho while in the first person view, for a fringe case example.) graphics are very good, it's no Call of Duty: Modern Warfare, but then those more recent titles take up an entire eighth of the storage on my desktop computer each.

What more can I think of to say? Well.. sometimes the game runs a little less than optimal in minigames, making it a bit of a  headache to play karaoke or baseball because you don't even get at least 60 FPS, so in fringe cases, it can affect my timing, or I end up completely lost over what happened.

Another thing I'm a bit pensive about is going away from the previous skill progression system, there are improvements to it, some new skills were added, some old favourites from other titles and what have you... now you have 5 different skill point categories when buying skills, I can't exactly pinpoint why, but it doesn't personally resonate with me. Your mileage may vary with that.

I can't really think of much else aside from all of the above, so I will leave it at that.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 was released on the Playstation 4 around December 2017 in Japan and August 2018 for worldwide release. The PC version was released on May 9, 2019 and features the game‚Äôs engine, the Dragon Engine, for the first time on Steam. Kiwami 2 is a remake of Yakuza 2 from the PS2 era. The game takes place in 2006, just after the events of Yakuza Kiwami (or Yakuza 1) of which the Tojo Clan survived an internal, civil war and tragic consequences continue to affect all major characters. In Kiwami 2, the Tojo Clan faced a major rival, the Omi Alliance, who is led by Ryoji Goda, seeks to win all over Japan‚Äôs underground criminal organization. Yakuza Kiwami 2‚Äôs storyline is considered as one of the best, if not the best story in the entire franchise. Is Kiwami 2 worth purchasing?

The Dragon Engine on the PC is spectacular, beautifully impressive, and jaw dropping. The fictional Tokyo and Osaka urban environments are worthy for multiple screenshots. If the player can max out the game‚Äôs settings, the graphics are out of this world and highly realistic. Like Yakuza 0 and Kiwami, the number of miniature games is available for the player to access and doesn‚Äôt take as long which is a great convenience for those who want to 100% complete the game. Kiwami 2 core gameplay is like Yakuza 0 and Kiwami so I wouldn‚Äôt go further details on it since I wrote the reviews for the games already. The major difference is the protagonist‚Äôs combat style, which changed drastically and somewhat of a disappointment. The number of action moves are fewer than the previous titles and the game‚Äôs physics is inconsistent, wild, and unintentionally funny. Regardless, the moves are expectedly brutal for Kiryu to utilize against enemy NPCs and boss battles. The game‚Äôs greatest strength is the main story and the characters involved and the relationships among multiple characters. The voice acting performances from the cast are outstanding as expected from Japan‚Äôs notable voice acting culture and reputation. 

Yakuza Kiwami 2 has a lot of good merits, particularly on the game‚Äôs highly realistic graphics engine and solid story line, but there are some negative attributes need to be considered. The anti-aliasing setting is oddly taxing, specifically on SSAA. The SSAA is ranged from 1.00 to 2.00 which each option increases by 0.25. If placing the SSAA on 1.50 or more, the game performance will dramatically decrease even with contemporary and latest PC systems. The game is not Crysis or the CryEngine, but it is worth noting and recommend to not go at SSAA 1.50 or more. Not worth the performance hit for minimal graphical enhancements. Additionally, the late sequences in the game‚Äôs storyline are painful because of the story‚Äôs twists and turns ‚Äì perhaps a bit excessive and dampens the overall storyline. 

Kiwami 2 is a solid game. I never played the original so I couldn‚Äôt compare what‚Äôs better or what isn‚Äôt, so the reader has to find other reviews to check. For me, the Yakuza series‚Äô narrative and character evolution for the main protagonist stands out to me the most. This review applies mainly to those who are already invested into the series rather than new players. Regardless, Kiwami 2 has a solid recommendation, but a bit reservation on the later sequences on the main storyline. It‚Äôs worth for the $30 spent to give to SEGA and the Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio (for me), but it‚Äôs also better to buy the title when it‚Äôs on sale.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is an 8-bit era game on steroids, it features a 100% badass gameplay full of of people to beat the shit out first and ask questions later. At some point you will be surprised when you meet characters that don't give you an excuse to violently bash their skulls against the wall. 

Unlike it's predecessors, Yakuza 0 and Yakuza Kiwami (Or Like a Dragon Zero and Like a Dragon Kiwami), this entry does not feature multiple battle styles so it might anger some people, but on the good side, upgrading abilities it's much simpler now and you don't need to updgrade your health 8 times before getting higher levels of damage like in the previous entries. The Dragon Engine also makes transitions way more smooth than previous engines so no more loading when entering buildings or getting into fights. If you see a thug you don't like you can punch them faster this time around.

The story is, as Mike Stoklasa put it once, "Elegantly bad". Good characters that are actually evil, evil characters that are actually good, and good characters that are actually evil except ¬°NO! they're actually good. It's totally self-aware of how much shit it's throwing in the pot at the same time with it's constant twists to fall into the common narrative trap of turning into a pretentious self-wankery like it happens with a lot of "auteurs" in gaming (Won't name anyone but you are probably thinking of somebody you hate). What matters are feelings, emotions. Who cares if it is a little stupid? all people should be a little bit stupid.

I can see Yakuza Kiwami 2 being in lots of people's "Best games of all time" lists.

This is my first experience in the new Yakuza engine, and it was pretty impressive.  Kamurocho and Sotenbori are mostly-seamless open-world style now, and it's so natural that it makes me forget where the loadscreens used to be.  Battles also flow in and out smoothly, and the new combat, while simpler, trims a lot of the fat that came with balancing several styles.  Gear and Weapons are better integrated than ever, and I found myself using them both extensively, which is a first.  The new character models are a great touch (gone are the days of Kiryu's 2cm pores), and while it isn't graphically jaw-dropping, it gets the job done with cinematic flair.  "Real Yakuza Use a Gamepad", but this port is fidgety, and will require you to delve into the Steam Big Picture settings to fix compatibility problems.  In addition, the Toylets minigame is broken at 60fps - temporarily turn the game down to 30fps to solve such issues.  

For completionists - the 100% journey took me approximately 85 hours to complete, with regular guide usage.  This is quite moderate by Yakuza standards, and the difficulty was not crushing.  Be aware that Haruka's Requests make a return, so minigame grinding is best left to the Premium Adventure endgame, lest you have to repeat a challenge twice.  Substories on the whole were excellent, some of the best I've played.  Amon, however, was disappointing.

Kiwami 2 serves as a return to form after the mostly disappointing Kiwami 1. Like with all Yakuza games, if you have played one, you have more or less played all of them. Just as before, the story follows the ever-stoic Kazuma Kiryu and his on-again, off-again relationship with his clan. The plot is a major improvement over the previous game and does a lot to sell the melodramatic world of ever-shifting allegiances, back-stabbing, and twists. The plot in these games is never the main selling point but act as wonderfully entertaining ways to contextualize the maihem. This plot revolves around a rivalry between two Tojo Clan and the Omi Alliance who are trying to expand their territory by absorbing the, now weakened, Tojo Clan. Heading the Omi is a man named Ryuji Goda who serves as a parallel to Kiryu‚Äîthey even both use the ‚Äòdragon‚Äô moniker. The plot does a great job in wrapping up and incorporating old plot lines into this game to make it feel far bigger than the sum of its parts.
	
This time around, Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio made some major upgrades across the board. Not only is this entry just as content-packed as Zero but it also comes with an impressive visual overhaul. While Kiwami 1 felt like a stripped down Zero, Kiwami 2 developed its own identity by making massive enhancements to the preexisting framework. Down to the little details, Kiwami 2 makes the cozy, familiar city of Kamurocho feel fresh and vibrant. I actually gasped when I discovered I could simply walk into most buildings in the city without any loading screens. The developers did an amazing job of turning the toybox map of the pervious games into a living city. 
	
Finally, the gameplay feels far more balanced than in either of the two previous entries. While this sounds great on paper, it is more of a neutral change. It is nice to use more of the skills you have acquired over the playthrough, it also feels disappointing to not feel like a invincible god of street fights (or at least not as much of one). Also, I always try to complete as much of these games as possible, and like always it tends to get a bit repetitive and dull towards the end so I would not recommend completing this game, just sample the options of what‚Äôs there. You earn enough experience to complete the skill tree without much grinding so kill yourself over it. 
	
At the end of the day, it is another Yakuza game but it feels elevated. While it does lean on your knowledge of previous games, nothing that comes before feels like required reading to have an enjoyable time. If you are curious about this series and want to test the waters‚Äîplay Zero. But if you simply refuse to play anything without really pretty graphics, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a great time. For fans of the franchise: I doubt you need my recommendation.

Considered from a gameplay and design perspective, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is both a big step forward and a step back. The move to the Dragon Engine provides an enormous graphical upgrade over Kiwami, striking in how much more vibrant Kamurocho looks. The enhancements in the engine extend to everything you can see - the mini-map provides the live locations of every NPC in the streets, doors you can enter, and shows places of interest much more precisely than before, the ragdoll physics are deeply entertaining, and object physics in general are impressive in how you can interact with the destructible environment. Of the three games I've played thus far, Kiwami 2 is easily the most visually impressive.

Combat, on the other hand, feels like a big regression. Losing multiple battle styles in favor of a single style made combat much more repetitive than in previous games, and I felt that the combo systems was much less responsive here than it was in 0 or Kiwami. A lot of the time, I would bounce off a block and lose my flow completely, not having an idea of where in the combo I'd been interrupted. Furthermore - and this may not just be an engine but a game design thing - several of the bosses were absolutely ridiculous in their ability to eat and dodge hits and then dish out ridiculous damage by simply dodging around my guard to lay in a ten-hit combo. The Man in Black was by far the worst offender, with his stupid fucking knife shoes, but other bosses were just as painful in this regard. 

Narrative is what I play Yakuza games for, however, and Kiwami 2 is a big step up from Kiwami in that regard. Much of this hinges on the charisma of Ryuji Goda and Kaoru Sayama, the main antagonist and deuteragonist, respectively. Like 0 and Kiwami, Kiwami 2 weaves an intricate web of a plot, and though the goofiness of Yakuza starts to show through towards the end of the narrative, with false finishes and last-minute villain reveals that take some of the air out of the story to that point, I found myself absolutely captivated, as always, by the multi-layered family drama at the heart of the story. The connections to 0 weren't nearly as prevalent here as they were in Kiwami, which I suppose is understandable - even if it's a post-0 remake, a lot of those references and connective tissue were explored in Kiwami and don't really need to be rehashed here. Even so, the core narrative, the substories, the cabaret club minigame - all excellent, as expected.

Yakuza 2 is usually held up as one of the best stories of the entire series, primarily on the back of Ryuji Goda, and I definitely see where people are coming from in that regard. Kiwami 2 is a great game in its own right, deep and diverse, and a promising, if uneven, showing of the Dragon Engine that continues to underpin most RGG Studio games after this. Absolutely wroth it.

Kiwami 2 is a great sequel from Kiwami 1. Everything is an improvement from the way combat feels to the amount of activities you can do between both areas.

The story is your average Yakuza game story however I found it took a bit for it to get to the point where the stakes are high, it was quite enjoyable nonetheless. Throughout the story there are parts which don't directly relate to the story but are used to further Kiriyu's characterisation which I really liked. It really cemented for me how good of a character he is and I hope we keep seeing more scenes which flesh out his character.

The combat is pretty enjoyable because of the Dragon Engine's physics. It's comical how if you punch someone they just ragdoll and fly off 5 metres away. It's not as grounded as it was in the previous games but I think it's a lot more enjoyable doing fights with these physics. 

The Majima chapters you unlock throughout the main story is only 3 chapters long but allow you to revisit some of the characters you would've met in Yakuza 0.

If you've played other Yakuza games, this has more over the top Yakuza goodness.  It's not perfect though.  The early game is horribly rough because they took away all the styles and you are forced to play in the janky un-upgraded Dragon style for a good while.  Also there's some horribly done physics you'll spy once in a while with a laughable ragdoll effect.  However, the minigames are quite spot on and overall it's an enjoyable experience.

Depending on how you play it, it can either be one of the best or worst Yakuza games. I bought the game again while it was on sale for PC because I had it for Playstation and it does not support 60fps, even on PS5. Not only that, but this one's combat has some very strange design decisions and I do not recommend to play the game as it is. 

I [b] strongly recommend you install a combat mod [/b] to overhaul the gameplay. At the bare minimum, you'd want something that removes the bounce when an enemy blocks your attack (Such as "No more hit bounce on block" by dodolodo). My personal favorite however is "Legend Remix K2" by TripleAAA7331 as it completely changes the flow of combat, overhauling everything whilst adding it's own new stuff. It works very well. There's also the excellent "Style Switching" mod by ReLLeRtR that does exactly what is says, adding the style switching from Y0 and YK1 into this game in the Dragon Engine. However I found that it was a bit unbalanced since it basically gives you every styles completely upgraded, and Kiwami 2 wasn't built with it in mind. There's also lots of bug reports for it as well, although it's expected for such a project.
As the only way to buy it on PC I have to recommend it, but honestly try to play the original version over this one if you can.

A remake of the second game of the series that originally released on PS2. This game uses the same engine and mechanics as Yakuza 6: Song of life, and feels a bit different from 0, Kiwami, 3, 4 and 5.

If you're playing the series in chronological order, this one is going to feel very jarring at first. Once again, Kiryu is the only playable character, and on top of that his fighting styles are gone, condensed into just one moveset. The game boasts a new physics engine that Sega seemed to be very proud of- hitting an enemy with a heavy blow will cause them to turn into a ragdoll and go flying for 20 feet. Furniture that Kiryu touches with occasionally slip out from under him like it's covered in grease and will awkwardly explode. You no longer progress in a prolonged fight by sending an enemy through a locked door, opening a path for you. You now calmly open the door, demonstrating the new engine's ability to seamlessly pass through doorways without being interrupted by a loading screen.

Upgrading your character also got a major overhaul, carried over from  Yakuza 6. Kiryu now has 5 separate experience categories, which you gain at different rates and are used to unlock different upgrades. Progress at the start is very slow, and even towards the end of the game you need to shovel a lot of expensive food to learn abilities and boost your stats. 

Despite the changes, this was still a fun game. The side quests are as funny as ever, there's still an undeniable satisfaction from hitting enemies with your heat moves, especially the extreme heat attacks that are in this game. Even with the awkward new experience system, it arguably an upgrade to the restaurants that didn't serve much purpose in 0 and Kiwami 1. I still miss the styles of the last games,but after you get over how clowny the physics are you start to appreciate the charm of being able to punt a guy like a soccer ball while he's laying on the ground.

Only reason why I'm writing this review is because this game isn't all it was chalked up to be, and I don't feel like it deserves to have more positive reviews than Kiwami 1, a game that fulfilled all my expectations (with a few exceptions).

I was originally gonna write what would essentially just be an essay just talking about how different this game was and how much I hated it, as I kept hearing about how good this game is and never really hearing anyone say anything negative about it, but I'll try to keep it short for the sake of those reading it, and my sanity (in hindsight, I failed horribly lol).

- The combat is insanely different from 0 and Kiwami, so it has a completely different feel and can be jarring when going from Kiwami to this game, which led to me experiencing a feeling that I can only describe as "going to a reputable restaurant that I've gone to for years to get a delicious meal, but actually just getting a cheap bag of potato chips once I receive my food from the waiter." Seriously, this is the only game so far where i felt compelled to use weapons to speed up some of the bosses, as in the other games fighting them bare-fist was pretty satisfying with how fun the different styles in those games felt to use, but here the only time I felt that I enjoyed the combat was when I [spoiler] played through the optional Majima saga, but it was ridiculously short and was pretty much just Majima's Mad Dog of Shimano Style ripped straight out of Yakuza 0. It didn't help that you get the chapters for the Majima Saga one at a time, with you needing to reach chapter 11 (out of the 16 chapters this game has) just to finish it. [/spoiler] Weapons are also ridiculously fragile in this game, you'll pick up a bike and if you get hit ONCE you'll drop it and it'll break instantly. Hell, even you do something like drop a METAL BASEBALL BAT, it might break, like the fuck? The combat in this game isn't even that hard, it's just really painful to sit through, with certain enemies just refusing to be staggered and my hits not feeling like they due anything at all, ONLY FOR IT TO HAVE APPARENTLY DONE ONE WHOLE HEALTH BAR WORTH OF DAMAGE!?

- The game was made with a completely different engine, which leads to it looking way better than 0 and Kiwami (but not running as well). This also messes with the physics a lot, which things like the crane game in the arcade highlight, with the claw grabbing toys but having them phase straight out of the claw once lifted up.

- The upgrade system is a total mess, with you getting different categories of EXP to invest into upgrades, with some upgrades being as simple as needing a bit of one category, ranging to a bunch of different categories. However, it's no longer as linear, with you being able to do things like upgrade your health, heat, damage, and get actual skills/heat moves at pretty much whatever pace you want (some of the EXP costs for the upgrades vary greatly though, which can kinda force you into getting some of the cheaper ones once the more expensive ones start rolling around). 

- Completion Points are also gone, with most of the things you got from it being turned into upgrades instead, like running for longer periods of time and the Nouveau Riche Influx perk, and tasks that once rewarded you with completion Points now just giving you small amounts of EXP.

- Sidestories can reward you with special heat actions from the person you helped out, but you need to unlock them afterwards for some reason...

- The story is alright at best, but painful to follow at worst. Like there's a (supposed-to-be tragic) scene where [spoiler] Kiryu gets stabbed in the fucking chest [/spoiler] but they have music playing that sounds like it's straight out of a 13 year-old kid's AMV. The ending will literally leave you going: "Huh, that's it?" once the credits start rolling, only for the scene that pulls up after the credits to clear up the confusion and reveal that [spoiler] the last bit of the ending didn't matter at all and that you were effectively jebaited into giving an iota of a fuck about these characters. [/spoiler] 

I may be forgetting some other things (like the "positives" of course), but after finishing the story and wanting to punch a wall after the ending, of course I can only think negatively right now, but I don't see myself changing this review anytime soon.

While Kiwami 2 has the obvious upgrades in graphics over the original Yakuza 2 thanks to basing itself off Yakuza 6, Kiwami 2 also inherits the clunky combat and wonky physics and tedious skill systems of 6, along with having a share of unpatched bugs. The new sidestories and minigames can also become a drag, making the experience padded out like Kiwami 1. Despite these faults, the story of Yakuza 2 is still here and it still remains one of the best stories in the series, even if the changes made by Kiwami 2 don't always flatter that story. While both Kiwami's are fine remakes, their flaws make me wish the originals were also just as available.

As a Korean having visited actual locations in Japan(2019) like Dotonbori(Sotenbori in Yakuza), this game was extremely immersive. I admire the folks in SEGA for creating such vibrant digital worlds that probably will hook many fans into wanting to visit Japan from experiencing the environments in this game. Other than the cabaret girls' dating parts and the Haruka parts (I gave up on Poker - SSS) most of the substories were enjoyable. The combat system was streamlined and the menus easier to navigate, which I ended up liking way more than the circular menus in Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1. It also seems to be a trend to have 'crafting' in most RPG-esqeue games these days, so I appreciated that there was none of that garbage hauling crap here(even as a remake). The story is a bit slow and melodramatic at times, but it's mixed in with a good amount of well-placed humor. I haven't played Yakuza 3-6 yet, but I would recommend Kiwami 2 to anyone looking for a good action game to sink dozens of hours into.
