**This is not a don't recommend review, this is a neutral review**

I really wish steam had a neutral or mixed feel because there were definitely things I enjoyed and many things I also didn't enjoy. I'll try to make this as simple as possible.

If you had played Yakuza 0 or Yakuza Kiwami, you'll know the style of how the story and fighting went, they went quite different with the fighting in this game, you only have one mode and it's the blue one, the brawler mode, the things you could change in fighting were just using weapons. You could get weapons from the shop or pick up weapons from enemies during battles and you can put them in your inventory, I like this idea. There are very minimal loading zones this time meaning you aren't bombarded with loading zones when going in and out of shops, it's very seamless, no loading when you're going into a street fight it's a lot more smoother going in and out of things. I definitely liked the story better than Yakuza Kiwami but I still think Yakuza 0's story was better than these two. One of the biggest things I enjoyed was the inventory in general. You no longer have 25 slots max, you have 10 slots per item so you can carry loads of healing items without worry for your inventory space, which is incredibly good considering how much you'll use them. One great thing I'll always be thankful about is how Kiryu doesn't keel over and suffer every single gun shot and then you have to spam a button, E for those keyboard and mouse users like myself, it doesn't exactly help too much when it feels like everyone has a gun and everything will stun you, you just can't spam anything to do anything about it. Majima is definitely not annoying in this game and in fact he's significantly more comedic, I enjoyed his appearances and there seems to be more of him, a backstory I think? I've yet to do it as I was more focused on the story.

And now on to the cons,
Remember how awesome the cutscenes were in the other games? I mean they seem similar here except they've removed all voice acting from outside animated cutscenes, it's all the noises from dialogue that you'd expect from substories, it felt like they didn't have time or weren't bothered to care about voice acting for the main story, I guarantee many of you relied on subtitles anyway but having the voice still adds character than just mumbles.
The combat, again, is definitely a downgrade not only is there one fighting style and you don't even feel like the Dragon of Dojima anymore, they made the fighting feel goofy almost, there's literal ragdoll physics, if you hit someone onto the ground, they'll flop over like an actual fish it just kills the tension and its quite upsetting.
Remember those fat guys that hold the chairs and other massive furniture, they are the absolute worst in this game. They are bonkers tanky and there is absolutely nothing you can do against them, every hit will toss you across the room, ragdoll form.

I could continue with the cons but I really don't want to bash the game any more than it deserves, I think the story is really good, I think the game is good. I just think the gameplay is bad, it feels very rushed and I honestly think the post credits scene was awful. Not awfully animated or anything, I just thought it felt cheap. If the credits were the end. I'd genuinely be happy with it It would feel like an actual end not another cliff hanger.

My final verdict is this is a great story but not the best game to play, if this were a movie, or if this were the same design as Kiwami 1 then that would change my mind heavily. The game felt more tedious than fun sadly.

Before I get into my thoughts about the story of Kiwami 2, I would just like to say I'm very thankful and quite frankly impressed about the way the skill system, inventory, and overall gameplay was modified to a precise point where it is still very engaging and prevented any repetitive-ness of grinding out skills and such from the previous installments. The story of Kiwami 2, like kiwami, left me dumbfounded. Without getting into spoilers, the continued story of Kiryu in Kiwami 2 hit me hard, and after the emotional wreck Yakuza Kiwami left me (not in a bad way whatsoever), Kiwami 2 was able to preserve the seriousness, melancholic, and at times lighthearted moments of the Yakuza games thus far. It is not the same thing happening over and over again, it is just a genuinely interesting and "edge of your seat" kind of story, and one I was fully engaged in the whole time. 

I really do recommend and hope more people can enjoy and experience the Yakuza saga, especially 0, Kiwami, and Kiwami 2.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a stunning remake of Yakuza 2 using the Dragon Engine. Some points worth mentioning are:
[list]
   [*] The main story was much better than Kiwami 1 and the antagonist was built up well. The plot twists were timed perfectly!
   [*] I completed 54 sub-stories out of 76. They ranged from being funny to emotional and had a lot of references to other media.
   [*] Physics in this game is based on their new engine and I felt that it was a good change from the previous entries. Having said that, the ragdoll was sometimes a bit over the top.
   [*] The graphics qualify is insane and the ability to enter any shop without a loading screen was a much-needed improvement. The skill system was tweaked as well.
   [*] Majima Saga (a separate 3-chapter story) serves as a satisfying conclusion [spoiler]to the bittersweet ending of Majima and Makoto in Yakuza 0[/spoiler].
   [*] The karaoke songs were decent although the new system of button prompts was a little jarring.
[/list]
This is again one of the high points in the series. The only issue would be the transition to the next title which is supposedly only a remaster, but I guess it will be worth it for the story.

Kazuma Kiryu just wants to move on from his yakuza life, but like a famous cinematic mafioso, just when he thought he was out, they pull him back in. The Dragon of Dojima has found a rival, like it or not, in a Kansai yakuza who also has a Dragon nickname who thinks there should only be one dragon. By the end of this soap opera-like journey of brotherhood, betrayal, secret heritage, and brawls, Kiryu's on the top of an unfinished skyscraper with a love interest while a bomb counts down. Oh yeah, it's drama!

The game is the game. I felt like Kiwami 2 moved back into some of the Yakuza 0 feel - as opposed to Kiwami 1, which was more sparse. There's more of a sense of whimsy and about neither Kiryu nor the game taking themselves too seriously all of the time. Side quests are fun, one of the game's two big minigames is fun (I liked the tower defense-like Majima-focused Clan Creator, skipped the "manage hostesses at a club" game entirely), fighting tons and tons of dudes in random street brawls and plot-related marathon fights is fun. I did think it was a bit of a slow starter, taking a while to get rolling. For several hours I asked myself, "Am I bored of this? Have I had enough Yakuza?" Then the old fun feeling kicked in and didn't let go. I liked that combat got streamlined so there are no longer multiple stances; I seldom used them anyway and found it an annoyance.

My modest laptop started running into occasional issues with the graphics in this game. There were occasional weird herky-jerky movements of the models during cutscenes that looked creepily like when aliens are pretending to be human in some kind of horror movie. I also had difficulty in this game using my Switch Pro controller, as the game kept putting PlayStation symbols on the screen for quick-time event prompts. When you've got XABY and the game flashes triangle, square, circle, or X, it's... you know. Especially when, no spoilers except to say this, the final boss fight requires you to execute one quick-time button push no matter how thoroughly you whip the guy's butt OR ELSE YOU LOSE AND HAVE TO DO THE WHOLE THING OVER, it's a little bit of an issue! I had fun, but man, that was annoying.

Again very happy Sega are releasing Yakuza to PC in story order rather than the console release order. This is fantastic apart from some people don't understand that the Kiwamis are remakes of old games. So of course Kiwami 2 has less features and is generally shorter than Yakuza 0. While 0 is the newer game it is a prequel. 

Release Order: Y1, Y2, Y3, Y4, Y5, Y0, YK1, Y6, YK2, YLAD(7)

Story Order Y0, YK1, YK2, Y3, Y4, Y5, Y6, YLAD(7)
(Kiwamis are remastered so replace the originals, 3-6 may not get the Kiwami treatment)

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a remastered version of the PS2 game Yakuza from 2006. The remake has been done very well and they have built the game with the Yakuza 6 Dragon engine. Kamurocho and Sotenbori look beautiful in the new engine with the hustle and bustle of the cities feeling even better that before.

A year after leaving his former life in the Tojo Clan behind, ex-yakuza Kazuma Kiryu is called back into action when the clan's Fifth Chairman Yukio Terada is murdered by assassins from a rival organization, the Omi Alliance. Returning to Kamurocho, Kiryu must find a new chairman for the Tojo Clan and prevent an all-out war between the Tojo and the Omi, bringing him into conflict with Ryuji Goda, the legendary "Dragon Of Kansai" of the Omi Alliance. 

The fighting system instead of having the three stances like in 0 an K1 have now been merged in to one fighting style. While some people prefer the 3 stance fighting this mode is very good as when you learn the combo's you can have some very fluid fighting. The fighting like in all Yakuza games is meaty and satisfying. The weapons system has been enhanced nicely too being a lot more fluid than the previous versions.

With the new engine there are no loading times or screen fades when entering shops and fights etc. Its just instant which is really nice.

You get to play as Majima again in this title with him having his own stand alone story. "Majima Saga"  explains how Majima came to leave the Tojo Clan following the death of his patron, Futoshi Shimano, a year earlier and form a legitimate enterprise, "Majima Construction", between Yakuza and Yakuza 2. 

The voice acting, cutscenes, storytelling and music are stellar once again.

Slightly less mini games than other titles and substantially easier to complete the completion list in my opinion. There are a lot of cheat items for the Japanese games like Mahjong and Koi Koi. The mini games have all had a polish and there are some new ones. Darts, Golf, Mahjong, Koi Koi, Blackjack, Poker, Bouncer Missions (A lot of them lol), Karaoke, Photography, Cabaret management, Clan creator. I personally enjoy Mahjong and my love for the series was that strong I actually learned how to play basic Richii Mahjong.

Cabaret management from Yakuza 0 is back which will make a lot of people happy as that mini game is like pure crack on the addiction level XD.

Clan creator is in this game which I hear was in Y6 originally. In this mode its like a top down RTS using a team put together to defend Majima construction. Can be quite challenging (It has been nerfed if you choose to use the CC DLC)

Couple of things omitted in this title which I missed were, No Pocket Circuit and No Baka Mitai

I have very high hopes for the rest of the series being brought to PC now after the recent announcement and release of Yakuza 3,4 and 5 to the PlayStation. The Yakuza director has hinted very strongly that we will get them.

Thank you SEGA and Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio for this fantastic series and thank you for bringing it to the PC <3

A great continuation. The huge jump in graphics fidelity, the even more detailed city and the seamless walking into the restaurants/shops makes it a refreshing experience even though it's mostly the same locations from 0 and Kiwami 1.

The story is the usual very good stuff. Intriguing characters, unexpected plot-twists and just a good structure of giving the player bits of information and slowly piecing them together. The detective Sayama also turned out to be a much better character than I initially thought.

It's typical Yakuza: Funny, zany, and a WAYYY over the top - What's not to love?! 

Starting off with the positives, the world feels more alive than Kiwami thanks to traffic & a ragdoll physics engine that results in Kiryu knocking over absolutely everything within walking distance. Those same physics lead to punching enemies into the air so far they leave the screen, or launching them several meters back into their unsuspecting cronies. The minigames are all there as you'd expect, though I'll be honest & say they've never really been my jam when it comes to this franchise.

The story, however, most certainly is. It feels like a step up from Kiwami in pretty much every way, though out of the three titles I've played so far, I'd still say Yakuza 0 stands alone. Still, it's extremely wacky, surprisingly emotional, & while it might be a bit too reliant on the "Rule of Cool" for some, for me, I wouldn't want it any other way. If by the end of the series I don't see Kiryu punch a moving tank to a standstill, I'll be feeling disappointed, because he's punched pretty much everything else up until this point!

The combat is sadly something I'm yet to bond with, though. It feels like something that's gatekeeping me from enjoying the story, although thankfully you an trivialize most of it with consumables & weapons. I understand it's all part of the spectacle, & it might just be that 3D brawlers just aren't my jam, but I cannot recommend it based on the combat alone - Fortunately, I don't have to.

Overall, I still have gripes with the combat, & yes the story is cheesy insanity carried by a hell of a lot of cutscenes, but I'm not sure I'd have it any other way. Just imagine Arnie's "True Lies" set in Japan co-written by a somewhat drunk Tarantino, and you've pretty much got the Yakuza franchise down. It's wild, bizarre, & honestly, pretty bloody brilliant.

This game is just amazing. I loved every second of playing it, I loved the story, I REALLY loved the gameplay and I could gush about yakuza all day but I'll spare you. I see almost no flaws in this game except for 2 glaring things that I will list below. The fighting honestly felt like the best that it's ever been. Being able to switch combat styles in 0 was cool, but I'm more a fan of 1 fighting style that has it all and Kiwami 2 executes that perfectly. The story, although the end is not as impactful as Yakuza 0's, is so unique and you must experience it if you enjoy Yakuza.

I feel that "Legend" difficulty is too easy. I don't know if it was my experience playing yakuza games so much or if i over-built Kiryu (I don't think I did) but i feel like those final few fights should have been more grueling and challenging but At the end I didn't even need to use many of my Health items or weapons. 

One other thing I'm not too happy about: I wish Ryuji Goda was more. He seemed like he had so much more to him but I don't feel like he was given the spot light enough and I don't think he was as fleshed out as he could have been. I feel that him and Kiryu are equals, but the story doesn't lead you to really believe that.

With all that said, I give this game a 9/10 objectively, but subjectively a 10/10 because dispite its flaws, I'm struggling to decide if I like this game more of Yakuza 0 more.

Saying that this is the weakest of the Yakuza games thus far damns it with false condemnation. It's just not as good as the themes and executions set up in Yakuza 0 and Kiwami. It's always a joy, though, coming back to Kamurocho now and seeing what has changed since the previous games, what has returned, what hasn't, and what new songs are available at the karaoke bar.

It can be forgiven that this game came out so early in the series that there's a little bit of weirdness involved in its storytelling, namely the Sayama romance plot that was dropped in 3 onwards and then pretends like that never happened. Granted, you could read it as Kiryu rebounding after losing Yumi in the previous game.

This game continues to make callbacks to side stories that happened in 0 and Kiwami, like the cabaret club and the extra chapter that concludes things with Majima and Makoto, as well as showing what caused Majima to step away from the Yakuza and start up a construction company.

in 2020, I played two new Yakuza games. In 2021, I‚Äôve played two more, with a Fist of the North Star spinoff on the way. The latest, Yakuza Kiwami 2, is a modernized remake of Yakuza 2, made in the new Yakuza 6 engine. Life ‚Ä¶ is good.

As a Yakuza fan, I thought it was nothing but necessary to go to Japan to live the same life as Kiryu-Chan. Upon arriving, I was dreadful. There was no funny eye patch man, and the real yakuza blew out my kneecaps. I limped over to a local massage parlor (in hopes of going on a cool journey like Majima did in Yakuza 0). They looked at me and said "What the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• are you doing, this is not a doctor, we're calling immediate help" when I was in that ambulance, I understood what it meant to be Yakuza, and I look foward to returning to Japan to go beast style (Yakuza 0 - Yakuza Kiwami 1) and defeat the guys who shot my knees.

I went into this game with some pretty high expectations, with people saying it's one of the best in the series (if not the best). After finishing the game I can say that I'm definitely not disappointed.

This is the first game in the series that uses the Dragon Engine, and you can really tell that the devs tried to do everything they could with it. Some people complain about the graphics being too bloom-y and water looking but I don't have that complaint. There's also a LOT of cutscenes in this game, like 90% of the scenes that would normally be the textbox ones that you mash to skip are replaced by full on rendered cutscenes. Graphics still clean so I won't fuss about that either.

Now onto the most controversial part of the Dragon Engine, the ragdoll physics in fights. Yes, you're gonna miss the gameplay from the last 2 games. But the fighting in this game is by no means bad, chasing enemies who fly across the screen after a jab might be annoying but it can make some hilarious moments while playing. The upgrade system is alright, it actually made me eat at restaurants a lot in this game which is an achievement I guess? I used to just ignore them. Also, the first time I saw that you could walk in and out of buildings freely blew my mind.

Ryuji Goda is by far my favorite antagonist of the series so far. They set him up as a very basic person but take his character progression in a really interesting way towards the end, and the atmosphere set up by the final fight is my favorite in the series so far as well, it feels like you get injected with so much testosterone and adrenaline. The fight itself on the other hand, not so much to be honest. It honestly went by so fast, that I didn't even get to the best part of the OST by the time I finished. The boss OSTs in this game slap by the way.

Notably this game is the most expensive in the series for some reason, maybe because of the Majima Saga. Honestly it's 3 chapters full of fanservice. The main plot is pretty basic, but what can you expect from what's basically a mini arc. But the fanservice part, this saga delivers so so well. Won't get into the details here but showing the player the serious Majima still buried deep below for almost 20 years is great. You play through his saga and start tearing up, you head into a karaoke bar and he sings Shiawase Nara ii Ya and you start bawling. 

Long story short, this game is definitely a recommend. It'll take a while to get used to all the changes from the Dragon Engine but when the game starts to get good, it gets really good. Expect the same great substories and minigames (I love the return of the cabaret club, although I haven't actually started on it). And hey, 3 games in, only 4 more games left so you might as well go all in. Well now, you're gonna have to start the black sheep of the series, Yakuza 3. But that's a review for another time.

[h1] Kiwami 2, the remake that'll tax your specs harder than a tiger drop [/h1]
Yakuza Kiwami 2 is one of those games that fall flat on a few aspects but make up for it in every other one. Story as usual is superb and one of the best in the franchise in my opinion. Ending had me in awe after I finished my favorite boss fight of all time. Gameplay is where it becomes pretty subpar considering the original Y2 had amazing combat. Difficulty is a lot easier compared to the rest of the games, lock on is broken in the aspect of where it doesn't lock on to an enemy if you're not facing him, and the fighting style was reworked to better suit the engine albeit a bit futile if you ask me. As much as I love the Dragon Engine and it's ragdoll physics, it just doesn't suit Kiryu's fighting style considering it was built around the engines where wall bounding was a mechanic. This engine better suits a certain lawyer-turned-private investigator's fighting styles if you know what I mean (and to that extent his ex-yakuza partner). One redeeming factor of the game however is the return of the cabaret club minigame in which I know a lot of us who played Y0 enjoyed to the fullest. Certain characters from that minigame also return along with new faces. As it is a DE game, many people who're fresh off Yakuza Kiwami will find a lot of aspects reworked like the inventory system, nerfed Tiger Drop, and no loading screens when entering a building (with a few exceptions). Graphics in the DE are amazing which enhances cutscenes by a lot, but it goes without saying that it's a lot heavier than the previous titles. [url=https://youtu.be/EichdGKOnh0]Luckily, playing at 30 fps in this game is actually preferable which is explained in this video right here[/url]. Substories have that essential Yakuza wackiness in them alongside the minigames. The soundtrack is arguably my favorite of the series and I am still mad this is one of the games that had a limited soundtrack release. Overall it's a good game that's somewhat limited by it's gameplay but still a pretty enjoyable experience.

I genuinely have nothing bad to say about this entry in the series and am very happy with this game.

Kiryu storyline:
Starts out really good but quickly diminishes its potential. The Omi yakuza war is so interesting and fun conpaired to the jing won mafia plot with the detective woman that takes up so much of the game that most of the games story feels wasted. Go Ryu is such a badass who is given hardly any screen time. Honestly all of the Omi alliance had potential to be a bad ass villain league but they are not used at all in the story and only do much at the beginning and the end. Also the game has some of the most generic not relevant subplots I have ever seen. Like actually sub story level stuff that must be completed. Once I realized what they were I skipped over them. like I said the story has its moments but alot holding it back.

Majima storyline:  
The Majima saga is really short and just exists to give Kiryu and money boost if you do the side content. story wise if it just exists to set up some of the events of the main game and it plays out in a similar way. Only exception to this is the makato stuff. Its so wholesome to follow up from the Majimas plot in yakuza 0 and is the only Ark Majima goes through.

Combat and gameplay:
Dragon engine looks really nice but the combat is generally a downgrade from yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1. Lot more lose and floaty which inst bad but mainly misses the mark in terms of variety and options in attacking. The fighting is not bad its just its not as good. but it can be very rewarding when you get good at it. 

Dragon engine: 
Its awesome. No more looking at somewhere and not being able to go to there. No more loading screens in between areas. exploring the cities is flawless and still really fun to do. 

Substories:
Not much to say here. They are still really funny. this game has some of the bests like the baby one, the photo shoot, the voice acting gig. Brilliant work here.

Conclusion: Honestly if you played and liked yakuza 0 and kiwami 1 your gonna have to play this one. even with its plot failures its a true yakuza experience an you cant skip out on it. Theres a method to the madness somewhere and I love this game even with its problems.

As a huge fan of both 0 and Kiwami, I came into this game with very high expectations, and it delivered in almost every aspect. Kamurocho and Sotenbori both look great and are full of content. 

Starting this game after playing 0 and Kiwami, you'll notice something quite quickly: the removal of battle styles. At first, I thought this would impact my experience negatively, but I quickly learned that fights felt a lot more fluid and upgrading Kiryu felt more impactful. His move set overall felt very well balanced with lots of offensive and defensive tools at his disposal. This game also comes with the addition of "Extreme Heat Mode" which turns Kiryu into an absolute beast. Komaki Tiger Drop being nerfed was desperately needed for combat to not become absolutely trivial like it did by the end of Kiwami.

The storyline, while at first felt rather shallow and boring in comparison to the previous titles, ended up being a very meticulously crafted and emotionally driven narrative which left me crying at the end. While at first I disliked the cast, over time I grew to respect their characters the more the game delved into their story. You'll find yourself revisiting a lot of old places, while also meeting a lot of new faces. Overall a very well executed and concise experience.

Cabaret Club management returns alongside a new "Clan Creator" mode where you join Majima and his construction company. The cabaret mode remains just as fun as ever. Clan Creator, while I don't personally enjoy the RTS-style gameplay, is quite honestly entertaining merely by its concept and execution. It retains enough charm to keep me hooked.

And of course, the classic Yakuza humor is around to stay. TL;DR this game is 100% worth its full price. If you can grab it on sale, do not hesitate.

[h1] Story [/h1]
It has flaws, but I still love it. You'll most likely start the game thinking the main antagonist is incredibly boring and one-note, only to come out of the game's ending at LEAST respecting him a shit ton. While a couple of the early chapters can drag on a bit, and the main antagonist becomes absent for a long time, there were times that I would forget that it's a faithful remake of a PS2 era game from 2006. Plus, the music enhances the impact of the most emotional beats to an insane degree. No other game has made me tear up during the final battle, before.

Oh yeah, the Jingweon Mafia plot is there too... The plotline regarding Ryuji Goda and the whole "Two Dragons" thing with him and Kiryu is honestly one of my favorite stories in a video game, but I'm not going to pretend I cared about like 95% of the Jingweon Mafia parts of the story at all. Hell, I completely overlooked it and had to edit this review when I remembered that it existed. I'm still able to find great joy in the overall story, but that secondary plot about the Korean Mafia did nothing but add like 5 twists that had no impact whatsoever during the last 2 chapters. If you ignore like 90% of that plotline, this game's story comes out to be like a 8.5/10, in my eyes.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
I could go on and on about the variety of actual things to do as a result of all the minigames, but when it comes to the main focus, the combat, this game is absolutely wonderful. Nearly every hit and technique is incredibly visceral and satisfying to use and land, regardless of their actual practicality. Landing one of those finishers in Extreme Heat Mode that let you get extra damage by mashing Y during the zoom in is the sorta feeling that makes you feel incredibly powerful in a way many games can only dream of. The combat is kinda similar to Mario 64 in that it's pretty easy to get into at first, and while there's no need for the average player to master it, putting in the work to get better at it is so satisfying that it's worth it just for that feeling you get after you pull off something sick. 

The only issue I have with this game's combat is a single enemy type, that being the large fellas holding furniture during some of the extended combat sequences that require you to wait for them to use their telegraphed, armored singular attack so you can slowly chip away at their health. The loss of the heat action from Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1 that allows you to one-hit them stings. But thankfully, they aren't used that much, so it doesn't bog down the overall experience much, if at all.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]
The Dragon engine is visually such a huge upgrade from the engine used in 0 and Kiwami 1 that it isn't even funny. I was genuinely shocked when I booted this game up totally blind and saw the streets of Sotenbori for the first time. Definition of a glow up.

[h1] Music [/h1]
The music is really fucking good, and it's utilized wonderfully. This is something you realize the instant you get into a street fight in Sotenbori and hear "Outlaw's Lullaby" for the first time.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
I got this game on sale, but in all honesty, I don't think I'd have any qualms with paying the full $30 for it if I knew I'd enjoy it as much as I did. I genuinely see myself going back to complete the substories, and other miscellaneous missions just so that I can continue to experience this game. 9/10.

Let's get this out of the way: the Yakuza games are amazing. Collectively, what they give you is some of the best gaming has to offer, and much of the praise I have for Kiwami 2 is echoed in what I'd say in a review of the others. I have a handful of qualms with Kiwami 2, most minor, but on the whole it's a Yakuza game. And that means it's very, very good and an easy recommendation. If you haven't played the series and are somehow stumbling on this review, start with Yakuza 0 then Kiwami 1, then play this game. But most importantly, play the Yakuza series. These games are insanely good.

With that out of the way, I'll give my thoughts on the good and bad of Kiwami 2:

The Good:

-No game series does humor as well as Yakuza, and that's as true here as in any other iteration. Yakuza isn't afraid to push boundaries, and some of the sidequests in particular are absurd in all the right ways. Somehow Yakuza is able to do this in between incredibly tense and dramatic story beats, all while playing the Japanese John Wick. I don't know how they pull off this tonal range but they do, and it's glorious.

-The drama really is amazing, though. I cried multiple times. And even though so many iconic characters have gotten killed off, they somehow find a way to add new ones and make me care for them. It's not a perfect story for sure; they might have gone a bit too far with the twists near the end, and I definitely prefer 0 and Yakuza 1's stories more, but there are so many scenes and set pieces here that I'll remember forever that it's hard to complain.

-As with the other games, Kiwami 2 is set in one of the most gorgeous, fully realized virtual worlds I've ever seen. What's especially appreciated here is that there are no load times when entering buildings! This really keeps the open world moving and is a huge difference maker.

-The facial animations, voice acting, and overall presentation are as good as ever. If you've played the others you've come to expect it but it really can't be overstated. These are damn good looking games.

-The Majima side mission they added that's exclusive to Kiwami 2 (and wasn't in the original Yakuza 2 at all) is incredible. So much so that it might be my favorite part of the whole game. Majima in general is one of my all-time favorite video game characters, and just about everything he's a part of in here is awesome.

-As with other Yakuza games, the variety of optional content is just absurd, and really helps immerse you in the open world. You won't like everything (I personally hate the Majima Construction minigame), but you'll certainly have fun with whatever side content appeals to you, and most of all you'll just enjoy that it's all there if you want it. Oh, and the Caberet Club is back, baby! ^_^

-You'll get so god damn cultured playing these games. I learned Mahjong and Shogi from Yakuza, for crying out loud. Hell I think my very rudimentary Japanese skills got better too. You might not know what a "kuro gyaru" is or much about gravure, but you will after playing Yakuza, and you know what that's freaking sick.

The Bad:

-My biggest qualm with this entry is the Dragon Engine. It's still quite enjoyable, but it streamlines things quite a bit, and thus pales in comparison to the depth of Y0 and Kiwami. Instead, the game seemed to put more emphasis on weapons and heat actions, which is fine, but truth be told most of them are absolutely broken. I struggled to find a playstyle that made the fights rewarding for me. If I played without weapons, it felt like combat was too simple, but when I played with weapons, everything was way too easy, even though I played on Hard difficulty. When you max out Kiryu, boss fights go down remarkably fast, and there's no worse example of this than the final sequence. The final fights ended up being super anticlimactic for me, and sure I could have gimped myself by playing with certain restrictions, but honestly the game gives you way too many tools to trivialize it.

-That isn't to say that Kiwami 2 is braindead easy; it's not hard by any means but rather it's mostly just uneven. Certain fights (Coliseum fights, Man in Black, etc) are legitimate challenges and others are over in a matter of seconds. I try not to use health items at all in Yakuza games, but I had to break that rule a few times in this one. Like I said, I found it hard to find a rewarding playstyle.

Minor gripes:
-Enemies on the overworld aren't rewarding / engaging. They don't drop much money or experience, so you mostly just want to avoid them. But so many spawn that it's tough. It doesn't take long to beat them down, but sometimes you just want to go from point A to point B.

-The earlygame is paced quite slowly. A lot of time is spent on a new character (Daigo Dojima) but then he's pretty much thrown away and discarded as the story progresses. The game picks up as it goes on, but it takes a bit to get going.

-Continues after dying don't always just send you right back into the fight. Y0 and Kiwami did it correctly so I'm surprised this is a problem in this one.

-If you read quickly and don't let animations fully play out, there is a lot of animation jitter between each text box. You'll get used to it, but it's one of the first things you'll notice in an otherwise highly polished game.

-Some of the cut content from the original Yakuza 2 is a big time bummer. Most of the music doesn't make a return, and there's even a small "third city" called Sinseicho that isn't in this one at all (they incorporate it into Sotenbori instead). There's a substory where you play as a host (so sort of reverse caberet club) that's cut too and apparently that's one of the best. Kiwami 2 is still by far the definitive Yakuza 2 experience at this point, and other than the music, none of that stuff is all that important, but it doesn't quite have the accuracy to the original that Kiwami 1 had, and that's a shame.

I love Yakuza. Categorically. I'd like to emphasize that my love of the series supercedes whatever bumblings I wrote here as criticism. Can't wait to play more.

Oh, Yakuza, my beloved soul food. You've done it time and again. 

As with it's updated predecessors, Kiwami 2 offers a deep consistent experience as Kiryu (and to an extent, Majima in his three bonus chapters) in our old stomping grounds of Kamurocho and Sotenbori, with all the bells and whistles of the other two games almost completely in tact.

Now, this is understandably not always a good thing, as anyone who has played mini-games can explain, playing crane game and considerably obtuse (arguably under explained to hell and back) Japanese gambling games get's extremely old, extremely fast, and having most games reappear between titles, with a whole new slew of challenges with em can be a tad tedious.

Which is fine, as frankly that is all optional!

In this title, every single upgrade is determined by a few factors, which are mostly sub-stories, and of course, experience. How do you get experience? Doing literally anything! Including simply eating out at the diners, or just punching dudes. It's very easy to bring Kiryu to god status long before end game; especially if you are focused on the real meat of the game, the sub-stories.

 Although a good chunk of these are dedicated to 'allies' around both cities. Many of the stories are very well fleshed out, offering a great experience, even if arguably the rewards tend to be a tad random, or even lacking if they aren't unlocking employees for both of the main sub story games, or techniques for Kiryu to learn. Still, the characters are the biggest reward.

To bring it to a head, the combat, as the main draw point of the game, is considerably a comfortable middle ground of the game play of Zero and Kiwami 1.
 The engine is extremely well used for insane ragdoll physics, leading to some of the crunchiest violence this side of Japan. 
Of course the strange lack of the Brawler, Beast and Rush makes the over all options of the game some what lesser, as Kiryu by default uses his Dragon/Legend style, albeit much more free form.
 One could say it's more accurate to the original experience, and of course the weapons system got an overhaul that ultimately replaces the three styles giving Kiryu many options outside of fist fighting.

Finally, we have the main story. Continuing a year after Kiwami, and offering story of duty, honour and keeping tradition in the face of a changing world, where traditional Yakuza are slowly petering out in the face of a new more business focused Yakuza. With a focus on Kiryu coming to terms with the events of last year, and finding his own path with Haruka as his adoptive daughter.

While the story is utterly fantastic, and gets the 'made me tear up' award just as the other games have done, I personally found the double dipping of Cabaret from Zero with extremely few changes to the formula, and the over all lacking of a certain something to the Clan Creator mode. 
As well as a few too many places where the game said 'Go mess around or do all these things with Haruka.' when I arguably felt that the game should have just kept going to the finish line (especially when I have to redo mini games that I've already done, just for Haruka).

In the end, I absolutely adored Yakuza Kiwami 2. A story always worth watching, and action worth playing... of course, I have no intent to replay it, as 30 of the 64 hours was spent on effectively grinding Kiryu up with the repetitive Cabaret, and consuming Millions of Yen worth of food and digestive medication. Not exactly the most engaging way of power progression. However, past that grind was a deep, emotional, gut wrenching story about a man literally to powerful to die, suffering in order to regain a home in his broken life.

8.5/10  Needed more Kiryu tanking stab wounds than vibe checking wild animals.

As always Yakuza does not disappoint. It has a great story, a great set of characters, great action and combat, great music, a lot of activities in the game itself and amazing visuals - in spite of a lot of 2D being used on 3D objects it has more detail and is more appealing than many 3D games out nowadays. Truly an amazing game. It may be very different from Yakuza 0 and Yakuza Kiwami but I feel that different does not necessarily mean that it is worse. 

The jump in graphics after playing Yakuza 0 and Yakuza Kiwami is jaw-dropping with the dragon engine making the cities of Kamurocho and Sotenbori feel more alive than ever. The ability to explore the city with barely any restrictions is liberating and even though the physics can be janky and goofy at times, I feel that it adds even more charm to Yakuza Kiwami 2.

The combat is very different from Yakuza 0 and Yakuza Kiwami and I'll admit to the fact that it is not as good. Does it mean that it is bad? No, not at all. Yes, the weird physics and hit boxes can be infuriating at times and the combat does feel very stiff at times. However, if we look at it on it's own without comparing it to Yakuza 0 and Yakuza Kiwami, it is still good and is still quite fun with satisfying heat moves and combos.

The music may not be as good as Yakuza 0 but it is comparable with Yakuza Kiwami with some notable hits like Outlaw's Lullaby and A Scattered Moment.

Lastly, the story. The story takes many twists and turns and it can be quite predictable at times. Furthermore, the plot does take a dip in quality at certain points but overall, the story is still amazing with plenty of badass and emotional moments. The most memorable experiences from this story personally was the reunion of Kiryu and Majima and the final battle against Ryuji.

Overall, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a great game. I highly recommend anyone to play this game but there is the downside of the game being a sequel so to get the maximum amount of enjoyment from Yakuza Kiwami 2, it is also highly recommended to complete both Yakuza 0 and Yakuza Kiwami first before jumping into this one.

[b] One of the best Yakuza games with everything except...the combat. [/b]

[h1] 1: Combat [/h1]

Unpopular opinion,but the combat is absolutely clunky and sluggish in this game coming from Y0 or YK1 where the combat there was fluid and just perfect. Sure there are new heat actions that are pretty hilarious not gonna lie,and using weapons is better than the previous games,but you mainly wanna use your fists and kicks in these games. Kiryu feels like exactly like everyone describes him in combat,an old man,he moves slow,barely can dodge anything and he does not feel like the Dragon of Dojima that we know him of.

As for Majima,the combat is pretty good but with only 2 heat actions of it`s own which is pathetic for an iconic character like him.

[h1] 2: Story [/h1]

Skip this part as it will contain spoilers (duh) if you haven't played the game yet. 
At first,i didn't like Ryuji,as I thought he would be the stereotypical brute villain but no,he shows us all how much of a giga chad he is,I mean,he had plenty of opportunities to kill Kiryu,but no,he likes a fair fight,even returning Haruka back to Kiryu after Ryuji killed that fat fuck of a Omi Patriarch that i`m not bothered to remember his name that kidnapped Haruka.
The romance between Kiryu and Kaoru made me giggle like a school girl when it happened.
Insert KSI`s "YES YES YES" meme here.
And the many plot twists that happen in the final chapters of this game mess with your mind but in general it`s a pretty good story,and i honestly dunno if i prefer this,Y0 or K1`s main story as i love all of them.

[h1] 3: Majima Saga [/h1]

A short prequel before the events of the main story of this game. All i can say is that it`s short but sweet at the end.

[h1] 4: Substories [/h1]

They are pretty good,there are some famous ones like the "Be my baby" one or the ghost tape one. They are full of quality too which mind remind you of Y0`s substories which some of them will reference back i think.

[h1] 5: Cabaret Grand Prix [/h1]

Yeah,i know it`s a recycled minigame from Y0,it`s still the best one in this game too,with some QOL improvements and overall being better than in the game it originated from. Koyuki best girl,change my mind.

[h1] 6: Soundtrack [/h1]

Decent enough,not that many memorable pieces maybe except the final Ryuji boss fight one,but outside of that,meh.

[h1] 7: Conclusion [/h1]

If you are a fan of Yakuza,this is a must play,despite some flaws with the combat thanks to the new engine,it`s still a fun game to experience,to laugh and cry with.

[h1] 7/10 [/h1]

This game is a god damn masterpiece. I thought Yakuza Kiwami 1 was decent enough, but this is in another league. The presentation, graphics, and gameplay are the best in the series so far. There is so much to love about this game. I'll start with the elephant in the room: the new engine. It makes the game actually look and play like a triple-A title. It's such a breath of fresh air to be able to walk in and out of every building without having it load every time. Though what's easily the best part of the engine is its physics. It has one of the most unrealistic physics engines I've ever seen and yet it fits so perfectly.

As for the actual gameplay, whether it be combat or side quests, it's also a hefty improvement. The combat has the best progression in the series so far and it feels so much smoother. Plus, the physics engine elevates it even further. The side quests are also at their best in the series. You do stuff like fight a yakuza family with a baby kink, pose for shirtless pictures while being photographed by a man in his underwear, and voice act sex scenes in an upcoming video game. They are also a few new side activities like the hilarious peeing minigame and the softcore porn photoshoot nobody wants to admit they completed. I have to give a small shoutout to the Bouncer missions where you fight through a bunch of goons. It made me really appreciate the game's combat. Also the Karaoke is great as always. The first song I played was Tonight which made me quite sad for reasons I don't want to spoil. The Cabaret Club also returns with a few slight improvements (except I preferred the music from Yakuza 0). 

And then there's the outstanding presentation. It's wonderful to watch Kiryu pop a glass of champagne in the Cabaret Club or perform a slew of entertaining heat actions. The presentation is at its best when in boss fights. Nearly every boss intro is super badass, with the final boss being one of the coolest fights I've ever seen in a video game. The music also puts these fights on another level. I had no clue some soft piano could set the tone of a fight so well.

And of course I wouldn't forget about Majima. He runs his own construction company which is actually a full-fledged MOBA. Whether you like it or not, it's quite impressive that they put this much effort into a Majima side quest. This might be a bit of a spoiler but he shoves himself into the Caberet Club Tournament which is a great callback to Yakuza 0. But there is a short side story you gradually unlock while playing the main game called the Majima Saga which basically catches us up to why he started Majima Construction. This next sentence is another spoiler. Makoto Makimura has a humble appearance in the Majima Saga and it is by far the most emotionally powerful part of the game. The same goes for Majima's ending in Yakuza 0. They were both enough to choke me up.

I don't have much to say about the main story but I think Ryuji Goda is the best villain in the series so far since he actually is somewhat humanized. I also have the story to thank for some great memes like when Kiryu slams a table and aggressively opens a door. The story is decent. Not amazing and not bad.

Overall, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is probably the best game in the series. I prefer Yakuza 0 a little bit because of the story, but Kiwami 2 made such a massive improvement on the gameplay. Even if this is the only Yakuza game you ever play, you will love it.

Playing this game makes me appreciate just how good Kiwami 1 was. The combat in Kiwami 2 is just not as compelling. Gone is the smooth, precise, arcade-y feel, replaced by some weird mush of Rockstar Games physics and mediocre brawler mechanics with stylish heat actions added on top. The lack of diversity in movesets really hurts, and the developers have compensated for this by making boss battles significantly shorter. Kiwami 1 may have issues with difficulty, but it eventually forced you to memorise a huge arsenal of powerful moves, and that ended up being a far more rewarding experience. Kiwami 2 greatly oversimplifies combat to the extent it starts feeling brainless, and does absolutely nothing to force players to deeply engage with the system, because there is little depth to begin with.

But apart from that, this is definitely a huge step up from its prequel. The story, presentation, and characters are improved across the board. Even the music is pretty good, and the minigames are really great too. 

Seeing Kamurocho and Sotenbori for the first time with these graphics is probably worth the price of admission on its own, but there are also serious technical problems with this release. The aliasing is absolutely horrendous, and the game often hitches just before heat action prompts show up, which makes combat unbelievably annoying.

Overall, I'd give it a 7.5/10, same as I gave Kiwami, on the strength of the presentation and story alone. My quest to chase the high of Yakuza 0 continues.

If you don't have a gamepad don't play this game cos u won't be able to lock-in during the boss fights. This makes it extremely difficult to hit your attacks since u have manually guide all of your hits while the boss can easily hit all of theirs. Technically speaking you can lock-in by clicking your scrolling key in your mouse...but know what the problem is? As soon as you let go of scrolling key your lock immediately dissipates. And you know what is great about this game? You can't customize the controls. I wanted to switch the lock-on feature on my left Ctrl key and guess what? It's impossible! there is a control setting on the Options menu, but certain actions are always fixed to default setting. (For example, Left Click=weak attack, Right click=Heavy attack, Middle key/Scrolling key=Lock on, these settings are unchangeable unfortunately)   
Another thing that ticked me off was that there was literally no counter-play u can employ against the enemy especially the bosses . You can't parry enemy attacks, u can't dodge enemy attacks (u technically can but since you move so little u end up getting hit anyway), u can block enemy attacks but that doesn't mean a thing since u can't counterattack afterwards (they will dodge it). Also have I mentioned that you can't use strong attacks during the boss fights? Even if u do stun them for 1~3 seconds, as soon as u right click (heavy attack) they are immediately "cleansed" and will dodge=>counterattack right away. And when bosses dodge unlike u they slide a good meter or 2, whereas ur dodge stretches for a couple of centimeters, can't believe I forgot to mention that. 
All in all the game is so keyboard unfriendly that I strongly recommend u buy a pad to play this or not buy it at all.

Everything about this game is incredible. The fluidity is mind-blowing, the absolute best I've ever seen in a video game. There were maybe three loading screens in total. Graphics are insanely good, not like it matters, but it was so impressive. This is an experience you do not want to miss. So far the best story-telling I've experienced in the series.

Completion at time of writing: 259/303.

Don't think I'll get any more progress on this game though. First of all, let me say this is a good game. If you've played any of the previous games, you'll enjoy this one. It follows much of the same recipe and that should be what you're looking for. That said, I'll give my opinion on this game.

The story is good. It's not great. I really loved the previous two games, and this one had some unexpected twists, but the character writing felt off for a lot of characters, There were a lot of times when characters just acted weird and strangely.. out of character, I suppose. Either way, it's pretty good, even if the ending had a bit too much 'but really, I'm the culprit!' 'no, -I- am the culprit', etc.

However, what would define this game for me, and what I would advise against, is the grind. This game has a lot of minigames and I am a sucker for completion. However, doing that will be a struggle. Oh you want to do colliseum? Sure, here's a million things to grind through. Oh you want to run a cabaret club, here's a million openings to grind through. Oh you want to run majima's construction, here's a million battles to grind through. I did most of the grinds, but couldn't get myself to do them all. Probably don't.

My advice for this game? Play it a bit. Do the things you like, leave the things you don't really like. Only 100% this game if you *really* want to, but probably don't get bogged down in the grind like I did. You'll enjoy the game better.

Yakuza 2 is often regarded as one of long time fans' favorite in the series and with this Kiwami remake treatment, the game becomes even more better with its new Dragon Engine resulting in seamless gameplay, exploration, gorgeous visual and very well-directed cutscenes.

The main theme of identity is executed pretty well with its twists and turns wrapped in a mystery-crime-drama tale. With lots of tension throughout the campaign, the game still manages to find some breathing space to develop Kiryu and other characters's relationship, mainly Osaka Division 4 police Kaoru Sayama, Jiro Kawara and Omi Alliance's Dragon of Kansai, Ryuji Goda.

These main characters are trying to find the answer (except Ryuji Goda as he is the villain) to the mystery surrounding foreign mafia and Yakuza local war as each of them later struggles to cope with the newly found answers to their past. How they deal with their identities is what is the center of Yakuza Kiwami 2's core, with Kiryu thrown into the mix with his own struggle over a certain character death.

in terms of gameplay, Kiwami 2 is a very superb one as well, with its streamlined fighting style, brutal Heat Actions, responsive controls and great sound design. What is noteworthy is its massive new contents including Majima Construction; a real time strategy minigame and Cabaret Grand Prix minigame which is a continuation to Yakuza 0's Cabaret Club minigame, among other minigames.

Looking at its characters and story alone, it's easy to see why Yakuza 2 is fan-favorite but along with this Kiwami 2 treatment, it ends up being as one of the best and most immersive Yakuza game ever with story full of genuine human emotions and fun gameplay.

I'm writing this just after finishing the main story line (and Four Sunshine fml) in Kiwami 2, having played the initial trilogy in order. Looking back I'd say Yakuza 0 is definitely the best one out of the three. It certainly has the best story, and the graphics are not 100% up to par with the third game but they're right up there still. Go play it, it's a cool and interesting story and at the same time there is plenty of fun and silliness too.

The second game (Kiwami "1" if you will) was definitely the weakest. Graphics wise it's a big step back, and moreover the story is short and just kinda meh. [spoiler]Majima is reduced to nothing but a bad joke, which I found awful especially after him being such a strong character in Yakuza 0.[/spoiler]. At the beginning of Kiwami 2 you can choose to watch a quick recap of the events from the second game, and honestly that's enough to get the gist of it. You're really not missing much if you just skip this one entirely.

The third game is certainly the prettiest one and it has some nice quality of life updates, e.g. being able to walk in and out of stores without any loading screens. The combat is simplified a little (no more different stances) but still loads of fun with all the situational special moves they added. As for the story... not as bad and not as short as 1, but not as great as 0 either.  [spoiler]Majima is still mostly there for comic relief but still they did a better job with him this time around.[/spoiler] The story and the missions toward the end are terrible (ugh that Osaka Castle level...). I'd say play this one only if you really loved 0 and want to see a little more of the city with a nice graphical update, but as far as the story goes try to keep your expectations low so you don't get disappointed too much.

tl;dr definitely play 0, might as well skip 1, and play 2 just for the pretty girls.

Loved Yakuza 0, felt Kiwami 1's story really felt like it came out of a PS2 era game, and really didn't love it. Kiwami 2...is kinda alot of that. The Story isn't that engaging to me and the combat system frankly just sucks. It's so very...the same. Every time. Every enemy. There's no tension in the fights, the hit sounds are boring and lack punch, and without any variation of styles, you just kinda...keep punching. Till you win. It's very boring to me. I think graphically, the game looks great, but nothing here just makes me love this game. I hate the eating mechanic to make your stats better, it just takes so long, and you farm the hell out of one location. It's very tiring. Perfect way to describe the whole end result of the game, tiring. I wish I could recommend this game. But I can't. Give this a shot if you like, well made game, I'll still play it, but Majima isn't going to change this 180 to becoming a great review in my opinion.

All right, looks like you've been on a Yakuza binge lately ‚Äì you've already dealt with [b][url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/nuitcalme/recommended/638970/]the prologue[/url][/b] and [b][url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/nuitcalme/recommended/834530/]Kiwami[/url][/b], so now you're looking at Kiwami 2, most likely rubbing your hands and drooling (just a little) in anticipationü§§

Kiwami... You should be well aware by now that it means "extreme" in Japanese. Well, the name hasn't changed, the only new thing is the Arabic numeral at the end, so it should be more of the same, or at least very similar... right?

Well, it's a little bit of [b]yes[/b] and a big friggin' deal of [b]NO[/b]. Despite many core elements being kept largely the same ‚Äì it's still a beat 'em up RPG with all-too-familiar plot devices and our sweet boy Kiryu gracing the streets of Kamurocho and Sotenbori with his divine presence ‚Äì Kiwami 2 still has a lot of notable differences from its predecessor, and I'd like to use the graciously allotted 8000 characters of available space here to tell you about them and not let you die of boredom in the process. 

So, buckle up and make yourself comfortable ‚Äì we're sallying forth into the realm of the new Dragon Engineüêâ
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2698075070
Here's the roadmap we're gonna follow:
[list]
    [*]üíª Performance drops ‚Äì laptop owners beware!
    [*]üíæ No loading screens when entering buildings ‚Äì something you never thought you needed, but it's an absolute game changer.
    [*]üö≤ Destructible environment ‚Äì nothing says "Fierce Dragon" more than being able to decimate an entire office in 5 seconds.
    [*]ü§∏‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Ragdolls and new fighting [u]style[/u] ‚Äì yes, singular.
    [*]üéÆ Reworked experience, inventory and completion list ‚Äì tastes differ, you may hate it or love it to bits. 
    [*]üíã ...and, last but not least, Horny Dragon ‚Äì Kiryu will be finding himself in all kinds of sexy situations way more often than in both previous games combined. 
[/list]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2698067983
[h3]Performance drops[/h3]
[quote]The happy owners of desktop PCs may heave a sigh of relief, but for those with laptops I shall be the bearer of bad news ‚Äì the Dragon Engine may just be way too awesome for our weak-–∞ss computers to comfortably handle. I experienced virtually no lag or stutters in Zero and Kiwami, but Kiwami 2 felt a lot more jittery with constant FPS drops. I got used to it fairly quickly though ‚Äì most of us are ready to sacrifice a lot for a pretty picture, and in this game, it's a pretty picture all rightüòç[/quote]

[h3]Loading screens begone![/h3]
[quote]One of the reasons for performance issues on lower-end PCs is that the open world actually became open for the first time in the series. You can walk into stores and buildings in general without having to stare at black loading screens, and I'm honestly at a loss for words to express how much it adds to the level of immersion. The streets of Kamurocho are finally full of people and objects now, too. It all just feels so alive. The first time I launched the game, I spent two hours just walking everywhere and staring at signs and taking pictures and selfies and oh god you can climb onto the roof?!üò≤[/quote] 

[h3]Destructible environment[/h3]
[quote]The Dragon of Dojima should not be stopped dead in his tracks by a measly traffic cone. Now, the traffic cone will obediently fu—Åk off to the side, as well as crates, bicycles, signs, benches, people... You can go eat at a restaurant and then destroy it completely in a fight with a group of thugs. The owner, scared out of their wits, will tell you to leave and will not sell anything.[/quote]

[h3]Ragdolls and the new fighting style[/h3]
[quote]Bicycles and traffic cones won't be the only things flying around Kamurocho and Sotenbori ‚Äì don't forget about the lifeless bodies of slain enemies colliding with (and subsequently destroying) shop windows and patio tables. Yes, you only get to use one moveset ‚Äì but even then, the combat feels very satisfying due to being a lot more... [i]"realistic"[/i]. Not realistic as in "strictly obeying the laws of physics", but realistic as in "enemies don't have the same falling animation".[/quote]

[h3]Experience, inventory and completion list[/h3]
[quote]...have been completely revamped, and I think I spent at least several hours getting the hang of the new system. I don't wanna get too deeply into the details, so let's just say this:

> EXPERIENCE, LEVELLING AND UPGRADES ‚Äì the new approach is way more complex, but it's also more fun and rewarding, with a billion unlockable skills and ways to earn experience points;
> INVENTORY ‚Äì having 10 of each recovery item has made the game a cakewalk... for the most part;
> COMPLETION LIST ‚Äì won't show completion percentage anymore, but will tell you exactly what you need to do in order to fulfil each requirement.[/quote]

[h3]Horny Dragon[/h3]
[quote]Let's be honest ‚Äì we all love the trademark zany Japanese humour, especially when it's about all things racy and lewd. This is the niche they excel in, and you'll find more than enough of that juicy stuff in this entry of the series. 

I mean, just look at this...üòè[/quote]

[h2]Majima Saga[/h2]
You won't be able to play as Majima (everyone's favourite cute little angel) in the main story, but you'll get a bite-sized DLC to enjoy for a couple of hours. It will tell you about the important events between Kiwami and Kiwami 2 ‚Äì standard-issue Yakuza drama, with a nice little emotional cherry on top.

Won't tell you what that cherry is exactly, but it hit me more than the entire main plot. By [i]"it hit me more"[/i] I mean that I was a sobbing mess, even in front of my girlfriend ‚Äì and you will be, too, unless you're a heartless bastardüò≠

The new engine is really good, though the ragdolls are clunky. The major benefit of this engine is the ability to walk freely between interiors and exteriors, so an Open-World game, and also most of the cutscenes being rendered in the engine, so there's no disconnect between gameplay and cinematics.

One thing I do have to pick with this new engine is the fighting styles (or rather, the lack of them). Yep, Brawler, Rush, Beast, Dragon? Forget about them. In this game there's only one fighting style, which is a mix between those 4 kind of. It's alright, but this game is a little buggier than those made on the older engine (like Yakuza 0 and Kiwami). Heat actions icons not appearing, being stuck in side-stories (only happened once in a training sub-story), people flying across the battle field and so on. But, it still was fun so I can't really say anything.

The story is pretty good, Majima Saga just being a very nice, added bonus, that happens between Kiwami 1 and Kiwami 2 and dives into Majima's character, which I felt he deserved.

The extra content is fun and nice, maybe some annoying and confusing, but I'd say that's in the 2% of the time. There's so much to do, I actually kind of feel overwhelmed, but I enjoy the extra content so it's a good type of overwhelming. It's not necessary, but for those hungry for loads of content, it's there, don't worry.

The Cabaret Club minigame is pretty good, pretty much the same as Yakuza 0, maybe a little more refined.
I really enjoyed this minigame in 0 so I was very happy to see it back here.

Majima Construction for me just wasn't as fun. It's pretty hard to take care of all of your deployed units, but try it and see if it's something YOU might like. I played it a few times and that's it.

Overall, it's your standard Yakuza game, with loads to love and so much content you could sink 100's of hours into this game. It feels more fluid thanks to the new engine, though keep in mind it isn't as refined and bug-free as the old engine. Can't wait to finish the side content!
Good Game!

Honestly, the one thing that ultimately brings this game down for me is the combat: I wish they had just kept the style system from 0 and Kiwami. I get why, storywise, Kiryu doesn't use those styles anymore, but the combat in this one is just...languid; mobs aren't much of a threat, but bosses can dodge as much as they need and block every punch you throw at them, immediately staggering you out of your combo, while you're stuck with the one style that tries to balance everything from speed to power, and the fight becomes less of a punchy-punchy back-and-forth brawl and more of an opening-finding, poking, Heat action-spamming slogfest.

If there's one thing I genuinely enjoy out of the combat, though, it would be the Extreme Heat mode. What it does is: when your Heat gauge is full--as in, actually full to the brim and not just one section of it--instead of using Heat actions, you can activate Devil Trigger, raising your attack power, allowing you to pick up motorcycles, automatically swing nearby objects, and gain access to unique, ever-so-slightly more violent Heat actions. My favourite part, though, is that it changes the final blow of any heavy-attack string to a pseudo-QTE where the camera zooms into the enemy's face as it makes contact with Kiryu's fist or foot in slow motion and you have to rapidly press the heavy attack button to accumulate damage.

Aside from that, being a remake of the second game in the series and all, the writing isn't as compelling as, say, 0, and I found that multiple substories are almost quite literally just

Hostile: "Hey punk, you gonna keep punking or do we have to beat the punk out of you?!"
Wee Lil Victim: "Oh no, mister hostile! Please don't beat me senseless! Oh were it not for the absence of a gallant warrior here to rescue poor me in my time of need!"
[SUBSTORY: Ye Olde Harassment starts]
Kiryu: "The only punk I see here is you"
Hostile: "What was that, asshole?! I'll beat your punk ass too!"
[Kiryu beatdown noises]
Hostile: "Forgive me, mister dragon! I shan't be a knave evermore! AIIIIEEEE!"
Ex-victim: "Thank you, sir! I promise to repay this debt however I can!"
[SUBSTORY: Ye Olde Harassment CLEAR]

Then they unlock a situational Heat action. Not the most compelling substories.

The game looks great though, I'll give it that; doesn't give it any points in my book but there you go.

I'd say only get this game if you really want to experience Kiryu's entire saga or if you really, really just want another Yakuza to play.

Having played through Zero and Kiwami 1 so far this one does bring more to the table. The street fights are a lot more organic and can happen literally anywhere, with many destructible objects around you. The environments are also extremely fleshed out and exporable. The food and drink system has been improved on as well. The story seems interesting so far. I'd go so far as to recommend playing this after Zero and watch the story recap option in the beginning of Kiwami 2.
You buy the game to see Kiryu's story and next thing you know you're spending hours trying to level up girls to become the top cabaret club instead of helping your friends. 10/10 would play again.

So far: 0 > Kiwami 2 > Kiwami

All three games are amazing, but 0 is still my favorite so far and Kiwami 2 edges out Kiwami for multiple reasons. Better substories, more stuff to do, returning the business-style substories from 0 but in new ways, giving resolution to Majima for things that happened in Yakuza 0--this game really does it all. 

There is a TON of fanservice regarding Yakuza 0 in this game. Lots of cameos, references, and direct continuations of storylines. It's all really, really good, but it definitely means that in order to enjoy it fully, you MUST have knowledge of events and characters in Yakuza 0. (I mean, the entire Cabaret Club Czar storyline is just one big callback to Yakuza 0.)

Combat felt TERRIBLE to me at first in this new engine, but once you realize that charged attacks are a godsend and will stop enemies from breaking your combos, it isn't too difficult even on Hard difficulty. Kiryu feels weak and combat feels sort of frustrating at first, but once you begin to level up skills, Kiryu can and will become godly. Seriously, my Kiryu ate bosses for breakfast, even on Hard.

There is a lot of stuff to do in this game. Lots of fun minigames this time around (except the robot fighting one for Haruka....UGH), and more silly substories and fun events. Both business substories, the cabaret and Majima Construction, are strong additions. 

The storyline is just what you'd expect from Yakuza, with plenty of riveting and well-done scenes and characters you know and love. The final chapter pulls out a record amount of plot twists though, lol. Definitely a scene to behold.

I wouldn't generally recommend this game to everyone. Steam unfortunately doesn't allow a rating in-between yes and no, but mine does tend to be a little more towards the yes side. Also: I have no fucking clue about how to properly structure or write this. I'm writing this on a whim after finally getting all achievements and playing it for a half a year now.

[h1]Technical difficulties[/h1]
This PC port is atrocious. When you start the game, it is basically gambling if it will actually render the game or if it will be a black screen with an infinitely falling Steam notification, forcing you to quit and restart the game over and over again until it finally renders properly. 

Forget ever tabbing out of the game to read messages, watch a Stream or generally anything else outside the game, because as you soon join in the game again, it will be a black screen yet again and you can keep spamming Alt+F4 and keep on clicking the "X" to close in the taskbar, it will take at least a minute no matter what for the Game to finally crash and trying to open the task manager or anything else will not help, as the game in this black screen state will always overlay over any other Application you have running. Streaming over Discord also wasn't possible for me.
The previous PC ports of 0 and Kiwami 1 already presented various technical difficulties such as random crashes at certain settings etc., but Kiwami 2 certainly takes the cake here.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story is not horrible, but not great like 0's either. I'd say slightly worse than Kiwami 1. Major complaint for me is introducing characters, but then sidelining and dumping them for more than half the game, before reintroducing them at the end after fighting "ass-pull backstabbing traitor surprise villains" to somehow connect to them again, a mistake which the first game did as well. Some new Characters are interesting like Daigo, Ryuji and Kei Ibuchi, but it's especially sad with Ryuji and Kei because they have a great and cool foundation that never really gets greatly built upon or fleshed out and it turns out as really flat and unchanged in the end. Most substories are rather forgetfull I'd say, but some stand quite out and are interesting like: 
[list]
    [*]"Be My Baby"
    [*]"The Legendary Dragon"
    [*]"Embracing my True Self"
    [*]"Kazuma Kiryu, Professional Voice Actor"
[/list]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Gameplay wise it has made a lot of Improvements over the previous games, thanks to the new Dragon Engine (although that has seemed to introduce other problems as mentioned before), like fluid and seemless transitions into fights and buildings, ragdoll effects and physics and obviously greater graphical fidelity. 
Thanks to this game basically being a Yakuza 2 re-skin of Yakuza 6, Battles have gone way more stale though. As there is now only one single fighting style, and only a limited amount of different combos and heat actions one can perform and it gets really boring and repetitive very quickly. One thing that I noticed was the seemingly inconsistent UI. When you try to quit or exit something, sometimes the selection already hovers over "yes", sometimes over "no". In certain sections, if you click yes, the game will ask you again if you are sure or not, while in most sections it doesn't. 
The game is quite tire- and bothersome to play for me like the previous games, because for example: 
[list]
 [*]you need to keep running back and forth to purchase certain items and trying again
 [*]RNG screwing you over
 [*]having too many menu pop-ups
 [*]extremely annoying enemies and fighting styles
[/list]

At first I played this game for 1-2 hours max before I got too tired and lethargic, and dropped it a lot of times, which explains why it took half a year for me to actually finish it.

[h1]Verdict[/h1] 
Yakuza Kiwami 2 isn't a horrible or bad game, but it definitely missed a lot of spots where it had more potential or even dropped ones it already had. It's an alright game, not something I'd recommend for everyone to get into Yakuza or looking for a really good game. This is rather for people like me, who like to play all the games in a series in canonical order as is possible and who have played the previous Titles Kiwami 1 and Yakuza 0 and want to get the full story before moving to the next games. 

I'd rate it a .... 6-6.5/10? maybe I'll change my mind.
Honestly this game is really fucking good. I had some issues with cpu usage at the start (i5 7600) but once I fixed framerate inconsistency I could really start to enjoy what this game is good for.

Even though the combat is very different from 0 and Kiwami, it's still very enjoyable with its own charms. The story is stronger than Kiwami and is surprisingly interconnected. The substories are also pretty good. None of them were a hassle and at worst were uninteresting. Overall, this game gets an 8/10 from me (just don't bother trying to complete it or else you'll come off with a worse experience).
The game had an engaging story line. And there is no lack of extra materials like side missions and mini games. Looking to start Yakuza Remastered 3 now.

I'm coming into this after having played the two previous entries in chronological order. This has, so far, been my least favourite title in the series. However it doesn't mean that it's a bad game.
Y2 receives a new coat of paint for this remake but, in my opinion, the fancy graphics don't really do the game a favour. I would've preferred if they kept this remake in the previous engine, the one used for Y0 and Y1Kiwami. Yes, the character models look great and the lighting is spectacular so visually this game is impressive, but the visuals don't really do enough to hide this game's age.
Storywise, it's pretty standard affair. The plot is needlessly complicated throughout with many plot points and characters and flashbacks all crammed together. Yes, by the end it all makes sense and ties in together, but the pacing is a little bit off and the trade-off is that the final chapter is a chaotic mix of plot twist after plot twist, merely minutes away from each other, bringing all the characters together in a 'No, it was actually me that did it.' scenario that repeats itself a bit too many times. Still, some twists really did surprise me and it can be forgiven that the original story is quite old at this point but the fancy graphics fool you into thinking it's more modern. Still, is it bad? Nah, but it's not great either. Its saving grace is that Kyriu's character is explored in an interesting way that, I thought, ties in very well with the previous story and he remains throughout an amazing character and protagonist.
Minigames are, once again, prevalent and needlessly difficult. I don't find them 'challenging', I just find them so difficult that completing them becomes a chore with very small elements of fun throughout. For example, I love the karaoke but trying to actually get the score high enough to 'complete' it seems impossible so I just didn't bother, personally.
The Cabaret side quest is back in this one from Y0 and I enjoyed my time with it, though its story wasn't as good as the one in Y0. They also introduced a new side quest series with Majima Construction, but that too felt very grindy and not too interesting. What I liked about these two is the way they used the characters available and it felt like the famous NPCs of the Yakuza world have been given some sort of presence and purpose, which was something I appreciated.
Speaking of the world, it was great to return to Kamurocho and Sotenbori, seeing them with the new updated engine, though I felt that their previous iterations in Y0 had more charm and aliveness, though I am aware that this is technically an older game.
To conclude, you should play this as a fan of the series, seeing the next chapter in Kyriu's story, but it didn't feel like it deserved the attention and time that I dedicated to the previous entries. It's a bit bloated and trying too hard to impress, but overall remains a confident Yakuza experience.
The soundtrack didn't feel very impressive either, but again I'm coming to it with my ears adjusted to the wonderful OST of Y0 and probably expecting a little too much.

PROS: Kyriu - Characters - Some cool story twists - Combat gameplay and physics
CONS: OST - Story pacing - Completion - Less charm

Have you played Yakuza 0? Yakuza Kiwami 1? No? Go play those first and then play this one. Why you ask? Because YK2's gameplay mechanics, stat system, and open world blow those two out of the water in quality and enjoyment. With the exception of a couple minigames (like darts) that I thought were implemented a little bit better in previous installments, pretty much everything here is an upgrade. So, if you like quality of life features, it might be best to play previous games before you do this one so you're able to enjoy Y0/YK1 to the fullest without comparing them to this game.

Also, obviously, you'll know and understand more of the character actions in this game if you know the previous ones. The game is fun, and you'll get plenty of enjoyment out of it, whether it's watching the amazing drama unfold in the cutscenes, or playing Mahjong or Shogi for fun while you kill some time. If you're on the fence, wait for a sale I guess? But I got 44 hours out of this game and I think that that's more than worth the price it's sold for. Especially if you're the type to go after side quests and get away from the serious yakuza stories and more into the silly kung fu grandma  side stories.
