I came into Yakuza Kiwami 2 expecting more from what Yakuza 0 and Kiwami gave me. I got more (and I also got some things different that I'm not too fond of).

[h1] The Good [/h1]

Yakuza Kiwami 2 brings along with it the things that made me fond of 0 and Kiwami: brutal, hong-kong action flick, over the top violence, ridiculous side-quests, a kick ass soundtrack, and too much additional content than I am actually willing to participate with, for better and for worse.

Kiwami 2 is probably the biggest game in the Yakuza franchise I have played so far, being on par with 0 in terms of raw, total content, so there's definitely plenty for people to enjoy here.

Kiwami 2's story is actually pretty solid, better than Kiwami's and about as good 0's. Not bad. I usually don't care for story but when it's done well on top of solid gameplay I have nothing but praise.

If you're following from 0 to Kiwami to Kiwami 2, like I have, then you will be happy to know that the Cabaret Club major side-quest is back, with new girls to make papa LOTS OF MONEY, and the inclusion of a "new" mini-game, which is MAJIMA CONSTRUCTION, where you play a sorta tower-defense like game using some of your favorite side characters and enemies from the Yakuza games to beat the hell out of punks who want to destroy Majima's construction operation. It's essentially an entirely different game in its own right, and its fun side content for when the combat gets tire-some.

A new side-story that wasn't present in the original Yakuza 2 has you play as Majima, preceding the events of the game's actual story. It's a small side-story, and as such, is very minimal in content. You simply get to play with Mad Dog style Majima from 0 the entire time, and me telling you reader that much isn't really a spoiler.

[h1] The Bad [/h1]

Yakuza Kiwami 2 made the absolute most horrid sin of all sins in any beat em up game. Enemies can block your attacks mid-combo. That means every single attack, the enemy can potentially just block it, throwing you off your game entirely and letting them get in some cheap punishes. That's not how this works. See, what's SUPPOSED to happen, is that as the player, when I throw out an attack, and I hit an enemy THAT ISN'T BLOCKING, every subsequent strike in the combo SHOULD connect UNLESS I try to do an "untrue" combo, in which case, the enemy can recover from being struck and potentially punish my more risky move (or, if I made the right bet, I land a more devastating strike on them). The only other time the enemy gets to punish me is if I completely miss my attack, known as "whiffing," due to them dodging or my accuracy was awful, which would allow them to get hits on me, or the enemy has "super-armor," meaning they do not suffer from "hit-stun" when you strike them, which lets the enemy eat your attacks and hit you anyway (which requires you, the player, to understand your attacks aren't getting through and thus you need to A.) grab or B.) dodge).

This is basic fighting game 101, and this is how 0 and Kiwami functioned, and this how practically every other action-fighting-beatem-up-hybrid of a game has worked forever. Even if they could "combo-break" that's a whole lot different than the enemy blocking your attacks mid-combo, which disrupts the pacing of combat and leads to very unsatisfying gameplay. A wheel is a damn wheel. Making it a square doesn't do anything except for make it annoying as all hell and make me put Kiwami 2, in terms of it's major gameplay component (being the combat) lower than 0 and even Kiwami. 0 had 10 different fighting styles, 5 for each character in Kiryu and Majima, and Kiwami, despite being half the game 0 was, contained 5 returning styles and even fleshed out the Dragon style to the point to where it almost had some Majima styles in it. Kiwami 2's combat is just the Dragon Style the entire time, without the flare and style it had in 0 and Kiwami.

That being said...Kiwami 2's combat is still pretty good. I simply did not like it as much as I liked 0 and Kiwami's combat, and it was a more frustrating experience because of that.

[h1] The Ugly [/h1]

Speaking of "flare," I don't know if it's just me or not, but things feel...lacking in "impact." Kiryu's combos don't feel as satisfying to land. Some heat actions certainly have punch, but others feel a little flat. The ragdoll physics actually do more harm than good because it often feels like I'm pounding on wet plastic bags, and whenever Kiryu is stuck in a ragdoll state, flopping around like a fish out of water, part of me laughs, and part of me is annoyed because he won't get the hell up. This also extends to trying to finish enemies in a ragdoll state, because they're constantly rolling around on the ground sometimes your window to finish them off with a heat action doesn't happen, or, you can abuse the map geometry and keep them stuck in corners so that they never get up.

Basically, the ragdoll physics, at least to me, don't do the game any favors and was more often an inconvenience than a glaring detriment to gameplay, along side the flow and impact of attacks on enemies not feeling as strong as they used to. The only exception to the lack of impact on attacks is from the "Extreme Heat Mode," which is where the best, most brutal heat actions are.

Some music tracks are recycled from Yakuza Kiwami. While I'm not against their inclusion (as they're awesome tunes), it does conflict with the style and tone of the newer tracks in the game. Kiwami had a very distinct feel to it in terms of it's music, and mixing it with Kiwami 2's just makes it feel kinda iffy.

A criticism I have of the Yakuza franchise so far, from 0 to Kiwami and even Kiwami 2, is how there are certain characters introduced that have very dramatic introductions, only for them to get killed off literally within the next or the next next cutscene. They're there, and then they're gone, but they get all this dramatic attention to them and it doesn't feel right.

[h1] Verdict [/h1]

I didn't like Yakuza Kiwami 2 as much as I liked 0 and Kiwami in terms of gameplay and side-content, but Kiwami 2's main plot was actually pretty good all things considered, it's a very pretty game, and despite it not being as alluring as the previous games in terms of gameplay, it was still pretty damn good.

All in all, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a pretty solid game, that is visually impressive, narratively engaging, ripe with side content, and has solid gameplay. Not bad at all.

Some people don't like Kiwami 2, with its gaudy green filter, divisive combat and changes compared to the original. But Kiwami 2 offers more than enough to be worth your time, and at its core is still a Yakuza game full of content, wackiness and fun.

Currently playing following the Yakuza time line so finished Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1 before playing this one.
Kiwami 2 is an interesting change in play from Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1. Instead of loading when entering store fronts or pubs you can generally go in and out directly which makes for a somewhat smoother experience. Weapons can be collected from beaten foes. This was a nice change from Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1 where you could pick up the weapons of goons but after the fight you tossed it aside. In Kiwami 2 you have the option to store it during the fight and sell or repair it later. Fight styles are gone however which was mildly disappointing as I favored rush style with its fast paced stick and move style of play. It's still possible once you unlock quickstep Max but boss targets tend to start defending or counter punching after getting hit in the blindside once or twice while in previous iterations rush could land a full combo. Parry sort of follows the same problem. Though there is a heat option after parry I found it less reliable. Fighting large scale mobs tend to dissolve in either weapons swings, bouncing from target to target or grabbing a goon and using them as a wrecking ball as you hurl them into the rest of the crowd. A rather pleasant if repetitive move. Charge moves are a nice touch particularly in dodgy targets as there is a wider swing to the attack. A lot of the earlier iteration problems are not present as regeneration armor doesn't seem to be present nor is firearms as massively over powering as there are less large aoe weapons more limited shots. 
The story is ok if a little weird with the flashback memories of people who appear clueless of events that they were part of and yet have to investigate in modern day. It's a little predictable in parts but suits the game.
With decent mechanics the game is a reasonably good time.

Kiwami 2 was a really fun game for me, so much so that it was another Yakuza game I felt I had to get 100% with. I went to Kiwami 2 straight after playing Kiwami 1 and comparing the two, I personally like 2 more than 1. The combat in this one feels more mobile and I preferred having the condensed fighting styles. Character models do ragdoll when they get hit hard though which sometimes is a bit off-putting, but is a minor point really. The story is much more in depth than it is in the first game and the characters are great. As always with Yakuza games, the sub stories are hilarious and are worth completing. The only part that really annoyed me was doing the bouncer quests for the achievement. Of course, you don't have to do all these but if you're going for the completion, 26 quests with 3 difficulties each gets a bit tedious. The Majima Saga was a great addition and is certainly worth playing through, both because it's Majima and why wouldn't you want to play as him, but also for the added context of how things ended up the way they are at the start of the game. I enjoyed doing the cabaret club minigame and spent a lot of time on that, and preferred it over the Majima Construction game as this felt a little long-winded, albeit good for the accompanying story. 

Overall, another brilliant Yakuza game that's worth playing. For me, it seemed to have a perfect way of making me feel like I'm really good at it but at the same time, challenging me enough to keep me engaged and trying hard.

[i][b]Linux & Steam Deck:[/b] Runs well on Arch-based system on Proton 6.3-7, but has controller issues on Ubuntu. Plugging the controller before you launch the game will cause the game to stall. Launch the game first with the controller unplugged, and then plug-in the controller. [/i]
[hr][/hr]
Being the last of Yakuza series that feature the signature flashy action combat, Yakuza Kiwami 2 also sees the final installment with Kiryu Kazuma as the protagonist. Kiwami 2 is a swan song to a 15 year saga of Kiryu and it is mostly a triumphant one. Excellent graphics, engaging sub-stories, wonderfully realized mini-games topping off what is a mostly good story, revamped physics engine, good leveling economy and progression as well as  combat. 

With even Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio‚Äôs spin-off Lost Judgment having an uncertain future, there‚Äôs no telling if and when Yakuza‚Äôs flashy combat system will make a return and so Kiwami 2 is a bittersweet end to the old-school Yakuza series. 

It is a worthy farewell. Strongly recommended. 
[hr][/hr]
[h3]What‚Äôs Excellent[/h3]

[list]
	[*]Beautiful near life-like graphics.
	[*]Interesting and well told sub-stories.
	[*]Excellent and robust mini-games. 
[/list]

Kiwami 2 has the best graphics of the old-school Yakuza series. Character models are rendered to near life-like and they are beautiful, and the environment of Kamurocho and Sotenbori are as densed as ever. Both towns feel alive and lived in, and Ryu Ga Gotoku went 2 steps further and remove the loading time for entering and exiting the shops, making the transition seamless. The effect is spectacular, it‚Äôs like you‚Äôre really walking into the store. The buildings too have a lot of depth, allowing you to enter it, going to it‚Äôs second, third, fourth floor and the attic, weaving into the buildings rooms and offices and even finding their exits in the back alleys. It‚Äôs a novel experience. 

Having people walking on the streets of Kamurocho and Sotenbori isn‚Äôt what made them feel alive, rather the many many sub-stories is what gives these cities their life-like character. Kiryu is still helping people and solving problems. It is these sub-stories that make Yakuza feel like an open-world game in a closed map and it is something that Ryu Ga Gotoku has perfected. The stories are interesting, ranging from helping a granny against a triad to voice-acting a ‚ÄúBoy‚Äôs Love‚Äù video game, there is so many things here that you make laugh or move you. 

Another Yakuza series signature is it‚Äôs always entertaining and well-designed mini-games. Cabaret Club makes a return with Yakuza 0‚Äôs alumni hostess Yuki taking centre stage again. The obligatory underground Coliseum also makes a return with everything still in tact. A new mini-game called Clan Creator is introduced, with you leading Majima Construction company as foremen. It‚Äôs a mini real-time strategy game with you controlling many heroes to battle against other construction companies for control of Kamurocho Hills. There is also the slightly not wholesome and a little annoying Haruka‚Äôs Request, where you get to spend time with your adopted daughter Haruka fulfilling her wishes that includes gambling in the Purgatory Casino. Lastly, There is the overly long Bouncer Missions, a 28 stage rush mode where you get to go around Kamurocho and Sotenbori beating out different types of mobs and bosses. 
[hr][/hr]
[h3]What‚Äôs Good[/h3]

[list]
	[*]New physics engine make the environment more interactive. 
	[*]Story has great potential, with good beginning and middle.
	[*]Leveling economy and progression is solid.
	[*]Combat is more free form with more emphasis on weapons. 
[/list]

The new physics engine makes the world of Yakuza more interactive. Kiryu can now knock over benches, bikes and traffic cones, he can also leap across railings or jump off from the 2nd floor without fall damage, he can also climb over slight elevation, etcetera. Of course, due to a new engine there is also new jank. Character models here behave like rag-dolls especially during combat, but it‚Äôs nothing game-breaking. 

The story as a lot of potential, enacting the long awaited rival gang-war between the Omi Alliance and the Tojo Clan as well as foreign organized crime. As usual there is deception and betrayal, and the set-up and build-up is I‚Äôd say, spectacular but Kiwami 2 didn‚Äôt quite stick the landing. Kiryu‚Äôs romance with Sayama is I believe unnecessary but understandable. And the twist at the end is unjustified because there was no fore-shadowing of it. Goda Ryuji is an excellent antagonist and most of the side characters are interesting as well although, I think there are some parts that are too Hollywood for my liking such as the Game of Death inspired sequence, with a gaudy golden castle rising from the ground. 

The character and leveling system is pretty solid, where you know have 5 stats that you require to level, and everything you do in Kiwami 2 will raise these 5 attributes. Combat, mini-games, sub-stories, playing arcade, darts, karaoke, eating, drinking, all contribute to raising your stats. These stat points are used to gain a variety of skills including techniques, heat actions and life skills. This economic system works really great and do mimic a life-like experience. 

Due to a new physics engine, the combat system gets tweaked a little bit. Battling groups are now free form and even enemies can utilized environmental assets to hit you. Weapons are now greatly buffed, and there are even more essential in Bouncer Missions as well as main story boss fights. Enemy A.I. is also enhanced being able to dodge and counter effectively. Heat Mode is unbalanced, especially with bosses which make them practically invulnerable except when you pop your own heat mode. And of course, the rag doll effect is ridiculous and funny but it doesn‚Äôt negatively affect combat. 
[hr][/hr]
[h3]What‚Äôs Could‚Äôve Been Better[/h3]

[list]
	[*]Cringe ending to the main story. 
	[*]Mini-Games are too numerous and exhausting. 
[/list]

To be fair, there aren‚Äôt many negative-ish things to say about Kiwami 2. The story is 15 years old and so, most of the weak points on the main story can be forgiven. Particular, the less than satisfying romance between Sayama and Kiryu, which I thought rather sudden and the build-up wasn‚Äôt executed as realistically as I‚Äôd hope. The ending though was just not very good, and handled in a very 80s Hollywood summer blockbuster way, rather than a 70s Martin Scorsese or Francis Ford Coppola direction. It‚Äôs corny and cringey at times though, it‚Äôs really not that bad with all things considered. 

Also another negative is the length of mini-games. On top of the already lengthy Cabaret Club and Clan Creator that averages 10 hours each, there is also 3 different types of battle mini-games that include the Coliseum, Street Bosses and Bouncer Missions. The Bouncer Missions especially takes forever to complete, and the last 9 stages where you have to defeat the Amon brothers are especially difficult. It is very exhausting and takes too long to finish but fortunately, these battle mini-games are not essential to the main game (unlike the Cabaret and Clan which arguably, are essential to the main story progression). 
[hr][/hr]
[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
Old fans can still find some solace in knowing that Yakuza‚Äôs 3 main PC releases, Yakuza 0, Yakuza Kiwami and this Yakuza Kiwami 2, are great games that are worthy of any collection. I would recommend buying all 3 and start with Yakuza 0 and if you already played the previous two installments, Yakuza Kiwami 2 will be a moderately satisfying end to this long-running franchise. Strongly recommended. 

Of course, you can still buy the Playstation port of Yakuza 3,4,5 and 6 on Steam if you‚Äôre so inclined.

[h1] Sub Story 69: A Rambling Review [/h1]

At first I was a bit worried that this game wouldn't live up to both Yakuza 0 and Yakuza Kiwami. The switch to the dragon engine was a bit jarring. Everything was so shiny and Kiryu felt a hell of a lot heavier to control and yearned for the Kiwami/0 engine. I'm glad to say though that once you get used to the new combat system things start to really click and the shiny new coat of paint make the cities of Kamurocho and Sotenbori really shine.

Let's talk about combat. At first, I lamented the loss of the distinct combat styles and style switching however the newfound weight of the overhauled physics really makes combat feel impactful and heavy. I feel like it really works even 
though some of the style and complexity of the combat is lost. However, some new additions such as extreme heat mode and charge attacks keep the combat interesting. Essentially you will be playing the entire game in what is the dragon style of the previous games, which isn't such a bad thing. One thing I particularly enjoy is that extreme heat mode brings back elements of [strike] Best [/strike] Beast mode which is rad. So overall I feel it's a bit of a downgrade but not enough to really hold anything against the game. [spoiler] Of course this doesn't matter if your a rad dude and just Tiger Drop everyone you meet. [/spoiler]

So the combat is different but it's still fun. But what about the story? I hear all none of you ask. Well hypothetical person it's great! All of the twists and betrayal and absolutely rad title card entrances that you've come to expect are here. Gotta love Ryuji Goda dudes rad and I'm a sucker for motivations that are basically "THERE CAN ONLY BE ONE" which is what we've got here. Add in some bombs a foreign mafia some pretty good romance surprisingly and an ending that actually leaves Kiryu happy (Is this even legal in a Yakuza game?) and you've got a pretty enjoyable experience.

You like side content? Of course you do you idiot you're playing a Yakuza game. Get on board cause we've got 80+ hours of it here buddy and it ranges from amazing to kill me now. [i] Amazing [/i]: Kiryu voicing a Yaoi game. [i] Kill me now [/i]: Playing 72 bouncer missions [b] OF WHICH ONLY  24 ARE UNIQUE [/b]. Seriously though most things presented here are excellent and the bouncer missions are the only content I really thought was egregious padding. I mean did we really need three versions of each mission seriously? But I digress, the game offers a good amount of side content you can even hang out with Haruka and be a good dad or sing karaoke with Majima.

Speaking of Majima, he's a construction worker now and it's great the mini-game attached isn't the best but it isn't horrible. He does get a small three chapter playable side story which is cool adds a little backstory to the game as well.

Another plus about a game like this is that if you decide you want all the achievements you get to not only bash your head against 72 repetitive bouncer missions but also get to learn how to play Mahjong which is hard but now that I know how to play kinda it's actually pretty fun. So hey thanks Yakuza I feel a bit more enriched as a person now.

Basically all of my complaints could be solved by not being a completionist and ignoring some of the more less engaging content but in comparison to everything the 72 bouncer missions is kind of a drop in the bucket and I had a ton of fun in my 130 hours with the game there's even gravure photoshoot sessions as a mini-game with sexy ladies or taking Kiryu to a place to watch movies ranging from implied porn to horror and then he gives a small review that tend to be pretty funny. 

Oh I guess some people don't like the experience system but I thought it was fine not as cool as using literal money or having to fight Majima though so whatever it's kind of a minor aspect of the overall experience.

So yeah this game rocks.

[h1] Sub Story 69: A Rambling Review (END) [/h1]

I've been kind of binging the Yakuza series from the moment I started up Yakuza 0. If you've never played any Yakuza games, and you like strong but kindhearted protagonists, I recommend you stop reading any reviews and blindly get and install and start up Yakuza 0. That's what I did, and I've never in my life made a better decision regarding digital media.
By the time I finished Yakuza Kiwami, I thought "jeez, the fighting system might get kind of repetitive after 150 hours of it, I wish they could change it up in the next game... but I guess that'd be too big of a risk to take, and you can't exactly remake an entire game and still make it fun for the same reasons." But I was kiwami wrong. (Kiwami means extreme)
Yakuza Kiwami 2 feels like I'm playing a Yakuza game for the very first time... again. That feeling is beyond stellar, and I wish it on anyone. On another note, seeing the characters develop further through the Yakuza storyline feels like I'm watching my friends grow up. It's a beautiful experience that I haven't seen anywhere else in the same fashion yet and I've been playing videogames for more than a decade straight. 
You know how game reviewers always give 9/10, or 96/100, because they're too much of a coward to give a full score to any game? Well, anyone who doesn't rate Yakuza Kiwami 2 10/10 lives in a world of lies. These last three weeks I've been playing Yakuza hours every single day, and I've played through 3 Yakuza games in a row without anything that has a story in between, I can clearly see any weaknesses that Yakuza Kiwami 2 might have, and I must say, they're not that bad.
I took 40 hours to finish the main story of this game, and an additional 18 for the three biggest side stories. I don't 100% for shit, I just play what feels fun, and this game surely does.

Combat Wise:
The fighting system is much more simplified and so are the heat moves (until you advance further in and unlock EH Mode). You now play using the "LEGEND/DRAGON" fighting style from 0/Kiwami 1, with things mixed in like the clothesline punch from the Beast style, and the Drop Kick from the Brawler tree, and the Quicksteps and Punches from the Rush style. What I mean by "Legend/Dragon" mode is heavy attacks are timing based like in YK0, where holding down the heavy attack can change what attack you throw.
Story Wise:
The game has a great storyline in the series, and it offers twice as more than the original PS2 Version. Voice acting is again once again on point. If you played 0 and Kiwami 1 you'll have a blast, in the Cabaret's of Sotenbori, and in the side content of Kamurocho all villains are IRL wrestling big shots from the NJPW.
My one issue with the game if you're a completionist:
One side story is a Mahjong Tournament, and if you've never played it like me, it's hard, and it's even harder without the items that make it simpler for you to win in Mahjong, because the game doesn't offer a play by play guide to the player to teach them anything, it just gives you a 19+ piece Slideshow with everything.

Otherwise, I recommend the game. It also brings a full version of Virtua Fighter 2.1, and Virtual-On!

So far the most modern of the franchise I've played. The new engine has improved physics, dramatically improved textures and a different way to make the inventory and fighting work. There were so many changes to Zero and One that I don't even know where to start; and while I didn't think all of them were better - I prefer the battle stances, the more limited inventor space, the older experience system and the higher karaoke difficulty - all together I believe Yakuza is doing changes in the right direction as far as moving into the future goes. One step back, four steps forward.

The amount of fanservice in the game is downright insane. The fan-favorite Majima makes his appearance over so many instances that it almost feels like Zero again. He's there for your caba-club minigame, he is there for your Majima Construction and he's there for a few extra chapters where you actually get to control a 'nerfed' version of what we were used to, but all the same the extra mile was appreciated.

The minigames were reworked and while I don't agree with all the chances overall they ended up better than before; although it is a shame to see bowling go, the inclusion of a full RTS/beat-them-up hybrid makes up for that in spades. There are full, actual arcade SEGA games available to play and the extra missions were *brutal*; this may be the most powerful iteration of Kiryu yet with his new weapon mastery, special heat mode, new equipment options, far more healing items that you'd think necessary and variety of counters, but he really needs it for the optional, uber-hard content available.

I'm not gonna lie, this is a fantastic game but it slightly loses to zero for me. I liked the challenge of a few fights, and even the twists and twists and twists and twists  at the end rivaling your average Mexican telenovela were a little too much. "Ha-ha! I was actually the final boss!", "No! It was me all along!", "No, you fool; I played you like a fiddle!", "I outplayed your outplay with HIS outplay!", "No! actually..."

[b]General: [/b]
It has vast improvements to the first installment, making it feel much less clunky and a lot more open.
Combat is faster and therefore more enjoyable as well.
The Majima Saga was a nice bonus on top and felt more polished than the Majima Everywhere mechanic from the first game.

[b]Substories: [/b]
Unlike the Yakuza Kiwami 1, it's easy to keep track of all of the substories. The substories were far better and more memorable generally as well. Some of them even spread up into multiple parts.
Not all are great, there are a fair few minor ones as well but that is to be expected.

[b]Minigames: [/b]
Minigames are one of the best Part in the Yakuza Games.
Big Minigames: 2
- [spoiler] Majima Constructions [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] Hostess Club Four Shine [/spoiler]
Unique Minigames (Not counting those which are in most other games like Shogi, etc.) : 3
- [spoiler] Bodyguard Minigame [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] Toylets [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] Gravure Photoshoot [/spoiler]

[b]Conclusion: [/b]
All in all, it is a vast improvement to the first installment in pretty much every way.

I played Yakuza 0 and loved it so much that I decided to play the entire series. Moved on to Kiwami next and liked it a lot even though it was a step or two down from Y0 and has some annoying problems. Then I hyped to play Kiwami 2 as most consider it to be top tier Yakuza game.

The first half of the game has some pacing issues as well as other deeper problems especially the combat. The combat is a departure from the previous games which were style based and I think this new combat system is a step down. The style based combat system was much more enjoyable. The first half (more like 40%) of the game is really a chore, I hated the combat and the story was kind of all over the place. Many times I thought of quitting the game as I was not enjoying it but my love for the previous games made me push through.

After that is when the story starts getting a sense of direction and flow and it gets exciting. The combat gets more and more enjoyable as you improve stats and gain abilities and with it the combat starts getting some pace to it. From here on out, the game is a blast and I had an amazing time with it.

I still think Y0 had the best villains by far. No one comes close to Kuze. In this game, since it is juggling so many characters/orgs as antagonists, they don't really do much with Ryuji Goda. I loved this guy whenever he was on screen. He is a Yakuza with a code. He could have been so much awesome if he had his own game where he and his family are the only antagonist.

The story is amazing but second best to Y0. Combat is third behind the other two games. For me Y0 pulled more heartstrings and had better character arcs.

My ratings:
Y0 - 9.5/10
Kiwami 2 - 8.5/10
Kiwami - 7.5/10

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a great entry in a fantastic series. While it doesn't necessarily have the clarity or focus of Yakuza Kiwami 1, or the top notch drama writing of 0, it's still supremely solid. The combat is appropriately pared down to be simpler (much closer to the original games), but still fun to roll through crowds of enemies. Overall, still irreverently a Yakuza game and something I enjoyed every moment of. 

Pros:
-Ryuji Goda Fucks
-Kiryu battling a "Competing Dragon" is a cool thematic direction for the series.
-Kiryu punches not one, but two tigers
-Some of the substories are EXCELLENT (Fake Kiryu, Gondawara Family, etc)
-THE BONKERS OSAKA CASTLE SEQUENCE IS REALLY GOOD
-Majima Construction is objectively great
-Majima Saga was short, but sweet. An explosive bundle of emotional catharsis and closure for Majima after the events of Yakuza 0. Well appreciated.
-The Kiwami Exclusive fanfare in general is pretty good and really helps tie the game into the series current state.

Cons:
-The integration of the Jingweon Mafia is cool in some ways and very meh in others. Very weird to paint all Jingweon guys as LOYAL TO THE DEATH TO THE CODE when literally we are playing a game about the Japanese Mafia and their adherence or not to a Code. 
-The plot gets a little convoluted at times. Some twists feel like twists for the sake of twists. 
-Less memorable substories overall than 0 or 1
-You shouldn't have to spend EXP to buy ally heat moves. I didn't end up getting a single one.
-You can no longer pick up HEAVY OBJECTS like motorcycles

Misc:
-Food based EXP was an interesting direction. I don't think I hated it. It was fun watching Kiryu eat entire restaurants back to back.

Going to be a long one! So here I go! Played Yakuza 0 and fucking loved it, played Kiwami 1 and loved it. And 2 might..honestly be my favorite. It‚Äôs so cool how they did these remakes. Connecting things with 0 better. I love callbacks, and as the series grows the more the better. This game improves on a lot of things, it‚Äôs a different engine, which looks really nice, but it mainly brings in a lot of quality of life improvements. Locker keys are back but the finder doesn‚Äôt take up an item slot anymore for example. But mainly the no loading times going in and out of stores, the world continuing moving on while you‚Äôre inside, the random street fights included, which are still annoying, but you can avoid them better. Also you can throw guys into store windows and the store won‚Äôt serve you anymore until later. Couple that with insanely hilarious rag doll physics. And it‚Äôs the best engine they used so far. The combat is a bit more simplified, but I liked that a lot actually. Only complaint was lack of variation in heat actions. Though there were some awesome new ones, overall they were kinda low on new stuff, but that might be because I didn‚Äôt invest in that skill tree much. The side quests in this game had a lot more humor compared to Kiwami 1, and was more on the level of 0, which was awesome. Also a lot of heart again. This game series just has such a nice feeling put into the side quests. This game also once again features 2 major mini games. The hostess club game from 0 returns, and while it‚Äôs mostly a repeat of 0, it again just has so much charm and heart into the stories around it. You get the feeling you‚Äôre home with your friends. Also fun surprises and characters really make the story line there. Which brings me to the second big mini game..MAJIMA CONSTRUCTION! Holy shit when they first sang the song I died laughing. The actual mini game itself is pretty fun. But the whole theme around it, and especially the song is just so good. The main story is a bit more over the top compared to 1, which is great. Including a certain Yakuza Huntress~ add in an awesome Majima stand alone DLC thingy and it‚Äôs a perfect game. I once again did all side quests/optional bosses and a lot of achievements. And as usual, the only thing that‚Äôs stopping this game from being a 10/10 is the grinding really. Mostly in the big 2 mini games though. But damn this game is close. What an amazing series.

The graphics have vastly improved to appear more realistic as if you're watching a live-action Asian drama show. However, I cannot say the same for the physics since every time someone gets knocked down, their ragdoll bodies fly across the street as if they were on an ice rink.

The [b]only[/b] issue I have with Kiwami 2 is the COMBAT and this is coming from a guy who has played Yakuza 0 & Kiwami 1, so I'm still getting used to the new engine. 

Now I really dislike the removal of styles for Kiryu that were present in the previous aforementioned games, you are basically stuck with the heavily improved dragon style. The dragon style ain't bad, they added stuff to make it more viable such as charged attacks that stun, but it's not as bad as using Rush style to juggle enemies then using Beast to destroy them with a bike. It also pisses me off how once an enemy blocks, your entire combo just drops.

Overall, this game is pretty solid but if you were playing from 0 or Kiwami 1, it's gonna be a lil bit tough transitioning.

The graphics, the gameplay, the story, all really good.
There was a new engine in place for this that carried through 6 and 7 as well from what I know, known as the "Dragon Engine". To think, Ryu Ga Gotoku Studios built a whole new engine from the ground up, and now it makes the game look so smooth and beautiful. Absolute props to them for it, I think it looks much better than 0 and Kiwami, even though those games still look pretty good themselves. And they made it so most buildings don't need a loading screen anymore! Just enter the door of it, you're still in the same load session. 

The gameplay is a step up from it's predecessors, with what feels like more movement. Ledges you can walk onto, already opening the map up at least a bit. Railings you can vault over, and even some points, THERE ARE BUILDINGS YOU COULD JUMP OFF OF AND MAKE A SWIFT LANDING. (unless you're running) I spent at least 3 hours just running into street obstacles to knock them over such as signs, bikes, benches and people. (The people were in my way! I had no other choice!) The combat is more fleshed out than that of the previous games too, with charged attacks and some timing tweaks. (It feels like that to me, at least.) And you can also enter the aforementioned buildings (from the last section) and fight in those buildings. Did you know there's an achievement for that? (I won't elaborate, just do some testing for it!)

The story is... well, I can only say it's really well written. I don't want to elaborate on this one either, as the story is a big part of the game. 

Therefore, all I can say is to take my word for it and try it yourself! If it isn't your cup of tea, then that's fair. Then again, this is all just an opinion review, so if you're taking my word for it, get a bit of salt along with it. (As in: take it with a grain of salt)

But yes, this game is good.

My god this game is good, I love Ryuji Goda and Kiryu's dynamic. Combat is very fluid once you figure it out and invest time into acquiring good stats and skills. Some fights such as Man in Black are rough against newcomers, but should pose no threat after correctly surmising the appropriate way to fight. The revert from 4 styles to Kiryu's original Dragon of Dojima style was a bold move, but very well done. The story is markedly better than Kiwami 1 while the combat has an amazing amount of polish compared to Kiwami 1. The new Dragon game engine makes everything seem crisp and vibrant while attaining a new level of realism (but ragdolls fucking suck ass). I highly recommend this to Yakuza fans, but please don't skip Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1.

Amazing.

SEGA got rid of Yakuza 0's combat and replaced it with a more sluggish and physics-based system. Thus, battle styles (Brawler, Rush and Beast) are gone; it's Dragon or nothing.

Because of the new physics, Kiryu constantly ragdolls and flies around the place. In this game, you have to wait for him to get up and recover on his own. You can't mash buttons to get up quicker like you were able to in previous entries. The result is several boring seconds of doing nothing and just watching Kiryu having a seizure on the floor or something.

Most actions are mapped to different keys now, for better or worse. RIP, all the muscle memory I've acquired from playing Yakuza 0 and Yakuza Kiwami.

As for crashes, the game did so for me approximately every 5-30 minutes. I suppose this is the price for playing a SEGA game on PC, huh?

On an ending note, I'd like to mention the story and graphics are good, though.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Once again return to Kamurocho & Sotenbori, now featuring the new "Dragon Engine", visual representation and environmental textures are vastly more detailed than Y0 & YK
    [*]Very interesting story that focuses on the internal politics of the Yakuza
    [*]Majima Saga acts as a interlude to Kiwami 2's events, which take place briefly after the events of Kiwami; gives player's the option to play as Majima once again and also gives closure on a certain Y0 story
    [*]The open world has been expanded upon drastically, entering and exiting buildings is seamless without loading screens or downtime; this makes exploration, hidden items, and the completion list extremely intuitive
    [*]Physics, albeit hilariously unbalanced; makes weapons and charged attacks feel a lot more impactful
    [*]Very different but a more straightforward combat system, with the removal of Kiryu's battle styles (brawler, rush, beast), Kiwami 2 focuses around constant weapon switching and storing
    [*]Completion List & substories, many new distractions await you in 2006 Kamurocho & Sotenbori; new minigames & systems are always welcomed, substories are noticeably shorter than the previous games
    [*]Climax Battles have been phased out, instead there are 2 main side activities that have their own sub-plots developing that Kiryu can partake in
    [*][b]Daigo {Best Man}[/b]
[/list]
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
    [*]UFO Catcher has objectively become more scam than Mahjong
    [*]Personally, combat doesn't feel as imapctful as it did in Y0 & YK
    [*]Street thugs have such small HP bars that its almost impossible to determine if they have full HP or are near death
    [*]The guy in Mahjong that calls "Riichi" on the first discard and "Ron" on the second discard (Part 3 With New Animations)
[/list]

Other than those two things, it's still a great game. I'd get it if you are playing through the games in order, but if you are planning on just getting one game, I'd get Yakuza 0 instead.

If you're this many games into Yakuza you know what you're getting - it's compelling storytelling about family and duty with a wide variety of side activities and a dash of absurdity. The fighting is just a little bit dated/janky but everything else is top notch.

If steam had a "you might like it and you might not" neutral option, that is what I would give this, but due to my last few hours experience, i'm leaning towards negative as that's all steam allows.

Side stories are still a lot of fun. I was addicted to the cabaret side quest for a long while, but overall there are a lot of backward steps from Kiwami 1 in my opinion. 

The main story starts off really well, but then eventually descends into this nonsensical conga line of "IM A JINGWON SURVIVOR TOO!!! MWA HA HA!". It gets so bad that I just stopped caring about the story, because it was obvious they were just throwing out twist after twist just for kicks.

One of the main characters, Sayama, who is supposed to be this badass cop, just turns into another cliche tsundere who just wants to be loved. I had to start skipping cutscenes with her in them because she never actually said anything relevant to the plot. I watched the cutscenes on youtube at a faster speed to make sure i understood the story, that's how awful it got. 

The combat was a step down from Kiwami across the board. ridiculous rag dolling, bosses that all had hyper armor, heat actions that were very finicky.

The graphics engine is obviously new and needed more time to work out the optimization.

Overall, I was disappointed with the game and had to force myself to finish it. My suggestion would be to watch the story on youtube, and play for the sidequests, and make sure you buy this on sale.

[h1] Yakuza Kiwami 2 features the new Engine of yakuza game and its amazing. [/h1]

I did not love Yakuza Kiwami 1 as much as Yakuza 0 because most of it is just recycled content from the previous game But Yakuza Kiwami 2 Brought me back into  that YAKUZA FEEL. Yakuza Kiwami 2 had so many improvements and changes from making the city more immersive by it looks, populated and BEING ABLE TO GO INSIDE STORES!, The Graphics is really good that makes it walking in the Kamurocho and Sotenbori in first person relaxing. They also shifted the New Combat system from 4 fighting styles to only 1, but it's not a downgrade because combat is still amazing. The Heat actions are also Cool and blood pumping specially when kiryu is fighting a Boss or Ryuji, I really love Ryuji. 

There is 2 stories, the main and the Majima saga but Majima saga is just a short side story. The story starts fairly slow but never boring, Characters are detailed both looks and their personality and the plot is good and delivered well but i'm kinda disappointed in the last chapter. The battles and bosses are great (except for that knife boots dude), Ryuji's first fight is amazing and the second got quite boring because I maxed my stats and got too prepared before ending the story. Side stories in the other hand are quite fun and others are unique I tried completing them except for the majong ones. 

Of course not all games are perfect, The combat of the game feels slow and kinda grindy at the beginning. Less combos, heat actions and you really need tons of money to EAT FOOD to gain stats. And that eating to gain stat mechanic, It's not bad but the way of gaining is really dumb in my opinion. restaurant had different dishes that also differ in stats and some shops/resto's has Trash food. lastly, Majima Saga is REALLY short story, it only has 5 chapters and I didnt like the combat of majima. You can gift kiryu to help you in the main story but I did Majima saga after I finished the story soooo, dunno. Majima Feels slow and your arsenal of combos/heat actions are really limited and you can't gain more. I think those "Boss" thugs in the street with skull should give you new combos instead rather than money for kiryu. 

But Overall I'd give Yakuza Kiwami 2 a 8/10.

The stores were open and there were no loading screens to enter most buildings. The menus were better and the game in general was a massive improvement. The cut scenes were really well done too, this series is basically an interactive movie. The devs and writers for this should feel very proud, they latch you in despite some of the problems with the mechanics. 

There were a few problems I faced like the mf with knife in his boot. Tell me why he was harder to fight than the last boss. That dude is op as fuck. He dodges everything, blocks everything and will perform the same combos back to back giving 1 shot to hit him. However I figured out how to beat him without being super cheesy and just using heat actions or weapons like a lot of people say to do. Just try to block most of what you can, use heal items and just press triangle to kick him when you get the chances. That and grabbing him and knocking him down were the best ways. People here will tell you to just quickstep, parry and all that but it's unrealistic unless you're just a god at combat. For casual players you gotta be somewhat cheesy. The other problem I would say is lack of funds. I was a broke mf and just like the last game you can't earn bank by beating everyone up like Yakuza 0, you do earn some money as enemies drop them but it's nothing like 0. But thats why you have the club to run and gold plates to sell n shit. 

As I make my way through this series I'm worried about the next 3 remastered games as I'm aware they aren't full remakes like the Kiwami bunch. But I'm still going to finish they to see what happens next. I want to see where Kaoru, Kiyru and Haruka go if they're even apart of the next chapter to this story. 

(edit): I have just learned that they totally ditched Kaoru for the rest of the series. What a fucking shame. I'm heartbroken because I felt like that was a good reason for Kiryu to fight for. His new family. I didn't like Kaoru in the beginning but she grew on me later in the game and I felt that chemistry between the two. I'm quite annoyed with that decision of completely making her useless in the story now. Like what was really the point of her anyways if you just leave her out forever? If that was the plan in the first place then they could've ended the series there. I get why they didn't continue that relationship, for gameplay reasons with the bars and shit but damn at least have her return for Yakuza 6. I've read a bit about that final ending but nothing to spoil me. I'm a little worried now that the story starts to miss its mark in the next 4 games. I'm sure it will still be great but I don't expect it to match 0, Kiwami 1 and 2. This part doesn't sit well me knowing she's gone in Y3. But I'll be finishing the series despite all this hoping there's more to feed off of and that it ain't that bad. 

I'd also like to say that this is one of those stories that you just don't want to end, it reminds me of my Cyberpunk 2077 ending. I didn't want it to end because I enjoyed it so much and it sucks that it does end. If Yakuza was an endless story, I would play it until I couldn't no more. Idky or how I got this attached, because tbh I only watched 1 video about this series and decided to jump in blindly and now I've got myself addicted to all this. Which means it's gonna hurt more when I begin to finish the Kiryu saga. I did read that they're making a movie, hopefully they include everything abt this story and make it worth it. 

Once again this series amazes me each time, idk how this series is so underrated. It's the best experience I've had in long time when it comes to games and entertainment In general. I recommend this to anyone who loves a rich story, open and living world to explore with awesome combat. I've sunk 120 hours into this series so far and I plan on dropping more soon.

This is more of a general recommendation for all the Yakuza games since this is the first one I have on PC and can write a Steam review for, but the Yakuza games are fantastic experiences that I highly recommend. You play as Kiryu, a (in this game) former Yakuza, which is a term for the Japanese organized crime syndicates. The main story is a thrilling tale of drama, intrigue, and immense amounts of violence. The side stories are zany tales full of comedy, culture, and immense amounts of violence. The game mostly consists of roaming around one of two city areas at a time, doing various tasks to progress the plot of the story and get roped into side stories where Kiryu meets various characters that live in the city or experiences any of the activities available. Many compare the game to either GTA or Shenmue, and it's probably closer to the latter than to GTA. You do various side activities in the form of minigames or are simply put in the vicinity of their location so that you know where to go to play them later, and while the story revolves around crime, Kiryu is an upstanding guy despite being a former yakuza that he doesn't do anything actually... bad. Not intentionally anyway. The only time when you can think of him as doing illegal activity really is when any of the randomly generated thugs, delinquents, ruffians, etc. accost you in the street forcing you to fight them. And that's a player choice more often than not, as you can choose to, instead of simply punching and kicking them to submission, shoot them or stab them or swing various sign posts, metal poles, or other debris into their skulls. But even then, you supposedly "aren't killing" them since that's not Kiryu's way. 

But this all adds to the charm, really. It's very obviously a video game world, but the characters are super serious during main story beats which doesn't really detract from them. One second you can be sitting around with a few characters waiting on news from the surgery a friend of Kiryu's is having from a bullet wound he suffered, the next moment Kiryu can be running down to a discount store for a pair of underwear to hand off to a guy who crapped his pants a few days ago and refuses to leave his toilet stall until he has a fresh pair. Or gets wrapped up in disciplining a yakuza boss that's forcing his "infantilism" fetish on his subordinates. Or just playing Mahjong for several hours at a time. But these moments of side stories flesh out the world to give the city much more life than most other locations I can think of in video games. It gives Kiryu more of a personality too in a relatively unobtrusive way. Like, the guy is this big scary looking gangster that will very easily drop everything else he's doing to do Pocket Circuit racing against some literal children, and spend millions of yen just to make his strong enough to beat the kids' cars. But it feels believable because he isn't contradicting himself. And the sheer amount of stuff you can do in this game is astounding. There's fully fleshed out mechanics to play mahjong, shogi, minigames for batting cages, darts, black jack, a tower defense minigame, hell you can literally go down to an arcade in the game and just play Virtua Fighter. There's so much to do and so much you can experience that it's kind of crazy. I do have a few complaints though that are more specific to this one.

Firstly, it seems a little bit buggier, and I'm not sure if that's because this is a PC port or if Kiwami 2 is just a bit buggier than the other ones I've played, but Kiryuu has had some buggy-ness around objects in the environment moving him around a good bit on occasion, basically launching him a tiny distance if he stands on something wrong. This is the only bug I'm aware of though, which isn't bad by any means but worth noting that I didn't encounter a single bug in any other Yakuza game I played, all of which have been on PS4. The second thing is the encounters. Now, I like the combat just fine, but it feels just a tad repetitive, especially since Kiryu can't walk a single block before someone tries to pick a fight with him. I think, in the future if there's a Kiwami 3, or for future installments in the series, there should be an item you get (probably lategame or after finishing the story) that you can wear as an accessory that either reduces or eliminates the random thugs spawning. The sheer amount you face just becomes tiring, and it makes me feel like I've fought off the entire population of Japan. Not to mention the combat, while easy to pick up and has a decent amount of depth to it, is simplified to a few buttons, one of which has two purposes for both heavy attacks and also for what are essentially super moves. So if you're trying to stay prepared for an upcoming story segment, you'll likely run into an encounter and use up some health from random punches hitting you as well as using up super meter on accident when trying to perform simple heavy attacks. 

At any rate, these are my only issues with the game, which are relatively minor issues, and everything else about it I could easily gush about, such as various locations in Kamurocho playing Kiryu's karaoke rendition of "Baka Mitai" in the background, or some of the dumb shennanigans that Kiryu gets himself into. If you're interested in the series, do yourself a favor and start playing it!

If you're playing through the Yakuza series via the remakes, Kiwami 2 is kind of a weird one. Whereas 0 and Kiwami feel more like a direct evolution of the franchise's previous entries, Kiwami 2 has an extremely apparent generational leap that brings a completely redesigned experience. There's some great changes to be found, but I think some interesting parts of the series have been abandoned in the process. Kiwami 2 is a really solid Yakuza game, but I can't help but wish it had brought a bit more to the table.

The most refined part of Kiwami 2 is the open world, and man it's amazing. You'll notice immediately how seamless the world feels, there are no longer any loading screens between buildings, which dramatically improves the pacing & immersion of the world. The cities also feel a bit more open in general, there are a number of passageways and interiors that were previously blocked off that incentive exploration and just makes navigation more fun. Yakuza's always prioritised density over size in it's worlds and it's especially commendable here. I enjoyed finding pathways that lead to rooftops most, to take in the splendid sights. Kiwami 2 looks excellent, the environments and characters have so much detail jam packed into them & it's pretty amazing how well it ran on my fairly outdated rig, it feels pretty optimised. The content that fills the world is solid too, aside the numerous returning minigames which have always provided the series with a lot of diversity, you also have a load of fun substories that break up the action really well. My only complaint in this department is that Kiwami 2 doesn't really have any unique selling point for it's world. Both business games are reused from Yakuza 0 & 6 (I'm also not a huge fan of either), there's almost no new minigames and the substories, while still excellent, don't really bring anything new to the table. I know it's a remake, but considering they were willing to add massive amounts of content that wasn't in the original, it would've been nice if it was a bit more unique. They've also removed the city of Shinseicho, which isn't a huge deal since it was very small, but it's unfortunate to not see that area with all the benefits of the modern dragon engine. Kiwami 2 doesn't bring any big new element to the table, but the quality of life mostly makes up for it, leading to great interpretations of Kamurocho and Sotenbori worth exploring.

Combats received a huge redesign in Yakuza 6, and they've brought that back to Kiwami 2. This redesign always confused me, it's not different enough to make the experience innovative, but it changes just enough to bug me. Kiryu's fighting style is completely different here, you still rely on light and heavy attacks, but it's replaced that fast and arcadey feel with a more realistic brawler. Combat does feel fresh by how it takes advantage of the city, now that you can enter any building mid-fight or even just run away through the streets. The animations are greatly improved too, Kiryu's attacks all flow into one another, the ragdoll on enemies is hilarious and heat looks better than ever. By all means, it's still a lot of fun, tackling groups of enemies still feels satisfying, it just lacks the strategy of the previous games. Kiryu's moves lack meaning now that you can just kind of spam your way through fights, his leg sweep is the only combo that has any specific use (as a guard break) compared to the older games, where each of Kiryu's attacks provided differing outcomes. It also kind of ruins the storytelling of Kiryu's move set, evolving from it's unrefined styles in 0 to the complete Dragon style that he uses in the later entries, now he just fights completely differently for a single entry and it's rather odd if you then go to Yakuza 3. Combat's absolutely at it's best with larger groups of enemies, it's a lot of fun to plough through enemy hoards, but those 1 on 1 engagements really show how the old system excelled in comparison. I also think the upgrade system here is just, kind of bad. Most of your exp comes from food and miscellaneous challenges now, I can see what they were going for and I appreciate how open the upgrade tree is that you can go for specific abilities instantly, but It just becomes annoying to try and unlock some of the later moves. Kiwami 2's combat is still expertly crafted and stands out well, I just found it to be lacking in comparison to other entries in the series.

I think the biggest thing Yakuza 2 did for the series is expand the Yakuza world, due to it's story. Whereas the first game felt like Kiryu's story with a Yakuza backdrop, I really like how this game can blend those two worlds together really well. Introducing Sotenbori and The Omi Alliance immediately makes for some gripping stakes, the goals of the narrative are immediately clear and the intrigue is only further enhanced by uncovering the mysterious Jingweon Mafia. The amount of characters that return from the first game makes the world still feel active without your intervention, and I love how the events of Kiwami 1 are still extremely important here, Kiryu is both a loved and hated figure after the first game and it's just awesome to see you actually having an in-universe reputation from your actions. I'd say the majority of the narrative is really engaging and exciting, it still has mild pacing issues and some filler, but I was really invested  throughout. That's why it's particularly disappointing to say that I just cannot stand the ending of this game. To me, Yakuza has a pattern of a reliance on plot twists and lack of pay off, and it's particularly strong here. Without going into detail of the events, I just found the ending did an awful job at delivering on the awesome build up throughout Kiwami 2, and it left a real sour taste in my mouth. There's also just some really bizarre character moments I hated. It's a weird position, cause the narrative feels so good throughout and the bosses still stand out, but a lot of the positives of the story relate very closely to that lacking conclusion, it makes me kind of unsure as to what my final thoughts are on the narrative as a whole. Also, the "Majima Saga" included with this game is very lacking to say the least, I don't think it needed to be included at all. Its just an hour or 2 of generic fights, uninteresting plot & a small amount of fan service, I'd highly recommend skipping that endeavour. While I think the story doesn't quite stick the landing, Kiwami 2 still excels in expanding on the franchise's history and sets a great foundation for future titles.

[h1]Definitely a masterpiece![/h1]
In my mind, [i]Yakuza Kiwami 2[/i] can be ranked in the top three in the [i]Yakuza[/i] series. The remaining two of the top three should be [i]Yakuza 0[/i] and [i]Yakuza:Like a Dragon[/i]. But anyway, I fall in deep love with entire [i]Yakuza[/i] series.

As a game remade in 2018, [i]Yakuza Kiwami 2[/i] has superb and beautiful graphics and has improved a lot of physical details compared to the previous ones. At the same time, the optimization of the game is still so great. There is no low frame rate or dropped frames in the game. The game uses the same brand new Dragon Engine as [i]Yakuza 6[/i]. Overall, it was a  successful remake.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Due to the use of the new Dragon Engine, many aspects of the game have changed a lot. The map of the game is much more detailed, making it more convenient and intuitive for players to watch. The depiction of Tokyo and Osaka is also more detailed and lifelike. I can't help but linger in these two cities. In addition, there are also cars that are moving on the streets, which are closer to reality. More user-friendly is that more taxi service locations have been added to the city, saving a lot of time. The buildings in the city also have more places to walk, making the players more free to play.
The battle system of the game has also changed a lot. When you play [I]YK2[/i] after playing [i]Y0[/i] and [i]YK1[/i], you may be more or less uncomfortable. This game cancels the previous setting of the four combat styles, and instead only has a fixed, more comprehensive combat style. Intuitively, the sense of striking feeling is indeed reduced a lot. But the battle is surprisingly easier compared to the previous games. Especially in boss battles, your normal attacks will cause more damage, and extreme skills or Heat Moves are easier to trigger.For me,in the last boss battle with Ryuji Goda,I take medicines and constantly use Heat Moves to beat him out. The previous boss fight has never been easier than this time. 
[i]YK2[/i] also follows the great traditions of the previous games, retaining a large number of minigames, which increases the playability of the game.I really love this lifelike city in [i]Yakuza[/i].

[h1]Plot[/h1]
I consider [i]YK2[/i] has the same brilliant plot as [i]Y0[/i]. [i]YK2[/i] lets me relive the excitement and warmth when I was playing [i]Y0[/i].All in all, [spoiler]a year after leaving his former life in the Tojo Clan behind, ex-yakuza Kazuma Kiryu is called back into action when the clan's Fifth Chairman, Yukio Terada, is murdered by assassins from a rival organization, the Omi Alliance. Returning to Kamurocho, Kiryu must find a new chairman for the Tojo Clan and prevent an all-out war between the Tojo and the Omi, bringing him into conflict with Ryuji Goda, the legendary "Dragon Of Kansai" of the Omi Alliance.[/spoiler] The ups and downs and infinite reversal of the plot really made me addicted, as if I was in it. This work also has a deeper portrayal of the main characters, especially for the new comers, Daigo Dojima, Kaoru Syama and Ryuji Goda. 
This work also has ulterior motives in the portrayal of family and love. In addition to the desperate kiss of Kiryu and Sayama before death, what impressed me the most was the night when the two played in Osaka. The good time was The difficulties and obstacles that followed laid the groundwork for them, and the difficulties and obstacles that followed in turn reflected the sincere feelings revealed this evening.
The most unforgettable thing for me was the spirit of the gunshot wounded Kiryu and Goda in the final battle. It can be said that it shocked me deeply. The poignant BGM during the battle further enhanced the tragic atmosphere. I was holding back my tears to get it through.  He has gone through so many conspiracies and betrayals along the way, and eventually met a frank and righteous opponent Ryuji Goda. This may be the best ending for two of them. Ryuji Goda is absolutely a very charming villain.

[h1]What impresses me most[/h1]
Actually I didn't expect there would be a Majima Saga Plot.It really really surprises me. It's very coincidental and interesting that [spoiler]Majima receives service from a woman named Tateyama, who turns out to be Makoto Makimura, who Majima saved from the Tojo Clan 18 years prior. Majima, while attempting to hide his identity, learns that Makoto still kept her old watch as a memento of her savior. Some time later, Makoto leaves the country with her family; she receives an anonymous gift prior to her departure, which turns out to be a replacement strap for her watch. Realizing that her customer that day was also her savior 18 years ago, Makoto finally finds comfort knowing she has no regrets leaving Japan.[/spoiler]I was crying when I saw this happy ending between them. What can be more emotional than this?How romantic Majima is!

As someone who is going through the Yakuza series in chronological story order, Kiwami 2 was a completely different experience from the first time I was given control of Kiryu, the change of engine is immediately noticeable and I came to realize why exactly this game required so much more spec-wise compared to K1. This time around the combat system changes from separate battle styles, to a single one that has sprinkles of the previous ones, it took me a while to get used to (after 0 and K1 were so similar at their core) but it's really enjoyable. The PC version seems to have wacky physics (from what I understand this doesn't happen on the original console release), but they are not annoying, the're quite hilarious at times.
The fact that the entire town is present at all times with seaming-less transitions in between battle, roaming and even entering shops, makes Kamurocho feel more alive than ever.
Besides the main story line, K2 has not one but two side businesses, similar to 0 though this time both managed by Kiryu, the Cabaret Club feels just as great it did in 0, and it includes some new changes like skills the hostesses can posses. On the other hand, there is also a "tower defense" like mode in Clan Creator, where you need to strategize the position of your worker units to protect your equipment. Both modes come with their own storyline to immerse yourself more in the world and provide as side activities you can do while taking a rest from the main story.
Overall I enjoyed the game a lot, I don't have many noticeable bad experiences with it, besides the fact that one minigame is completely broken and unplayable in this version, and the solution is to either apply a fan patch or change the game to run at 30 fps manually. But besides this its a great experience to continue off from the past 2 games in the chronology.

[h1]"Finally, Virtua On and Virtua Fighter on PC. Also included: Yakuza Kiwami 2"[/h1]

I‚Äôm going to talk about some mundane technical stuff for a while. By doing this, I can trick people into thinking that this review isn‚Äôt going to veer hard into sheer weirdness later on.

Yakuza 2 is a 2008 PS2 explorative brawler that, quite secretly, was kind of excellent. It‚Äôs the continuing tale of Kazuma Kiryu, a former Yakuza member trying to make a go of it as a civilian. He‚Äôs really bad at it. Turns out his prior employers, The Tojo Clan, are having major issues with a rival faction, the Omni Alliance, and have genuine fears of being assimilated. After the events from the previous game, they‚Äôre drastically short of manpower, so are forced to turn to Kiryu. In an attempt to avoid outright war between the two factions, he agrees to go on a diplomatic mission, visiting the Omni to try and barter peace. To his surprise, the senior members of the alliance seem pretty receptive to the whole idea. Everything seems to be going well. Until it isn‚Äôt.

Most of the blame can be placed on Ryuji Goda, the impatient patriarch of an upstart Omni splinter clan spoiling for conflict. Ryuji‚Äôs this massive hulk of a man, always seemingly on the verge of losing his shit and battering everything in sight. But writing him off as a brainless lug would be a mistake; it‚Äôs his careful scheming that continues to snatch away any hope of the peace talks succeeding. He steals scenes by sheer presence. He‚Äôs a rumbling volcano of an antagonist you‚Äôre always expecting to explode, but contradicts this with an air of intelligence that makes him all the more chilling. He wants a war. If anyone can get one, it‚Äôs him.

This was all very well received, with a lot of series veterans ranking Ryuji as the best foil the series has yet to produce. But more people should have been part of this discussion; Despite being critically acclaimed at every step and having a loyal, vocal fanbase Yakuza never graduated any further than an underground hit outside of Japan. Then Yakuza 0 happened and everyone finally piled on the bandwagon. And they were very, very happy to find there was this whopping back catalogue of games to work through, giving SEGA the luxurious problem that there was a massive spike of interest in their old games. The speed bump was that the early, early entries were three console generations removed, but they had to find their way onto the market somehow. SEGA could have taken the easy route, shined their archaic software up as best they could and released them as HD remasters (as they would for most of the series) but they went above and beyond for the most venerable games. Yakuza 1 & 2 became Yakuza Kiwami 1 & 2, both rebuilt from the ground up using the new engine developed initially for Yakuza 6. And there was much rejoicing.

This is probably going to end up being a long review already, so I‚Äôll try and save us both some effort and tell you that the Kiwamis make a ridiculous amount of quality of life changes, transforming brilliant games ravaged by time into brilliant games that take advantage of modern advancements. It was a stroke of genius from the giant brains over at SEGA, meaning that people could transition from the series prequel, Yakuza 0, straight into the established canon without a massive quality drop. People making the trip to Yakuza Kiwami found themselves playing a faithful adaptation of the original game with all the bluster and sheen found in Zero. Good times were had. And then Kiwami 2 blew it away.

It‚Äôs the bigger game, for one, but it also had more extras implemented. It adopted the cabaret manager side quest from Zero and the RTS clan creator from Six. There‚Äôs three unlockable chapters for lovable psychopath, Goro Majima, explaining what he‚Äôs been up to between games, and even tying back to his origins in Zero. Where perhaps it noticeably falters in comparison is that, rather than adopt the same combat system as Zero and the first Kiwami, which gave you multiple fighting stances you can cycle through mid-combat, it instead refines Six‚Äôs single-style combat, but with a renewed interest in heat actions. These are high-powered attacks that momentarily pause combat to allow Kiryu to do something unspeakable to his opponents. Like ruthlessly batter them with a traffic cone. Or stab them in the belly before driving the knife even further in with a sadistic knee lift. Or throwing them groin-first into a nearby pylon. Or casually dropping them onto an already downed thug. Or, and this one really sucks, being lobbed a used plunger from a friendly toilet attendant, suction cupping someone‚Äôs face with it, then using it to repeatedly mash the back of their head into the floor. You‚Äôll eventually pry the plunger free from your victim‚Äôs face, complete with a splattering of the urinal water that was trapped within.

After being somewhat disappointed with Yakuza Kiwami, booting up and playing Yakuza Kiwami 2 is like getting a shot of adrenaline pumped into the veins. This review is hot off completing Yakuza Kiwami 2 to completion, so this will be much fresher than my previous two reviews. As I had much more enjoyment with this one than Kiwami, it should hopefully be a shorter review akin to my 0 review. 

Yakuza Kiwami 2 truly earns the Kiwami moniker, with a bomb going off in the Millenium Tower setting the stage for the epic feud between East and West that lies ahead. Kazuma Kiryu is once again enthralled into the Tojo Clan's affairs after leaving it behind in the last game, and his adventure is one hell of a ride. Kiwami 2 has a great story that matches the intensity and emotion of 0's, and it's easy to see why I liked 0's story so much when this story existed well before that game. Not only does this game give some pretty memorable sequences, it also has a memorable villain to boot, after coming off of Kiwami's disappointing final villain, it is truly a breath of fresh air. Kiwami 2's story is how you build upon an alright first game to great effect. While not quite as grounded as Kiwami's story, I don't see that as an entirely bad thing. I recommend getting the music patch as some of the original songs weren't licensed and some scenes lose their effect due to this change.

New to the Kiwami edition is the Majima Saga as well, though it should be renamed Majima's Side Story, as it is fairly short and only offers a glimpse as to how Majima got to where he is in the story. Though it is short and the effects of it are negligible at best, it does have you meet up with a certain someone again, and that makes it worth playing if you were gripped by Majima's narrative in 0.

Kiwami 2 runs off the Dragon Engine, and it is a sight to behold. While the uncapped framerates makes the ragdolls look more comedic than realistic, the game looks and runs pretty alright on my mid-tier machine. Certain minigames were cut and the variety isn't as vast as 0, this means you'd have an easier time doing the completion list for the minigames, at least. Some minigames have been made drastically easier (darts), while some prove to be a bit challenging (getting 30 mahjong wins is a tedium that's not appreciated). In order to do the Toylets minigame though, consider getting the SilentPatch to make it playable above 30 FPS.

Kiwami 2 sees the return of the best 0 minigame, Cabaret Club, as Kiryu is basically doing what Majima did in the 80's again. While it feels derivative at times in the story and accompanying substories, it's helped by still being at it's core, the Cabaret Club. If you loved it as much as I did, this will be a treat for you. New to the Kiwami rendition is also Clan Creator, which is a tower defense-ish minigame where you command Majima's construction crew to fend off against realtors and goons who want to take over the Kamurocho Hills project. This proves to be an alright minigame, though the final mission sees a great spike in difficulty if not prepared. There is a DLC that gives you really good characters, and I did that so I cannot confirm for non-DLC characters, but I believe it's doable as there is a wide range of characters to recruit into singing Majima Construction's theme.

Kiwami 2 is also home to some of the most legendary substories, perhaps in all of the Yakuza games up until this point. Kiwami suffered from having a lot of repetitive substories that involved people trying to scam Kiryu continuously, but it did have substories that pertained to the main plot. The substories here are of the quality of 0's, meaning most of them are fairly memorable and fun to do. You won't be disappointed in this department.

Combat is quite different from the games that preceded it. It's oddly weighty and you can't break enemy blocks anymore. While this is pretty annoying being constantly stopped mid-combo, the combat is still good enough to have enjoyment out of this one. It is probably the easiest game in the series as of late, especially with the help of the Weapon Master skill, which allows you to max out the durability of a weapon as long as it isn't broken. This basically gives you infinite durability (as long as you keep swapping or removing them before they break) until you are able to purchase the infinite durability weapons in Premium Adventure. Playing on Legend also doesn't make the QTEs faster, most likely because if you fail a boss QTE, you have to restart again (I know from experience doing the last section on Legend, real embarrassing).

Climax Battles are replaced with Bouncer missions, and if you bought the DLC that gave you some better weapons at the start, also with the help of the Weapon Master skill, it becomes fun in the earlier sections and more doable as you near the end. I much prefer this to doing pre-set missions with certain parameters, as you have access to your gear and weapons in the Bouncer missions, making them more fun to do even if there are a lot of them to do.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is probably some of the best fun I've had since 0. Kiwami in retrospect, is a necessary stepping stone to really enjoy Kiwami 2, and that is all the more worth it to experience one of the highs of the Yakuza series as of playing the series. While going into Yakuza 3 will need a lot of getting used to, this truly is the better of the 2 Yakuza games to have gotten the Kiwami treatment. A terrific continuation of the Dragon of Dojima's story, and some of his most defining moments are seen in this one. Don't miss it.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 fixes most of the issues i had with the first game. There are definitely a lot of quality of life improvements which were much needed like more storage as well as the stacking of items. The experience system on the other hand seemed it was made more complicated for no apparent reason . The simple completion point system of the first game was vastly superior in my opinion. The story is really good with plenty twists and turns. The visuals have been improved drastically since the first remake , at first i could not recognize the city of Kamurocho since it looked exceedingly better than it did in the first game. They also have added another playable city named Sotenbori which is much smaller in size to Kamurocho but definitely adds much needed freshness to the game. The fighting system has also been simplified with only one style instead of the four in the previous game which was for the better as i see it. The side content has also been considerably improved with more engaging side quests and unique characters. There is also a separate 2 hour campaign where you play as Majima (unlocked by completing the main campaign) which is really fun as Majimas fighting style is much different from Kazuma's. But the main draw of this game which made me sink considerable hours into just one single playthrough were the Majima Construction and Hostess Club management minigames. They were really well made with a lot of thought put into it even though they were completely optional. People who like basic management style games will definitely love this. I highly recommend playing this game to even to the people who were a bit disappointed by the first remake because for my money this fixes all of the issues of the previous game.
