As a newcomer to Yakuza, I was pretty blown away by this game. It looks amazing and the new combat is really fun (especially with the ragdolls). I really enjoyed the characters and I felt like this game was on par with Yakuza 0, which is one of my favourite games of all time.

Dude where do I even start with this one. Yakuza Kiwami 2 is my favourite Yakuza game yet and the best Yakuza game I have played.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 has such an incredibly strong story it's ridiculous. Ryuji Goda is the best antagonist of any Yakuza game I have played so far (those being Y0, YK and YK2), he has so much presence and absolutely steals every scene he's in. His motivation for specifically fighting Kiryu is kinda weak but I don't care, Ryuji is probably one of my top 3 favourite Yakuza characters. Kaoru Sayama is a fantastic foil to Kiryu and her place in the story is super well written. Fuck, dude, this game's plot is so fucking good it's worth playing it just for that.

The new engine is also amazing. The game looks incredible, the most major gripe I have with the engine that Y0 and YK run on is that everything looks kinda like plastic but Kiwami 2's engine looks great. The new engine has also totally switched up how the combat works. Yakuza Kiwami 2 has had the best combat of the games I've played so far. 0 and Kiwami 1 all had moments where I got frustrated with the combat but that never happened in Kiwami 2. Grabbing a dude twice Kiryu's weight, spinning him in a circle and then tossing him into 4 other guys will never not be fun. If I have a complaint, it's the removal of the multiple fighting styles. 0 and Kiwami 1 let you switch between 3 fighting styles whereas this game combines them all into one, sort of how the Dragon style from Kiwami 1 worked except much smoother. It's by no means a bad system and, like I said, it's really fun to kick people's asses with it but it does make combat feel somewhat more repetitive since youre invariably throwing out the same combos and heat moves against every enemy. The way Kiryu moves also makes combat feel a bit floaty and less grounded than it did in Y0 and Kiwami. Again though these are very minor complaints, I absolutely loved Kiwami 2's combat.

In terms of side content, Kiwami 2 knocks it out of the park. The substories are all so much fun to play (dont play the Be My Baby substory, worst mistake of my life), there are entirely separate games contained within the in-game arcades, like Virtua Fighter, which are addicting in their own right. Hell, there's an entire RTS game in here disguised as a construction company run by a shirtless man with an eyepatch. What the fuck. There's also a B-story, the Majima Saga, that you can play once you've beaten the main game. It's very short, only 3 chapters long, but it still serves you your Majima fix and acts as both a nice prologue to this game and a good epilogue to Yakuza 0. Everything about Yakuza Kiwami 2 earns it that ¬£25 price tag (the second highest in the franchise, behind Like a Dragon which costs ¬£50). One of my absolute favourite games of all time.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 was a pleasant surprise.
The story of the Dragon of Dojima continues in this extremely faithful remake of the PS2 original, as he finds himself dealing with the threat of the Omi Alliance's Ryuji Goda and a broken, messed up Tojo Clan that desperately needs the help of a legendary Yakuza. 
How will Kiryu face the challenges ahead and deal with the hardships of a potential new clan war? By beating the shit out of everyone with his bare fists, bicycles, traffic cones and household items. Duh.

It's not like I had low expectations or anything (especially considering just how masterfully crafted each Yakuza game is) but man, I'd say it's among my favorites solely because of how it handled certain aspects.

First off, the game looks great. This was the first Yakuza game on PC to use the Dragon Engine (The one used for Yakuza 6, Judgment and Like a Dragon, just to be clear) and it shows. Both Kamurocho and Sotenbori are oozing with life, detail and colors and the game doesn't have the stupid 30 FPS lock that still plagues the console versions, even the recent Xbox port.

The soundtrack is pretty neat too. I don't think it's as good as 0 (Or hell, even Kiwami 1) but it has a lot of catchy tunes that perfectly fit each situation they're played in. "Outlaw's Lullaby", "Break Off" and "A Scattered Moment" are my personal favorites (Careful though, if you search the latter online you're bound to find a LOT of spoilers. Trust me, you'll like *that* in-game moment where the song plays a helluva lot more if you go blind).

Lastly, and I MUST talk about this since others rarely do that: pacing. My God. One of Yakuza's biggest issues (Even in some of its best chapters) is story pacing. There are many, many occasions in Yakuza 0, Kiwami 1 and Yakuza 5 where the story suddenly comes to a screeching halt just for the games to ask you to do mundane, boring stuff.

Not with Kiwami 2 though, the game keeps moving and moving and it doesn't let up.
From the moment you start the game until the very end, Kiwami 2 keeps things interesting and bombards you with unexpected twists, amazing characters, badass action and even major tearjerkers.

And the best part is that it never seems to lose its spark and interest, it never overdoes things.
It knows when to drop the big reveals and it knows when it's time for the player to kick back and relax.
The pacing in Kiwami 2 is legendary.

My only complaints are that the game is VERY easy and that the fighting mechanics were kinda downgraded when compared to 0 and Kiwami's four-style combat system. It's not BAD, mind you... But it kinda devolves into button mashing.
As long as you keep upgrading your stats regularly and buy, like, 5 health items before each major fight, you're gonna be fine and nothing will really "challenge" you.

Other than that, though? Not a lot to complain about. 
Yakuza Kiwami 2 does not reach perfection (then again, no game does that) but it's still a rock solid experience for old and new fans alike. I highly recommend this one.

This game was an absolute blast to play through! I personally preferred the combat in this game compared to 0 and Kiwami. The fighting in those games wasn't bad by any means, but K2's combat just feels more fluid to me. The lack of loading screens when you enter restaurants and stores is also a very welcome bonus. As per Yakuza tradition, there's lots of substories to dig into, and this game has a number of wacky and memorable ones.

I love the return of the Cabaret Club mini game. I spent an ungodly amount of time on that in 0, and I am happy to say that I have "As You Like" playing on loop in my head again after 3 years. On the other hand, Clan Creator was... okay for me? I'm not the best at tower defense games, but after getting used to the mechanics I could complete most of the stages in one try. My advice is to get one employee who's ability can repair equipment, one who can heal your fighters' HP. The other two abilities are up to you. Good luck with having the Majima Construction Anthem permanently drilled into your brain. 

Story-wise, I still feel this game pales in comparison to 0. I might just be biased because 0 was my first Yakuza game, but I just wasn't as emotionally invested in K2's main plot? I do like most of the characters (especially Yayoi and Daigo), and I think Ryuji is a cool and pretty intimidating antagonist. Kaoru is badass and I like her as well, but her romance with Kiryu feels a bit... rushed, in my opinion. It's only been a year since the events of Kiwami and I find it a little hard to believe that Kiryu would move on so quickly. But IDK, as someone with little interest in romance that might just be a me problem ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø 

(Not to mention how the devs chucked her away right off the bat in Y3 despite everything Kiryu and Kaoru went through in this game, which I find both hilarious and a little sad.)

Majima Saga though... hoo boy. I completed it within an hour but it was the most emotional I ever got while playing this game. It's a nice and satisfying conclusion to Majima and Makoto's story. I won't say anything more but yes, I cried. Just a little.

To sum everything up, I recommend this game wholeheartedly. I wouldn't pick up K2 as an entry point to this series, but it's a solid game with tons of stuff to do, fun combat, and a story with unexpected twists and turns. Definitely get this game if you're a fan of the Yakuza games.

After finishing Kiwami 1, I went straight to Kiwami 2 because spoiled myself with the graphics this one had. Now having done most of the sidequests (Except for the final sidequest), I'll put a review here,

The story picks up literally after Kiwami 1. Kiryu, the main character, can't catch a break and is pulled to the Yakuza world once again. The story is cheesy and melodramatic and overall enjoyable. To be honest, I'm not really a fan of overdramatic parts of the game (and also the plot twist), but overall this story is good and a fun ride. To bad we won't see a certain interesting character from this game in future releases.

Gameplay is the main strong point in this one. The newer Dragon Engine same as the one used in Yakuza 6 (haven't played that one) is used for this game. The physics although goofy are perfect satisfying to see. The combat now more resembles a bit of Sleeping Dogs (the game where I expected Yakuza to be) but has its own unique mechanics. Although the heat actions are a bit underwhelming at first (especially coming from Yakuza Zero and Kiwami), I watched to old Yakuza 2 game and realised the devs stayed close and faithful to the old game's heat actions so I'll give it a pass. 

Free roaming is fun. Kamurocho is detailed af with this engine. Although smaller in size compared to GTA and Assassins Creeds' worlds, the content is all over the place in every nooks and cranny. Theres also a second city to explore. 

All the sidequests and substories are fun except for the Majima Construction Arc. Ngl that arc is the last thing I did in this game and it is boring af. I'm not really a strategy type of person but even learning all the chracters, upgrading, and making formations and shit never really made it interesting. Its a good thing that it was a sidequest instead of a main one. The Cabaret Club Arc was fun tho.

Overall, very fun. 4/5

Edit: I don't know how I forget to mention the Majima Saga. That saga acts as a sidestory and takes place before the main plot. The Majima Saga really gave closure to Majima's character. Having not be a fan of the main story, this one atleast satisfied me. Yakuza 0 fans, this one should not be ignored.

Yakuza Kiwami 2,

is a beat-em-up game. You control Kiryu Kazuma through his life as a Yakuza.
You can roam around the city, to beat some thugs along the way, level up his skill, play minigame, earn some money, etc.

Game has a superb story, it is recommended that you play through the previous title, Yakuza Kiwami (and Yakuza 0 optionally, the prequel). Although you can get to play this title directly and do the "remember past events" on the start of the game to get the gist of the story before Yakuza Kiwami 2.

There are a lot of side events and minigames that you can do along the way if you want to complete the trophy, They are fun.

The main story takes me about 16 hours to complete, and the rest of the time i ended up messing around with the side quests and minigame. Those 16 hours of gameplay and story entertain me with hot-blooded action and fun.

I truly recommend getting this game. Get the Yakuza Pack for cheaper price, and better on discount, as you will want to complete the whole series as they are fun.

ps: prepare some tissues if you have weak heart

A truly next-gen Yakuza game.

This game is great, the map is absolutely breathtakingly beautiful, the story is top tier, everything is perfect really. Minigames are great or atleast better than previous games (FINALLY, MAHJONG TILES WITH NUMBERS ON!), and some stuff that is just mindblowing compared to the earlier games (walking into stores directly!)

You can ignore the below rant on combat.

However... honestly... when I first played this game I loved it, especially how it forced me to adapt to combat properly (I was overly reliant on dodging in Yakuza 0 + Kiwami, meaning I never blocked). After dumping another 120 hours in Yakuza 0 and replaying Kiwami to 100% completion on a new Legend save I genuinely felt like a true master of the combat system that could run circles around all opponents. Kiwami 2 honestly feels much worse in terms of combat.  People that play on KB+M no doubt will complain it feels floaty, hence why the game tells you "real yakuza use gamepad"- which couldn't be more important for this game particularly. To me though, the main issue with combat isn't the floatyness, its the unreliable, imprecise, fighting. Kiryu always sprints around, meaning group combat can be a bit harder to co-ordinate (unless you want to barely move your joystick to make him walk, but that makes dodging punches unreliable). Heat actions only seem to work on command about 50% of the time, which sounds annoying but its absolutely soul destroying on Legend difficulty (asin, you do an animation that should allow a heat action afterwards but half the time the command won't even come up, or comes up for literally a frame). The arena has bullshit lock-in animations which can bully your health to 0 in no time flat, and blocking now cancels your combos, which absolutely destroys the flow of combat that Y0 and YK had. <- this cannot be overstated

You can carry an absurd amount of health boosters around, so late-game combat is honestly a joke compared to other games in the series if you know what you are doing.

The fun substory "essence of..." abilities are way overpriced.

Some minigames (milky nose, mahjong) are extremely hard to do for the completion list, and if you try to 100% your legend saves (like me, the moron) its a bad idea because the final bouncer missions on Legend: Legend are ABSOLUTELY impossible. 

Overall though this is a fantastic game, but if you want to 100% a Yakuza game, definitely don't pick this one. It is heavily recommended to play the prior Yakuza games too, to understand what is going on.

If you're a fan of the series, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a no-brainer. It changes the combat formula up but if you give it a chance and don't consider using items/weapons cheap, you'll have a blast. I'm already simultaneously dreading but looking forward to playing Yakuza 3, if only to see the story play out.

Going from Kiwami 1 (K1) to Kiwami 2 (K2) is kind of a shock since K2 was made using the engine RGG made for Yakuza 6, so we get a glimpse of that combat. A lot of people I know hated the combat in K2, and honestly I went from going "oh, it's refreshing" to "man this sucks" and settling on "ok this is a net good improvement... maybe?" - it's still up in the air but I think overall once you start unlocking moves with EXP and using items (like RGG wants us to), the combat potential opens up again. There's still something off that I can't put my thumb on.

Kiwami 2 captures that feeling Yakuza 0 (Y0) gave to me where I felt an actual desire to explore the old stomping grounds of Kamurocho and Sotenbori. A lot has changed in the world since K1, let alone Y0. The cities felt alive, even a bit moreso than Y0. Being able to enter and exit buildings seamlessly instead of pressing a button to move to a new section of the map that held the interior of the store? Beautiful.

Majima Construction was an awful minigame. Conversely, the Cabaret Club was a welcome surprise.

A major surprise was [spoiler]being able to walk around Kamurocho and Sotenbori with Haruka and eat food/play games to build her trust with you. Is this why people become parents?[/spoiler]

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is the second game I've tried in the series. In short, yes this game is definitely worth playing and I'll tell you why.

The game is filled with rich looking cut scenes from the moment you start the game to the end of the game. That's what sets this game apart from all the other games I have tried in the past. I usually skip a lot of the cut scenes in other video games but what I found to be the best aspect in this game was how the game tries its best to put you in the world of the Yakuza. The characters displaying emotions in scenes really helps you understand the characters better. My favorite character would probably have to be Majima though. There are a few parts in the game where I got in a few laughs from him. Especially, when he bangs his head on the steel table. Most of the game is really just cut scenes. Sometimes the characters exaggerate certain tasks but a lot of times, the missions turn out to be really easy. The game, for me at least, was a lot easier than Yakuza Kiwami 1. The battles in the first game seemed a lot harder than the ones in this game. The ending didn't feel all that epic but I understood the story a little better.

The city in the game appears to be small and at first glance I'm thinking, this game shouldn't be that hard! The city here looks like I can get through it in a few days. While I didn't get through most of the side quests in two days, the side quests really had me going all over the place. There's a lot of secret interactions within the city and minigames one could take part in. It had so much to offer but I didn't like how there are street gangs literally on every other block in the game. It gets annoying fighting/avoiding them. One would have to devise a plan to avoid them to try and get to your main objective or side quest. 

There was only one fight I needed help on and that was the first fight with that one blonde dude. His name started with an R. The game asked me if I wanted to switch over to easy and I did. Sure, I felt guilty but doing that made me want to continue the story instead of adding this game to my junk list just because I couldn't beat one enemy.

All in all, if you like a good story with some Tekken styled violence, you should add this one to your wish list. Maybe you're not like me and won't beat this game in a few days and enjoy the whole game on your own time. I'm not saying I just wanted to get this game out of the way, I just have a tendency to want to get things done. I will definitely come back to this gem. 5/5

This game is a good sequel. Yet again. Remade. 1080p. More than 60 fps. Console gamers, eat your heart out. 

Mocking aside, HOLY DAMN how good this game looks, graphically. We'll start there. Kamurocho and Sotenbori now really, REALLY looks AWESOME deluxe, no doubt thanks to the fantastic Dragon engine. The lights in the city, the reflections of the water, the wrinkles of Granny White - It all looks so good! It is superior to a lot of other titles, graphically.

Gameplay-wise, I'd say a lot has changed from 0 and Kiwami. For the better? Maybe. For the worse? No. You have physics now... Or well, you did in 0/Kiwami too, but now they cranked it up from 6 to 10. The player ragdolls when he takes a mace to the face, the NPCs flail around. A BIT immersion-breaking, but I learned to ignore it really fast. Oh, and you don't have the 4 styles of fighting anymore, just your fists and the eventual weapon you pick up. HOWEVER: I think this was a good choice. Sure, the styles were awesome, BUT, switching to them in a middle of a fight is something that you sometimes "forget" to do, because you got so experienced with one of them. I am on the fence about this, BUT I found myself using weapons much more, which made for so many more awesome combos and finishers. You can pick up signs and physics objects, and as you do a finisher, you sometimes get a QTE, which I think is based on how much Heat you have. It's fun and destroys faces.

The side missions are fun as always. No, really. Not only do you have the usual sub-stories, but now you can walk with Haruka, hand in hand as she drags you around Kamurocho and Sotenbori asking for stuff to do. Of course, little angel, let's go to a ramen store, just gotta beat these guys up first...

Speaking of: The encounter thingy has been changed quite a bit. You know in 0 and Kiwami when you bump into someone? Yeah, that doesn't happen here. Now you see where the NPCs that will fight you are, so that you have a good chance to just run off. You could do this in 0/Kiwami as well, but I feel it is better "refined" here. Well, whatever. It makes for some good EXP beating the thugs up, so I usually rushed into them full speed. 

The EXP system has been changed. Now you get these 5 different "orbs" after a fight. I don't know exactly what each of them mean, but if you have 100 reds and 200 blues, you can then unlock the next combo or health upgrade. I like this system.

The story is not as tear-jerking as in Kiwami, but it has its moments. I did feel bad for some of the bad guys, but nothing that left me a sobbing mess (Thanks for that, SEGA. (Talking about Kiwami)). Instead of it being Date-san that follows you around in every chapter, although he is there, the main attraction (and boy do I mean ATTRACTION) is Sayama Kaoru. She forces her way into your heart, and you will eventually come to like her. Trust me, she is a fine one.

I could write so much more about this game. Seriously. The karaoke, the Majima construction mini-game, the kabakura mini-game and so on. But this is something you have to see for yourself to truly get what I mean. 

So ultimately, do I recommend this? Hell yes. 
Is it different from 0/Kiwami? Yes, but not in a bad way!

Welcome back to Kamurocho. Things are different here now. The Tojo Clan is in disarray after the events of Yakuza Kiwami, Virtua Fighter 2 has been installed in the Sega Arcade, and Majima has started a construction company‚Äîtearing down the homeless camp of West Park in preparation for the Kamurocho Hills office complex. But more dramatic than any of these small developments is Yakuza Kiwami 2's big change: the series' new Dragon engine, and the many improvements and changes it brings.

Yakuza is an economical series that rarely reinvents the wheel. It often reuses assets and animations, because the focus is always on the same handful of districts, and the small ways they change over the course of decades. Kiwami 2 is still a Yakuza game, which means it's a crime drama interspersed by fights, exploration, minigames and substories full of ridiculous slice-of-life character moments that help humanise protagonist Kiryu‚Äîmaking him more than the hardboiled stereotype he could so easily have been. It's also a remake of 2006's Yakuza 2, which, despite looking significantly better, features mostly shot-for-shot recreations of its cutscenes.

Good remake of the second Yakuza game. While Kiwami 1 used Y0's engine, this Kiwami uses the engine seen previously in Yakuza 6. Yakuza 2 is usually considered the best game, at least story-wise, so the heavily updated graphics seen in this remake should be a great way to see how this story plays out. 

Gameplay is usual Yakuza fare, though due to this new engine and the up in the quality of character animations it brings, this game's combat tends to feel like it drags on more than it really should. The game still feels as arcade-y as it's PS3-era predecessors, but in a different kind of way, and it's a difference that isn't bad if we were to speak "objectively" (as objective as we can be about a video game), but it's not my cup of tea. You'll have to play for yourself to get a better picture of what I'm trying to describe and to see if it's something you'll be into more than I was.

The good:

Very good story and subtories, great minigames, with the returning minigames mostly improving, they have added allot of quality of life features, with allot of new features too that make the game more fun. Even though the game has less unique music that hasn't been brought back from past games, the new tracks are still great. Grinding is allot more easier since you just grind for money and eat combination of food to gain 5 types of exp that you can use to slowly upgrade, unlock abilities, stats, minigames upgrades and you can upgrade your sprint now, without using cp (since there isn't a cp system) which for me is a plus. The new characters and the voice acting is still amazing. They added allot of little features that are fun to mess around with, like the objects that are placed throughout the town now have physics, which let you just push them and even destroy them while roaming around, now you can take photos and you can roam around town in first person. Once you are spotted by an enemy, they just walk after you, instead of running. which makes it easier to escape them, you can even run away while in a fight and escape. The heat actions are more funnier and some of them are just straight up hardcore, for example: the most famous one is the heat action where Kiryu literally stick a tube up an enemies anus and pushes it further in by punching it deeper. The three chapters of the Majima saga storyline you unlock throughout progressing the main story where great, since you get to fight as Majima with a limited moveset of the legend style that plays very similarly to the Yakuza 0 version and the ending was very satisfying and emotional.

The bad:

The game has been poorly optimised for pc, in the sense that it lags sometimes when opening up the menu and running the game on high render scale will make your pc lag and/or overheat, even while having the recommended specs. Even after upgrading all of the stats and abilities, the combat in this game is still bad, since it's stiff, slow and just unsatisfying, hitting an enemy that is guarding, leaves you in allot of end lag, it cancels your attack and it completely gets rid of your momentum and speed. Enemies are constantly guarding which makes fighting painfully slow sometimes and they instantly dodge your grabs, sometimes grabbing damages the opponent, without actually letting you get a hold of the enemy you're grabbing, basically acting like a punch that doesn't hit stun. This game has ragdoll physics which can be funny and fun to mess around, but they can be annoying, janky and they ruin the ambience of serious fights, the most annoying thing about it is that, it can send enemies and bosses far away, which make it harder to use heat actions on them and kiryu himself ragdolls, which makes it so you take longer to get up. There isn't any unarmed heat actions or abilities that counter guarding, so the combat is more oriented towards using melee weapons instead, since they counter guards and you can heat action a guarding foe with weapons.

I would recommend to buy this game for anything else, besides the combat, since the combat and the way the game runs is the only big issue that this game has.

I'm going to review this game from the perspective of someone who played Yakuza 0, Kiwami(1) and now Kiwami 2 in order.

What a conclusion to this sort of original (prequel+remakes) trilogy.

The good:

- The game looks absolutely gorgeous. The Dragon Engine is just beautiful during gameplay and especially the lighting and map designs during freeroam. Some of the cutscenes are also very well animated.

- Almost no loading screens. The freeroam is seamless. Can enter shops, restaurants and minigame locations freely as they are directly connected to the outside of the cities.

-There are physics and proper collision with objects! You can walk through the street and move around benches, bikes and other objects and even break them on rougher contact.Fighting in a store and dropping items from shelves and then the shelf falling off is just so interactive!
When fighting bodies fly back due to knockback. The ragdolling can be a bit silly sometimes but overall it's a great addition.

-Sayama.
Although not playable, she is the 2nd main character of the game and is a great character.
A strong, assertive woman, who is also attractive, feminine, relatable and kind.
No fanservice, no pandering, no agenda forced but just genuinely a good female character. Take note SJW-pandering Western developers.

- Following on the improvement of Kiwami (1) over Yakuza 0, minigames and completionist task are fairly easier to do now. With once again Cheat items having a return. Although things like Mahjong still took a while, the overall experience was far less grindy and annoying compared to Yakuza 0.

- The city of Sotenbori is back :).

- Unlike Kiwami (1), The story here was quite enjoyable and interesting, in some ways even more than 0's.
The triple (Or even quadrupel) twists at the end, that pretty much all happened one after another during the final battle however felt a bit overdone and unnecessary.

-Cabret club minigame is back! And the story directly continues from the original in 0. Awesome!

-Although not a lot, we got some more cute Uncle Kiryu and Haruka moments. Yey!

- Music wasn't too bad. Still can't beat Yakuza 0's OST, but was better than Kiwami (1).

- YOU CAN SKIP PRETTY MUCH ALL DIALOGUE NOW IF YOU WANT TO. WHAT A GODSEND FOR SECOND PLAYTHROUGHS( In my case Legend playthrough). I cannot describe the relief i felt when i noticed it.



My complaints ( Nothing that i would really consider "BAD"):

- Did we really need 70+ bouncer missions? There was nothing unique in most of them, and the varied difficulties for each map didn't add anything other than healthbars for the most part. A better way to implement this would to just have one of each map instead of 3 and just balance the overall difficulties better, or have less maps all together.

- I wrote this review almost right after i finished the game, and other than the Cabret club side plot, i can't remember a single substory. They were all just not memorable here. Having ZERO voice acting in nearly all of them once again doesn't help either.

- Just like Kiwami (1) and unlike Yakuza 0, you can't skip freeroam battles. It is easier to avoid than before as enemies don't instantly jump you on here and you can maneuver around them better, but still annoying.

-There's a lot of backtracking for both the main missions and the side content. Personally felt worse than the previous 2 games. After almost every main mission, or during every side story, you are always sent to the other end of the map from the location you were. Then once you reach your destination, you have a conversation, maybe a short fight and back to the original position or a different spot at an extreme end of the map. Walking around the map, increased quite a bit of the run time of the game.

- The combat is a bit hit or miss. It's far more enjoyable than Kiwami (1)'s and although i haven't played yet obviously better than 3's. It is rather slow and you can't pull off too many moves as you only have your Dragon style now. 
There is a lot of focus on using weapons and their corresponding heatmoves on this one. It's still fun and works fine, but it ain't great.

-This is an issue with all Yakuza games, or even every Japanese game but you need to suspend a lot of disbelief to enjoy this or any other game of the series. There's a lot of moments where the main characters not only get ridiculous plotarmor, but there's decisions being made by characters that just don't make sense. So many gun standoffs than somehow end up either with fists winning and barely a shot being fired or shots to the body and endless monologue instead of just finishing someone off. It's of course very dramatic and cool, but also so very silly when you really take a moment to think about it later.

- For some reason unlike the previous games, there's no voice acting in main mission dialogue if it isn't Cutscenes. odd choice.

-Clan manager, a sort of tower/base defense minigame, is kinda hit or miss. You'll either sort of like it or be madly bored of it. The subplot revolving around it makes pretty much zero sense even by some Yakuza series standards as well.

-Haruka's design seemed a bit off for me. In Kiwami (1) she looked like a cute kid, but in Kiwami 2 it looks like an aged face was placed on a kids body in a way. Hard to really describe but easy to spot once you see it.


Overall this is a fantastic game, that is cheaply priced even without a sale.
The game is complete, has tons of content, no silly microtransactions or DLC locked content. 

Of course i wouldn't recommend starting with it, playing 0 and Kiwami(1) beforehand would be better.

Kiwami 2 is a gem from the Yakuza franchise. It uses the newer game engine that Yakuza 6 and Like a Dragon run on which makes it stand out quite a lot in terms of quality and gameplay. The game looks great, and it plays even better.

The gameplay is the star in this entry as I never had so much fun just bashing my way through Kamurocho and Sotenbori and doing every mini-game and sub-story. I spent hours learning and perfecting my Mahjong gameplay just for the achievement and god damn was it fun when I actually learned how it works. Aside from the side stuff the actual combat is great. It feels smooth, pulling off special moves is a blast, the heat actions are amazing, and just being able to pick someone and spin them into their mates is so fulfilling. The games world is also fully interconnected, there are no loading screens if you're entering a store from the street. Its all just part of the map, which can lead to some fights being led into the convenience marts which then lead to more special heat actions using the store as the canvas.

The story is decent, although I wouldn't say it beats Yakuza 0 for me. But I did enjoy the story in this game quite thoroughly as having something live up to the story of 0 is quite a feat. But just on its own the story was decent and the typical Yakuza story you'd come to expect. Plenty of drama, betrayal, pain and comedy with our favorite major character Majima Goro.

The music was phenomenal and have some truly great pieces that I added to my playlist. High octane and even somber pieces all weave within the gameplay and story to make some truly unforgettable moments in this game.

There's still a lot I did not cover as there is the whole Hostess mini-game (Which is like a continuation but also even better version of the Yakuza 0 hostess mini-game) along with Majima clan creation which was an... interesting strategy game to say the least. Overall I highly recommend this game if you're a fan of the Yakuza franchise as you'll have a great time with it and love every minute of the gameplay.

Fresh off the new Dragon Engine, Kiwami 2 is the second PS4 era Yakuza game sporting the engine. The only other game in the series to use the Dragon Engine thus far is Yakuza 6, also on the PS4 (and soon coming to PC). 

	If I had to summarize what the Dragon Engine improves on graphically, its primarily the lighting. Because the texture work on the PS3-era games (0, Kiwami 1) holds up well enough that  you'd be hard-pressed to differentiate Majima's model from here or Kiwami 1. It's when you see these models in the new night-time lighting that it sets itself apart. The way water reflects the environment off the floor, and storelights hit the pavement is something I can't imagine on a PS3. It might seem simple, but it changes a lot.

	Lighting and model improvements aside, the devs also have more resources this time around dedicated to areas they previously spent less on. No longer are you going to see low resolution, static textures used for storefront windows on buildings you can't enter. This time around we get NPC's interacting inside with full store decor. You also get debris, chairs, and trash cans that look decent. You'd think these are small improvements that don't do a lot, but you'd be wrong. Kamurocho and Sotenbori also have more buildings you can enter along with more alleyways and crevices that expand the city. But that's to be expected with each iteration.

	Compared to the PS2 game, this is the definite version, albeit not as strongly so as Kiwami 1. Kiwami 1 was almost a 1:1 replica of the first game, with stuff added. Kiwami 2 is 85% the same game, but the town of Shinseicho is missing, as is the male host side-quest. The sidequest had you playing as a male host who's goal it is to raise money, which was just the talking sections of the cabaret mini-game when you're trying to level up the girls (no big loss). The town of Shinseicho is the bigger missing piece here. Shinseicho wasn't relevant to the game-a small area with something like 3 stores, and visited only once. So you're not missing a lot, but they still engaged in the act of subtraction when crafting a remake, and that's always a negative. I get that development time and its irrelevance merited it, but I'd still love to see it in the new engine.

	Still, I'd argue Kiwami is the go-to experience since it adds the cabaret mini-game from 0. The original PS2 release had a cabaret game, but it was drastically different and nowhere near as good as it would turn out to be in later games. You also get the Majima focused side-game (clan fighter); bouncer missions (go through levels and fight bosses); the "Majima Saga" mini-campaign (finished in under an hour). The level-up system makes use of food more-so than before, but you can also level up to such a point that the boss battles become a joke. So the overall game is much easier (MUCH easier), if you choose to level up to that point, that is. 

	The combat system is similar to the PS2 original. It's not an exact replica, but it's in the same simplistic sort of vein. All your base combos are the same. As such, weapons play a bigger role since you don't have a mountain of heat actions and ways of opening up blocking enemies. Weapons, with higher base damage, are more viable ways of finishing fights that would otherwise take longer. I could understand staying truer to the PS2 original's combat in a remake (even if they didn't do that with Kiwami 1), but from my understanding this is just Yakuza 6's combat system with slight alterations. 

Like many have stated, combat feels like its regressing in complexity. I'm not so hard on it here since Kiwami 2 is just a remake of Yakuza 2, and in that respect combat is an improvement. It'd be more appropriate to delve into this point in Yakuza 6. As such, I'll say this: there was room to trim Yakuza 0's combat (what was the purpose of 'Brawler'), and combining various elements of the fighting style's isn't a bad idea. That said, the game could use more heat actions and introduce some of the nuances from the missing fighting styles (crowd control of 'Beast' and swiftness of 'Rush'). But combat is improved over the PS2 original, and even on its own I wouldn't call it bad.

	The writing is what I really have some complaints on: more ambitious than the first, but seems to not be able to handle its two story arc well. Yakuza 2 has two plots running parralel to one another. The problem is that the secondary plot (the Korean faction) completely eclipses the first (Ryuji and the Omi) to the point of irrelevance. Ryuji-the guy on the box and the man touted as the main villain-disappears/goes AFK for a LARGE portion of the game and is relegated to a sub-boss. Ryuji and the Omi appear every once in a while to remind you that they're in the game, but they're all ultimately henchmen for the much larger plot at play. They're tied to the secondary story in the easiest and laziest way, further burying that unnecessary plot arc as nothing more than people being useful idiots. It's a shame because Ryuji truly is built up as a fantastic threat, but becomes a wasted character. Imagine the final boss not actually being important to the story.

	Funnily enough, the secondary plot is actually good. It's a crime drama that ties our main character's histories together. Sayaka enters the story as a rookie cop, and comes out the main character of the game. Kiryu is only tangentially involved here, and arguably a secondary character. The only issue is the scenario can get ridiculous on that 'video-game writing' level; a foreign mafia is seeking revenge on the Tojo. Which is fine, but the long amount of time and the lengths some of these people go through to enact it becomes comedic. I like the ambition in the writing, but I can't take some of it seriously. Still like it, though.

	I'm down on how they handled the final boss and the two stories. I'm even down on the missing town of Shinseicho. Let's tack on a third bullet point and beat down how ridiculous a 26 year revenge plot where you become president just to randomly bomb the oval office is. I'll still praise Yakuza 2's ambition and effective dramatic moments. Better than 0? Hell no. Better than 1? I can see why some would prefer Yakuza 1, but I'll take Yakuza 2's larger scope in the end.

Graphics: 
The environments of Sotenbori and Kamurocho look absolutely stunning in this game. It really feels like the red light districts they are based on. What's a little weird is how detailed the faces are. Some are very well-detailed while other's, not so much. But the faces that are detailed have the best detailing out of any game. 

Sound Design: 
The fighting sounds, the bustling sounds of Tokyo and Osaka, mix very well to give the game a high score in that regard. 

Soundtrack:
The soundtrack has an abundance of music. What I really liked is how Sotenbori and Kamurocho have different songs playing while you fight, to represent the difference in location. Some of the songs they bring in, for example, "The Sound of Breath" by SiM is absolutely fantastic for the ending and does soundtrack right. 

Plot:
This game plot is very sensible and it always keeps you on your toes. The pacing is excellent and it doesn't feel drawn out. The villains are those you can sympathize with and the supporting cast is amazing. This game is one of the best, if not the best story in video game history. It is slightly better than Yakuza 0's story. There's also the Majima Saga, which is about an hour long, but provides some really good closure for the events of Yakuza 0 and is fun to play. 

Dialogue:
Nothing to complain about. All the banter makes sense, nothing is out of place, and the comedic dialogue is quite good as well. We can really see the voice actors put their heart into their lines so it's pretty great overall. 

Gameplay:
The gameplay takes a step back from Yakuza 0 and Kiwami, but the gameplay is still very satisfying for a beat 'em up game. The heat moves are in less quantity, but when you execute on them, are just as satisfying. The side quests and the minigames are also super satisfying. The story takes about 20 hours to complete, and I dumped 40 hours into the game. 

Setting:
Sotenbori and Kamurocho feel like very bustling environments and are a proper city, in comparison to other cities, for example, Los Santos in GTA V. There are so many side quests.

Overall, this game is another excellent addition to an already great franchise and I can't wait to see what Yakuza 3 has to offer.

One of my favourite games in the series so far. I loved Yakuza 0 but had a lukewarm reaction to Kiwami 1. I was hesitant on this game because of it but out of the three I've played, this one is definitely my favourite. 

This game is running on the new 'Dragon Engine', which basically means that it got a very big graphical boost and stats/upgrades work differently. Whilst people might not care about graphics and stuff that much, it made a huge difference for me just wandering around Kamurocho and Sotenbori, especially with the photo mode and first person view they added.

Fighting has changed slightly, as in there isn't multiple modes to fight with anymore, instead just one - closely matching the brawler type in the other games. The added heat moves and weapons offset slightly this however, and enemies don't have specific modes that you need to beat them anymore. I think it tightens the game up a bit, allowing more polish to be given to the one fighting style but it's understandable if you miss the variety of the previous games.

Mini games and other fun stuff is still there, but if you're already this deep in the series that's to be expected. The story however is where I think it shines the brightest. After the events of Kiwami 1, Kiryu is just a civilian with PTSD chilling with Haruka, until he obviously gets roped back into the clan. This time under the threat of Omi invasion. All the main characters feel very fleshed out, with clear goals and motivations driving them to keep moving forward. I guarantee that even the most stoic of people out there will be feeling pretty emotional after the ending, and with a 20+ hour story, you'll definitely have enough time to get to attached everyone by the end. Just as a side note, the Majima saga is really good, it ties up some loose ends after the events of Yakuza 0. It's only 3 chapters, so please play it.

I would 100% recommend this game at full price, but it goes on sale for 50% off relatively often, so it'd probably be wiser to wait.

[h1] [b] Yakuza Kiwami 2 [/b] [/h1]

Another entry into the Yakuza series, and a sequel to Yakuza Kiwami. Can SEGA keep the good times rolling? Or is it just another so-so sequel? Lets get into it.

[h1] [b] The Good [/b] [/h1]

[*] [b] The Combat [/b]

- Combat has always been a staple of the Yakuza games as in it's simplest form... you kind of just beat the **** out of people for the entire game. What Yakuza Kiwami 2 has down, however is a bit different from some of the other Yakuza games. Kiwami 2 removes the 4 (sometimes 5) fighting styles found in other Yakuza games, and simplifies them into one base combat mode, while allowing some of the more famous aspects of combat be unlocked through skills. This both adds a new and refreshing combat style to the game for returning players, and is simple enough to not scare off new players. A win-win, I say.

[*] [b] The Story and Characters [/b]

- The Yakuza games are famous for many things, but a good story and lovable/memorable characters are their biggest selling point to me. In Kiwami 2 you return as the famed Kazuma Kiryu, also known as the Dragon of Dojima. You must travel to a far away city to attempt to broker peace between two Yakuza clan, but an unexpected coup throws a wrench in your plans. Throughout this story you will experience the Yakuza game's famed characters and side stories which can range from "wholesome and heart-warming" to "I think I was just tricked into being a gay-porn model", y'know, just Yakuza stuff, man.

[*] [b] The Humor and Entertainment Value [/b]

- This is a very weird point to make, but there is so much to do to entertain yourself in Kiwami 2 that you can literally forget that you were supposed to be playing a game. I actually walked into an arcade off the street, played crane games and rip-off fighting games for three hours, and forgot that I was playing a videogame inside of a videogame. Other than that, there is so much random stuff that keeps you busy in this game. That, plus the very unique sense of humor you can only find in the Yakuza series makes for a game so entertaining you might forget you were supposed to be playing the story.

[*] [b] The Graphics [/b]

- The game is just actually quite beautiful. Walking through the lit-up streets or rampaging through a building, it just looks good. A nice remake. 

[h1] [b] The Bad [/b] [/h1]

[*] [b] The Pacing [/b]

- I will admit the story and some of the character developments can feel quite... rushed? Things come and go outta nowhere. The game seems randomly paced at times and can occasionally through you out of the immersion with it.

[h1] [b] The Ugly [/b] [/h1]

[*] [b] The Shadow of the Past [/b]

- I never try to compare a game to it's earlier entries, as it is important to always try to move and improve on ideas. However, Kawami 2 just doesn't give me the same feelings I got when playing earlier Yakuza entries. By no means is it bad through, and if this is the worst point of the game, how bad can it be?

[h1] [b] Overall [/b] [/h1]

This review is written form the perspective of first playing Yakuza 0 and the first Kiwami.

Kiwami 2 is the last of the original trilogy of PC Yakuza games, and up until recently, probably the last Yakuza a lot of people could play. It is the only entry in this trilogy not to make use of the style system, and also introduces an entirely different level and experience system. 

In this game, Kiryu has one basic light attack combo with different heavy attacks based on when in a combo you hit the button, and based on which direction kiryu is facing. These attacks can also be charged for greater ability to deal damage and break through guards. At first, I was afraid this would be underwhelming compared to the many options of the previous two games. However, in place of styles, this game puts much more time into the balance and usefulness of weaponry (both improvised and prepared). In the prior entries, I felt like weapons really didn't have much purpose, and only really used them when beast style automatically picked them up. Here, they do decent damage and seem to have better durability. Some weapons you get from having save data from kiwami (such as the machine gun) are actually so strong they are entirely broken.

Weapons often have a heat action that can be obtained from spending experience points, which brings us to the new leveling system. After finishing battles, substories, or other things on the completion list, you will receive experience in different categories. These can be used to acquire new attacks, new heat actions, quality of life features, or just general stat-ups. 

This system is good in theory, but I feel its bad in practice. Many substories end with you gaining a new "ally" in town or receiving a scroll. These allies perform special heat actions, and these scrolls give you special actions you couldn't otherwise use. The only problem is, for some reason, actually using these rewards requires spending experience. Completing these substories only gave you the ability to spend experience to actually learn the ability. This makes the rewards feel hollow, and they feel tied to the level system for no reason other than to waste experience. I actually never unlocked a single ally attack because I found everything else to be a better investment. Again, the system itself works fine, and I wouldn't be upset to work with it in other entries.

The story in this game tries to be much more complex than the prior two. Ultimately, 0's plot boiled down to solving mysteries about the empty lot, kiwami's plot boiled down to trying to find a specific person. Kiwami 2's plot is about how actions taken by one party tie into motivations for another party with direct relation to this or that character who ends up not being connected the way you think and so on and so forth. Quite frankly, I'm not even sure how to summarize it and be sure I don't accidentally spoil twists. If I had to give a basic summary I'd say this story is about rising tensions between the Tojo and Omi. Kiryu, feeling responsible for the events of last year (the events of the first game) involves himself in trying to protect and maintain what remains of the Tojo family.  However, the police force in Osaka is closely monitoring his actions, leading to a cop following him around for much of the story. The game becomes not only about solving the immediate issues in front of Kiryu, but also about the growing bond between these two characters. 

While the story has good character drama and is emotional, I can't help but feel like it became very overcomplicated by the end. It felt like it was more interested in having unexpected twists than making sure the story was good. This isn't to say the final result is bad, just that it could be better. 

Overall, Kiwami 2 is a very good, but also quite different, entry in the series. I will say I plan to move onto the rest of the series, but from here on have literally no knowledge about the series. I am a bit concerned Yakuza 3, being a game from the early ps3 era with none of the refinements of the Kiwami entries, may feel underwhelming or clunky gameplay wise, but I will give it a fair chance. I also worry the storyline will continue to become more interested in making sure the plot is complicated, rather than that it is memorable and interesting.  I would say that Kiwami 2 is about as good as Yakuza 0, which are both a bit better than the first Kiwami. I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who found the other entries fun.

I don't see a reason why anybody would dislike this entire series. It has everything, and I mean EVERYTHING a great game/franchise needs.  Every episode is crafted with precision, love and skill,  and they're all so well put together there are almost zero technical issues. You never have a dull moment in these games, and even though there is quite a lot of walking from point a to point b, just looking at the vibrant, bustling streets you're walking is a pleasure in itself. Each game looks and feels so alive, and they're all stuffed to the brim with lovable, unforgettable characters, interesting side-quests and minigames that are actually really fun (but not mandatory).

Yakuza 0,  Kiwami and Kiwami 2 all have a fantastically written main story that can bring you to tears if you let yourself be immersed in their world. I'm usually not a fan of "movie-like" games, especially not if the plot is so linear, but in these games you are presented with so many, beautifully crafted little gifts in between cinematic cutscenes, so many things to do, so many ways to enjoy yourself,  that the games simply make you fall in love with them and their exceptionally well written characters, to the point where you not only "forgive them" for having cutscenes that are sometimes several minutes long, but you actually really start to enjoy watching  them, just as much as you enjoy the heart-pumping action sequences when you get to curb-stomp yakuza bosses and toss delinquent teenagers in the river. 

Long story short, these games are phenomenal. Ry≈´ ga Gotoku is practically the only AAA franchise these days that's still exciting and is still worth both your time and money. That is, if you're willing to keep an open mind and dive into a world that's  both really exciting and a little strange at times.

It is very rare that a series maintains it's shimmer and shine throughout each installment, and Yakuza Kiwami 2 is no exception. I love this game, I in fact, cherish it. Everything about this game is an improvement from Zero and Kiwami. Not only is there a new engine to showcase the streets of Kamurocho and Sotenbori, there is a new combat system, skill tree, and a multitude of mechanics. Like previous installments, there are an insane amount of activities and mini-games. Kiwami 2's new combat system allows for new satisfying combos and finishers, with the ability to store weapons dropped by enemies. Along with that, by far one of the best additions. Rag doll physics. To have an enemy fly away at Mach 7 speed after a devastating punch or kick, alongside the rumble of the controller, amplifies combat to a new level. Partnered with these new fancy moves, is a phenomenal story. Building upon Zero's and Kiwami's story, with even MORE surprises and twists, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is an emotional and epic narrative. Seriously, when you think you have seen enough, you have not. This has been a roller-coaster through and through. Though it may be a little bias, I don't care. I love this game and cherish this series. Yakuza Kiwami 2 earns it's 9.5/10 with soaring dragons and ferocious flames.

One little note if you're having fps issues is to check the resolution in the graphics settings because for some reason the game automatically put it to the highest setting for me, fixing that made it run like butter tho

Combat was something I was iffy about because I really liked the multiple styles of 0 and kiwami but in hindsight I can admit I did spend most of my time using one style over all the others (Rush and slugger). This one size fits all approach in kiwami 2 really did grow on me and it has a bit more depth due to things like charge up attacks that can be prepped mid combo and the extreme heat mode doing more than a damage buff/ unlocking new moves. I found weapons were also more useful in here but sometimes to a DISGUSTING degree, I did only play on normal difficulty but I did that for all yakuza games and I easily beat a boss fight within like 10 seconds using some wooden sword.

There's also alot of improvements to minigames and substories, most notably map icons that point out where most substories actually are (also the writting for said substories is WAY better than Kiwami). I haven't gotten around to trying all the minigames yet but they improved on my favorite (karaoke) and made my not so favorite ( baseball) actually enjoyable. Oh and the cabaret club management is back (praise be) and they even made it so shops that you can partner with have a little icon pop up indicating the fact when you run by (praise be). 

There's also just a myriad of different QOL improvements that you'll definitely notice and appreciate when playing (such as way better inventory) and all around this just feels like a really smooth game that improved on everything from the previous 2 titles (except maybe the story compared to 0...but come on)

[h1] Yakuza Kiwami 2 [/h1]

I'm going to be blunt here. As someone who played the previous two games to 100% completion, I'm happy to say that Yakuza Kiwami 2 is not as bad as Kiwami but unfortunately, it's not as good as Yakuza 0, either. It fixes many of the weaknesses that were holding back the previous two games while making a few of its own. It's an average game through and through, and I'll explain why. But first, let's start with the positives. 

[u] The Positives [/u]

[b] 1. The Graphics [/b]
Yakuza Kiwami 2 is the second Yakuza game to run on the new Dragon Engine, and the game looks downright gorgeous. You will spend much of your time being in awe at how beautiful it looks, and how much improvements have been made since the last two games. Kamurocho and Sotenbori feel more alive than ever, and it's a blast exploring the two cities again in higher graphical fidelity. 

[b] 2. The Majima Saga [/b]
Set ten months before the events of Yakuza Kiwami 2, play as Goro Majima as you witness the domino pieces being set up for the events that would soon unravel a few months later. It's a new addition to the story that was never there in the original game. It goes beyond just providing contexts for the main campaign. To avoid any potential spoiler, let's just say anyone who was deeply invested in Majima's story in Yakuza 0 will finally get the closure they've been waiting for. 

[b] 3. Frustrating mini-games are gone [/b]
If you're like me, and you hated many of the mini-games in the previous two games that rely almost entirely on luck to win, then you'll be happy to know pretty much all of them have been removed and replaced by better ones in Yakuza Kiwami 2. A few of them have also been altered to be less grindy, so that's a huge bonus. 

[b] 4. Fun substories make a return [/b]
In my review of Yakuza Kiwami, I mentioned how I quite disliked many of the substories that were in that game for their lack of creativity and fun. However, that is not the case here. This is the one area where Yakuza Kiwami 2 can competently compete with Yakuza 0, and I'm happy to be able to say that. 

[u] The Average [/u]

This section is going to be entirely reserved for the plot of Yakuza Kiwami 2 because I firmly believe the story to be the most PAINFULLY average part of the entire game. The one good thing I can say about it is I guess it's not as bad as Yakuza Kiwami. But, that's not exactly a high praise when you consider just how terrible the last game was so surpassing it isn't really saying much. The story isn't a travesty by any means but it certainly has the potential to be a lot better in so many ways. Just trust me when I say if you're walking into Yakuza Kiwami 2 expecting the same level of writing as Yakuza 0, you're going to be sorely disappointed. Overall, it's passable. 

[u] The Negatives [/u]

[b] 1. The new combat system is worse in every way [/b]
Combat used to be the highlight of the Yakuza experience for me in Yakuza 0 and Kiwami, but in this game, it's nothing more than a watered-down version of what we used to have. Seriously, what the fuck happened? Nearly in every regard, it is objectively worse:

‚Ä£ Remember the four distinct fighting styles you used to have that kept combat from ever feeling stale and boring and helped make each fight exciting, fun, and varied? They're gone! There is now only one style. Much of the fun to be had in the previous games are now gone, and you're going to be forced to substitute them with different mediocre weapons that break faster than Greece's economy. One more thing, they made firearms absolute dog shit in this game. WHY???
‚Ä£ Combat feels weightless due to the ragdoll physics present in the game. It's funny and entertaining at first but after a few dozen times it starts to get old and annoying quickly, and you soon realize all it's doing is taking away from the impact, force, and weight that were once there in the combat that made it so brutal and visceral. 
‚Ä£ Distracting mobs with money is not an option and running away is significantly harder if you get spotted. So, in the end, what you have is a combat system that is worse in almost every imaginable way with ragdoll physics exacerbating the problem while having next to no option of running away to help alleviate the repetitiveness of combat. Great, this is exactly what I want in my Yakuza game. 

[b] 2. Bad facial animation outside of cutscenes [/b]
The upgrade in graphical fidelity means bad facial animations are now front and center and more apparent than ever before especially the mouth. I think I've seen robots with more realistic mouth movements than what the animators were able to come up with in this game. It's exceptionally bad.

[b] 3. The written dialogues are underwhelming [/b]
This is a subtle trend that I've been noticing ever since Kiwami but in Kiwami 2 it's even more apparent. Just to make sure I wasn't imagining things, I went back and re-watch playthroughs of Yakuza 0, and the difference is like night and day. The dialogue in Kiwami 2 definitely lacks the personality, charm, and style that made Zero so great. The protagonist himself, Kazuma Kiryu, is the perfect example of this problem. This is essentially the difference between the two games in terms of the quality of writing in a nutshell:
Yakuza 0
Kuze: Cocky little shit! You're gonna make an enemy of me? You think you're ready for what that entails!?
Kiryu: I'm ready. If I weren't, I'd have no business calling myself a yakuza. 
Yakuza Kiwami 2
[Daigo Dojima is tied up and being held captive by four yakuza grunts]
Kiryu: Give him back or else.

[b] 4. There are a lot of fillers in Chapter 10 [/b]
Just like with Kiwami, this game also suffered from a chapter being riddled with fillers for absolutely no reason whatsoever. You will be spending more than half of chapter 10 doing busywork that could have easily been turned into two simple substories. It wasn't important and contributed nothing to the story in any meaningful way. 

[b] 5. Frame rate related issues [/b]
There are quite a lot of problems with this game that can't be solved unless you fix the frame rate. Fortunately, the people over at this website had made a patch to fix these issues. For your convenience: https://cookieplmonster.github.io/2020/01/18/silentpatch-yakuza-kiwami-2/
Unless you want to be frustrated by having certain mini-games and things not work properly, I highly recommend you install this patch first before playing the game. 

[b] 6. The completion list no longer gives any meaningful rewards. [/b]
In the previous two games, completing the completion list gives you points that you can spend to unlock exclusive powerful weapons and perks that can only be bought in the CP store. Instead, now it only gives you attribute points that will only go toward unlocking skills and stats. Incredibly disappointed in the direction they took with this. 

[u] In Conclusion [/u]
Yakuza Kiwami 2 is an average game that took many steps forward but also many steps back. Its plot and characters are nothing to write home about but if you're a fan of the previous two Yakuza games, then I do believe it's still worth checking out this one. I'm looking forward to playing all the games in the series once the rest of the collection comes to Steam next year. Thank you for reading my review.

I knew where Taitei Blvd. was, Senryo Avenue, the locations of every little attraction. It was a pretty city to explore, with bright signs and such. But then came the gigantic jump in quality of Kiwami 2...

I don't know Kamurocho anymore. So much has changed over Kiwami. But what probably got me most, was the graphical fidelity. Usually, I'm not one to give a damn about graphics. But the moment I stepped back into Kamurocho... my jaw dropped. The city feels so much more alive. So many more people walking around, the bright lights nearly blinding me for real... and all the other stylistic flourishes of the series turned up to 11.

Combat is much more simplified. Rather than three main styles and the Dragon of Dojima style, we only have one style and 3 weapon slots. It's all Thug style now. Or I guess technically all Legend style? Either way it feels a lot less flexible. But I think they finally balanced out the leveling up system at least, likely due to reducing Style count. 

On the upside of this, your toolkit is much more expanded and useful compared to an individual style. You're also blatantly encouraged to use weapons more, giving you some variety in there. Guns got hugely nerfed though. Feels Bad Man.

I have one outright downside though. Kiryu's movement speed. Maybe it's due to the engine change but he feels so much slower when running around town. They seemingly doubled your base sprint time but your walk and run feel so much slower compared to the blistering speed you could go at in 0 and Kiwami. Or maybe it's just the graphics actually giving the illusion of slower speed. I should do a side by side comparison...

I'm still in the honeymoon phase I'm sure, but at this moment, I feel like this is overall a huge upgrade over 0 and Kiwami and makes me look forward to the rest of the series coming to PC.

A little over a summer ago, I fell in love with a little known series called Yakuza; so much so that I ended up playing every single entry in the series that I could get ahold of, even the shitty zombie shooter spinoff that came out on PS3. The carefully crafted and refined formula of the franchise never seems to get old no matter how many times they do it, and with Yakuza Kiwami 2, they‚Äôve only managed to perfect it even more. 

Personally, having not played the original Yakuza 2, I can‚Äôt make very many comparisons between this remake and the original, so I‚Äôm largely judging this as a standalone product.

Utilizing RGG Studio‚Äôs recently developed Dragon Engine, Yakuza has never been better, both in terms of gameplay and graphics. It‚Äôs such a powerful and complex engine that even the most high-end of PCs will be left with fans whirring as loud as humanly possible, as if Kazuma Kiryu himself is tiger dropping your CPU.

The combat feels more slick and stylish than ever before; you really feel the weight of each and every blow you deliver to your opponents, complimented by a throbbing, energetic soundtrack not too unlike its predecessors. The quality of life improvements in general make the game all the more satisfying to play, with items now being separated into individual groups, as well as a much more lenient approach to skill trees. The ragdoll physics, and the physics engine in general, never get old; even 100 hours in I‚Äôm still laughing my ass off at the idea that Kiryu can make a motorcycle self-destruct simply by walking into it.

And you can play Virtual On in the arcades. What more could you ask for?

The story and cutscenes are top notch; no longer is the storytelling bogged down by incredibly slow, dull pacing like in the previous games, with the cinematic cutscenes being front and center. Every single shot and line of dialogue is packed to the brim with emotion; the scene with Kiryu trying to light his cigarette in the rain by his lonesome after a falling out with Kaoru is cinematic perfection, amongst many other powerful moments in the game‚Äôs narrative.

As much as I‚Äôd love to continue praising the game for paragraphs upon paragraphs, it isn‚Äôt without its flaws. Due to being built on a completely new engine, a handful of minigames had to sadly be cut; longrunners like baseball, karaoke, and golf remain in tact, but there‚Äôs no more billiards, bowling, pocket racing or the like from the previous engine‚Äôs games. There‚Äôs also a lot of bullshit moments in the story missions (i.e. locking you from beating the fucking final boss behind a QTE), but overall, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is without a doubt the most commendable entry in the series thus far.

I loved Yakuza 0, and people had warned me Kiwami 1 is the worst in the series by comparison (but not too bad in itself), and that Kiwami 2 gets better.

That's all I knew. Kiwami 2 gets better.

Nobody really got it across to me that Kiwami 2 is in a completely different league from 0 and 1. 

I'm not saying Yakuza Kiwami 2 is necessarily better than 0. I'm only halfway through with 2's story, and I liked 0's a lot more. But pretty much everything else about Kiwami 2 is a more satisfying experience.

0 was a PS3 game, and Kiwami 2 was built from the ground up as a PS4 game, and it shows in every aspect.

The world is far more detailed and better lit. You can sneak into alleys and climb up stairwells, and enter random offices. There is no loading between going from the exteriors of buildings to the interiors, and vice versa. You can walk up to a restaurant window and see everyone eating inside, and then just walk inside with no loading screen. You can get into fights outside restaurants and throw enemies through their windows, and then get refused service by the restaurant afterward.

The fighting is a lot more satisfying than the previous games. Gone are the 4 different styles and skill trees. You have one set of moves and a ton of different abilities to learn. 

The XP system is a lot more flexible this time. It's fed by battling, but also mission completion, eating, and certain random items you collect. 

The hostess minigame from 0 is back, virtually unchanged. I enjoyed its story in 0 more, but it's still a welcome addition to 2. The clan creator isn't so hot, but it's not that bad either. Definitely one of the less interesting features in the game, but at least it's different from everything else.

Finally I got to finish this game/remake after all this time, and lemme tell ya, as a huge Yakuza fan, it easily lived up to my expectations, if not even surpassed it.

And that's another thing I feel like I have to add. While it is not mandatory to have played the aforementioned installments, I strongly do encourage to experience them prior to Kiwami 2 as a lot of story details are tied directly together.

To get the very best out of the story, I recommend you start with 0, then straight into Kiwami 1 and THEN you can start Kiwami 2.

Like I said, it's not mandatory, but imo the story, characters and overall worldbuilding is so much better if you play the games in order. The emotional bond between Kiryu and Haruka and basically every other character in this game is much stronger if you've played the other 2 games first. 

But that's just my opinion, you can start off with any entry you want as every story is self-contained, just know that the emotional impact won't be as strong if you skip 0 and Kiwami, which I might add I think is kinda silly because all of the Yakuza games are pretty damn fantastic. Hell, you ain't got no reason skippin' any, so play them. All of them.

A beautiful looking remake of Yakuza 2, Yakuza Kiwami 2 utilises the dragon engine to really help combat and graphics pop, with almost non-existent load times with seamless transitions into most stores and locales.

The story is one of the best in the series so far, just behind Zero for me, but still with that Yakuza polish that's been around since the start. [h1]Another absolutely great game in a great franchise![/h1]

From the combat, to world exploration, to continuing to tell amazing stories and substories that the Yakuza games are known for this game delivers on it all.

[b]Note:[/b]
If you haven't played a Yakuza game yet I'd say don't play this game you'd be robbing yourself of the experience, I'd say instead start with 0 and work your way upwards, playing through them all is extremely rewarding and there are many story lines that carry over between games!

[h2]World Exploration[/h2]
This is what I would consider to be a truly next-gen Yakuza game, there's no loading fade to black every time you enter a building, you just walk in and you're there. I cannot begin to describe how shocking that felt after finishing Kiwami 1! It truly makes the world feel much more connected.

[h2]Combat[/h2]
Ditching the combat system of Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1, this combat system feels much more streamlined and enjoyable. Instead of switching between different fighting styles you're focusing more on heat moves from my experience and that was much more enjoyable.

[h2]Story[/h2]
Kiwami 2 continues with an even crazier story with even more threads to keep track of that all overlap in interesting ways. The ending is very much worth getting to!

TL:DR: Don't start on this one, but playing the prior games is very worth it to get to experience this game as it's intended. The best I've played in the series so far.

[h1] TL:DR [/h1]
"No thanks. Everyone important to me, they're right here in my heart. I'm out of that world now. Not that I really wanted in...". Yakuza series is one of the best action-adventure game series developed by Sega. This time an ex-Yakuza but still the Dragon of Dojima family, Kazuma Kiryu is called back into action. But this time you will learn the true story of the rise and fall of his old friend and enemy Goro Majima. If you played the first two games in the series, then Kiwami 2 is a MUST play.

[h1] INFO [/h1]
- This review is a personal opinion. Try the game for yourself.
- You can play the game by itself, but it is best enjoyed if you played it after Yakuza Zero and Yakuza Kiwami and before Yakuza: Like a Dragon to grasp the full meaning of the saga.
- Kiwami 2 can be pretty much compared with Kiwami 1, not as good as Yakuza Zero but still a great story in the saga.
- Once you started playing the saga with Yakuza Zero, there is no going back, you must play all Yakuza games. The proper order to play the games is the Steam chronological release order: Yakuza Zero, Yakuza Kiwami, Yakuza Kiwami 2, Yakuza: Like a Dragon. While the plot of Yakuza: Like a Dragon takes place 5 years before the plot of Yakuza Kiwami 2, they are totally different stories. Also Kazuma Kiryu is featured only in Zero and both Kiwami games but he is not part of Yakuza: Like a Dragon game. 

[h1] PROS [/h1]
- Decent main story with an interesting plot, this time you will play the Majima saga and understand why Majima became the madman you met in the previous games.
- Better than Kiwami 1.
- Decent graphics, good soundtrack.
- The voice-overs are in the same Japanese with English subtitling and this gives more authenticity to the game.
- Excellent cutscenes and game atmosphere and the lively environment makes you feel immersed in the Japanese life and game's story.
- Good optimization, high fps count.
- Deccent skills tree.
- Enough side content, good side mini-stories.
- Best manual save option in the series.

[h1] CONS [/h1]
- Partial ultrawide support (cutscenes have side black bars, you can change FOV and display ratio to show them stretched or letterboxed).
- Very short story compared with Yakuza Zero and shorter compared with Yakuza Kiwami.
- Even if better than Kiwami 1 story, Kiwami 2 is still not as great as Yakuza Zero.
- A bit different combat system that seem not to be as good and interactive as in the previous games.
- Compared with the previous games, a bit more useless content and dialogues to fill-in gaps of the main story.
- In 4k, some ported animations feel a bit strange due to the Dragon graphical engine upgrade.

My favorites were the stories including Granny White, the Sunflower Orphanage, the infamous man-babies, and the scam companies.

[u] My Few Complaints [/u]
The new physics engine, while realistic and engaging much of the time, still has moments of heavy buggery or silliness that breaks the immersion factor. Some parts in the middle had small pacing issues, though that may have also been influenced by my breaks between playing the game across a few months.

- Overhaul of the combat system, doing away with complexity in favor of a "one size fits all" approach. Controls have been changed so it's easier to execute combos and heat moves are now easier to hit because the marker is moved to the center of the screen (WHERE IT SHOULD HAVE BEEN ALL ALONG.)

-Drop-dead gorgeous graphics. Sotenbori and Kamurocho have never looked so beautiful in the Yakuza world and are faithfully rendered to their real world inspirations. 

-The Police are finally playing a more serious role in a game about organized crime! |
