It's really hard to write a review for this game because its developers got so few things right...

# The Good Things

+ The Cabaret Club Minigame

There is a funny minigame in it called the "Cabaret Club Grand Prix". It's a hostess simulator where the player gets to groom hostesses
as the manager of the club and then host parties where costumers come to chat with a hostess and pay for it.
It's a "Grand Prix" because the player have to compete with other clubs to become the best in the country. The competitions have stories with plot twists, background and everything which makes it a good sidequest.
I don't know why but I had a lot of fun with this silly quest. It also had a huge effect on the game because I made a lot of money while playing it insead of grinding on the street(beating weak enemies over and over).

+ Overall Stability

The game was surprisingly stable - no crashes or artifacts. But the autosaves are not reliable.

+ (Some) Cutscenes

[i]Some[/i] of them are really well-made like they're from a proper movie - dialog, camera, faces etc. This was the "feature" that hooked me initially but later I found out that this is also one of the weak point of the game.

# The Bad Things

- Cutscenes, cutscenes, cutscenes...

If you don't like long cutscenes in a game where they treat the players like they're stupid then this game is not for you because most of the cutscenes are [i]extremely long[/i] and boring.
Of course, if you can't bear asian movies then you won't like this game anyway because there is barely any gameplay:
if I exclude the cabaret club minigame, I think I spent more time watching cutscenes than playing the core game. For every 5 minutes of gameplay in the main story you get multiple 5 minutes-long cutscenes.
There are also a lot of "cutscenes" that are not voice-acted and I just had to click through the dialogues while they moved their mouths - this happened frequently between "real" dialogues - like they were place-holders - so I guess they just didn't have the budget or time to finish the game.

- Lots of minigames, very little fun

Most of the minigames have nothing to do with the base game which is fine for me but they're also really boring and very repetitive.
If I would want to play mobile games I would play them on a mobile.
I would totally play the cabaret club on a smartphone while I'm traveling. I wouldn't play the rest again even if I would get paid for it.

- Spamming low-quality sidequests and encounters

While I was walking on the streets I got [i]constantly[/i] spammed by stupid sidequests and low-level fights. Regular people and gangs just came up to me, explained their boring stories and the resolution was almost always the same: beat up a few baddies and say good bye.
This would have been okay but I was forced to listen to the start of each sidequest and I often got "teleported" from my current position - taking user control away is bad.
Imagine if you would play the Witcher 3 and you would constantly get stopped by strangers to find their pans...

- Tedious level-up system

You have to beat a lot of weak enemies, eat food at restaurants, click+wait through all the nonsense just to get a little boost. The game has a lot of "skills" but the gameplay is far from diverse.

- Trashy combat system from bollywood

You need to level-up to get anywhere in combat(you can also just chug drinks if you have the money) but the combat system will be still stiff and rag-dolly, like it's a comedy game.
I didn't expect a soulsborne experience but I just couldn't prepare myself for the disappointment - most of the time, the combat feels like playing with a cheap bollywood movie.
Most enemies are way too weak and bosses feel like bullet-sponges if you don't use your special skills enough. They usually have 4-5 phases with the same moveset but with lots of poise, grab attacks and no cool-down between attacks.
From the controls I can tell the developers never played on PC.

- The graphics are incomplete

The anti-aliasing is terribly weak - everything is constantly shimmering at 1440p/ultra, jaggies are everywhere. Some objects have good textures but most of them are blurry which creates a really ugly contrast.

- Performance is subpar compared to the bad grapics

In terms of efficiency it belongs to the bottom 10% despite the fact that areas in this game are really small and the details are low. I'm playing at 1440p and 144Hz and my PC runs games like the witcher 3 fine but in this game my fps frequently drops below 90.

Yakuza kiwami 2 has better game systems than 0, fights now happen on map making enviromental heat moves possible and showing what weapons will be on the ground before the fight has started. Fighting has also be some what dumbed down by the removal of having four styles and how fickle heat moves can be to activate. Combat is somewhat redeemed by greatly expanded heat move offerings, combos involving a lot more kicking and heat burst mode making you a walking tank. Boss fights on normal feel under tuned with some street bosses being harder than late game bosses. The Coliseum feels overturned at times especially whenever you can run into enemies with 6 health bars in the first tournament.

The new experience system means everything you do successfully in game gains experience including mini games, sub stories, combat and consumables.  Food now matters and food combos are arguably one of the best ways to gain experience throughout the game. Most mini-games have been revamped to have more easy to understand systems and generally streamlined aside from the rigid ones like Mahjong. Majima Construction is top down waves of battle game with up to 11 party members that is a great minigame with a fun story but pays less than you're going to spend on it to stay relevant as you get further in the campaign. Money is much less abundant thereby far less necessary for most things. I had a million by the first time you leave Sotenbori and sixty million by the time I finished The Cabaret. I don't know what to say about the story other than it's good, if you like over the top action mixed with drama and little sprinkles of comedy which can be often found in the sub stories.

Due to it's use of the "dragon" engine, Yakuza Kiwami 2 feels a bit different than the previous games in the series. The first thing you'll notice is that the ability to swap fighting styles is gone, replaced with the ability to store three weapons at a time to take out whenever you need them. I felt this hurt the game somewhat from a strategic standpoint, as sometimes it was kinda fun trying to figure out which fighting style worked best against a specific opponent. I also felt that weapons were somewhat overpowered in this game, as even the final bosses died in seconds when I was wielding a weapon - of which you can purchase powerful ones literally seconds before the final fights. I completed the entire sequence of final battles without once having to heal. That being said the combat still feels familiar in spite of being arguably more limited in scope, and retains it's fun due in part to Kiryu feeling like a superhero this time around.

Another addition that the dragon engine provides now is that the cities are seemless. When you go toward a building there isn't a loading zone. You simply push open the door and walk into the shop as part of the normal playing map. This also goes for any building interior in the game with very few exceptions of special locations you have to drive a taxi separately to. Additionally due to the weapon heavy focus of this game the world is populated pretty liberally with stuff, such as entire rows of bicycles being locked up. And if you bump into them the game reacts by knocking them over, or in some cases completely wrecking them. In a battle near a convenience store you can enter the store during the fight and start breaking shelves. The world reacts to the player like never before, somewhat making up for the decision to limit the combat system to "get weapon and win".

The story is quite a bit more interesting than the story presented in Kiwami 1, and felt a lot closer to 0 in theme. Even with simple touches like Majima seeming less like a Joker cosplayer this time around, and more like his personality in 0 where he is crazy, but in that "crazy like a fox" kind of way. You see the crazy act get dropped for more serious moments several times, which helps for when you unlock an additional mini story mode where you play as him. This mode is highly recommended for people who played through 0, as it contains some of the most satisfying moments in the game during one of the chapters of it.

Kiwami 2 is still a pretty high recommendation for me, as even with the somewhat subdued battle system I didn't find myself having less fun with it. Perhaps it was more mindless fun, as instead of swapping styles to match kiwami auras to prevent recharging health (of which you won't run into that here, as a heads up) you instead spend most battles beating opponents with whatever isn't nailed to the floor within grabbing distance along with comical heat actions such as straight up throwing a guy off a bridge, or having a local shop owner throw you two giant leaks to use as weapons because you helped him find a new cooking utensil.

This game also is something of a return to the true identity of Yakuza, with the side quests very heavily veering into the goofy territory. A welcome change after a majority of the substories in Yakuza Kiwami 1 more or less were "I'm being scammed by this person" over and over, with very few overly comical variations on it. The game feels more like Yakuza 0, in spite of the more basic fighting system. If you enjoy the others in the series by all means give this a run. Especially if you intend to play Yakuza: Like A Dragon down the line, as that game contains a couple of references to things in this one.

Story is interesting from the beginning. Graphics are fantastic especially when it comes to the environment. Combat seems slightly simplified compared to 0 and Kiwami's stance system, but is easily much more fluid feeling with more satisfying animations. You should probably play the other two before this one if you want to keep up narratively, but you can probably scrape by playing Kiwami 2 and Yakuza 0 in whatever order you want.

Amazing story and music. Really brings modern game mechanics to the Yakuza franchise. Best of all, the game includes references and conclusions to plot points that people cared about in earlier games. 

The experience system here is much better than 0 or Kiwami 1. In 0, money is used for enhancing both your skills and as currency. This made spending money a slightly painful choice. In Kiwami 1, there was one type of experience that you would use across all the fighting styles. 

In Kiwami 2, there are different types of experience for various aspects / activities in the game, such as stamina, hitting harder, and so on. The system for lategame stats is also more developed, as there are more skills to unlock after maxing out your base skills.

The cities of Kamurocho and Sotenburi are amazingly detailed and feel like living, breathing spaces. There are so many things to do - if you are just focused on the main storyline, you would be missing out on so much.

Overall, this was an unforgettable experience. Please get this game so that we can get Kiwami versions of the other entries in the Yakuza franchise!

After completing Kiwami 1 you are rewarded with a beautifully crowded detail game. The graphics difference between this game and the previous is astounding, I can't help myself but to change into first person with the HUD off and appreciate the bustling neon filled streets of Kamurocho and Sotenbori. The Dragon engine did this game justice, the way light is simulated looks way too real. You can also seamlessly walk into buildings with no loading screen.

Kiwami 2 reintroduced the beloved the Hostess mini game, with its own story of Kiryu managing the Four Shine club with Yuki from Yakuza 0. It also introduced a new tower defence mini game called Clan creator which is  a revolves around Majima's construction company.

The notable 4 different combat styles from previous game is gone which can be a bother for some people. Kiryu now only use 1 style which feels the most similar to his dragon/legend style. I am a big fan of the combat change, the attacks feel weighty and sending enemies flying can be funny. But throwing enemies can be a huge waste of time in combat because enemies will be flying at least 3-5 meters away from you. With the new engine, ragdoll is added into this game which can look goofy as it seems to be tied with your frame rate. My opinion seems negative but what the game does right is making you feel powerful, as you upgrade your stats and unlock more moves you will feel overpowered. You can also unlock what ever skill you want as long you have the experience for it.

So far I am up to chapter 6 in the game,  I've encountered some enjoyable substories which were lacking from Kiwami 1. The most stand out substories are the silly fun ones. My personal favourites is the Kiryu imposter quest, catching a panty thief, the 'Be my baby' substory (the weirdest one so far) and modelling for a guy in a speedo. These substories I experienced is on par with Yakuza 0.

This game has breathtaking visuals, a very customizable combat system with lots of enjoyable side activities to do. Kiwami 2 is a treat for Yakuza 0 players and forgot to mention it has a Majima's own playable story.

If you liked the previous Yakuza games, you'll love this one too. It's miles better than Kiwami 1, but still holds on to the traditional Yakuza formula. The main story is better and less non-sensical than the previous games, the city looks much better with the new engine and I experienced no performance issues. The side missions are what really sold this game to me, after completing some missions you unlock characters that help you with random streetfights, like a guy who throws you a bowl of ramen in the middle of a fight. The fighting is also superb, some of the heat moves are absolutely crazy, the inclusion of weapons still feels extremely cheesy though, they seem far too overpowered and they break really quickly, so why even include them in the first place?

Cannot understate what a huge improvement this is over Kiwami 1. The engine is completely revamped, the combat is less frustrating, you can walk into buildings without a loading screen, the completion list, minigames and food system is better, it looks better, there are more people occupying the streets. If one were to start the Yakuza series here, there'd be no going back, the improvements are just too huge.

I started with Yakuza 0, and went into Yakuza Kiwami with some of the skills I learned there. Yakuza Kiwami 2 is on a different Engine, however, and not everything seems to carry over. However, I am having a lot of fun playing this, and would highly recommend it if you enjoyed 0 or Kiwami (or the original Yakuza and Yakuza 2, which I never played).

Like Kiwami, Kiwami 2's writing is a little rough in some places. But keep in mind that Yakuza and Yakuza 2 came out in 2005 and 2006 respectively, and that Yakuza 0 was the 7th released game in the series; so of course it was a bit better written as it came out after they had at least 6 games behind them. This doesn't mean I think the writing is bad, though. It's just got that mid 2000s PS2 era vibe to it... seeing as they're remakes of mid 2000s PS2 era games.

All in all, I do recommend this game, as well as Kiwami and 0. I wouldn't take my word too highly though, seeing as I only managed 20~% of Yakuza 0 (at this time), and 65~% of Yakuza Kiwami (at this time), and am in no way a completionist. However, despite those low percentages, I did complete the main story for both and enjoyed them thoroughly.

The Yakuza series is fast becoming my favorite game series. 

I was initially skeptical and thought that everything is currently overhyped due to the meme that is 'Baka Mitai', but I'm so glad to be proven wrong.

The characters are well-written, and the music is great. As with most JRPGs, there's a bit of grinding involved, but grinding is actually FUN in these games. Sure, some quests are worse than others (I personally think the Haruka quests are annoying af), but most of the sidestories are enjoyable.

For Kiwami 2 in particular, I enjoy the streamlined combat system in comparison to Kiwami 1, though I do miss being able to swap styles. The minigames in Kiwami 2 are a lot more fun. Cabaret club is a money hellhole that I'll happily throw myself into...
Clan creattion is okay, if you would like to support the developers I recommend buying the DLC bundle. Plus it gets you through the construction storyline faster, and nets you achievements faster as well.

TLDR great game, can't wait for the rest of the series to be ported into PC, though I would happily buy a PS just to finish the games. Give me moar Yakuza please. 9/10

First off, I haven't played the original Yakuza 2, so this isn't a comparison, but my impressions of this game on its own.

Overall, a great experience. Good storyline, great characters, fun combat and side stuff (like cabaret management from Yakuza 0), etc. The kind of game where you can beat up street punks, get some fine dining, and go gambling while hardly moving a block. Also, no shortage funny gags in Yakuza series tradition to keep the game lighthearted despite its serious themes.

Still, I've got my complaints. Because this uses a new game engine called the Dragon Engine, I can't even get a 30 fps framerate without having the game look like complete junk (I have a GTX 760), whereas in previous titles I can play in fullscreen with nice-looking graphics. Also the ragdolling is insane, but I think it's actually kind of amusing, so it's not necessarily a bad point.

Also, not to flex or anything, but the game was way too easy. I played on hard and the only part I really had trouble on was the fight with Ryuji at the start of the game, on which I had to take up the offer to switch to easy difficulty for the fight. Otherwise, heat moves and weapons are insanely overpowered and made the game feel way too easy, especially compared to Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1 (which I played on normal difficulty). I think this took away from some of the fights that were meant to be more epic.

Kiwami 2 has really nice graphics compared to 0 and Kiwami 1's which were already pretty great but out of the 3 I've played I can say only one thing, I enjoyed this game the least out of the trio because the fighting system is completely different than 0 and 1 and so is the xp system. The story is interesting but not really special, however the plot twists at the end are good and nearly impossible to predict. The side content is fun as always except the colosseum at higher levels because many enemies have like 15 health bars (no joke) but it gets a lot more fun and a lot easier the more you play since you get new moves and more damage/health/rage.

TL;DR
It's fun, different than 1 and 0 but not to an extent where it's a diffferent game.

Coming from Yakuza 0 and Kiwami, this game is really amazing. It takes something that was already great and builds up on it with its magnificent Dragon engine and typical Yakuza shenanigans.

Graphics: This is where the game is an obvious cut above the previous entries. The city looks so good that I would easily mistake it for real. The game looks next gen compared to Yakuza 0 and Kiwami, and attention to detail is mind-boggling. Simplest tasks like opening different types of doors are so fluid that they actually look natural. The gameplay is strikingly similar to cutscenes. This is one of the best looking game I have played of late - and I did not expect to say this about a Yakuza game.

Gameplay: With the newer and sleeker Dragon engine the gameplay is much smoother than previous games. Other than that, it is the same reliable Yakuza mix of beat'em up and free roam, and it is as delightful as in the past. The substories are more than half of game's chunk, and they are hilarious enough that I burst out laughing multiple times.  

Story: The weakest link, in my opinion. While Yakuza 0 still has the best ever story, this time it's not as disappointing as in Kiwami, and the finale is actually really clever. The main issue is that it picks up amazingly in the final moments - while being a ho-hum cheesefest over most of the game. The main bad guy is great though. He has clear goals and a personality.

The extra content like substories, cabaret club management and the clan creator etc is massive and thanks to the better engine as polished as the main story. I have yet to go through it all but I look forward to it.

Overall, this game is great, and lives up to Yakuza legacy.

The Yakuza series owns my heart and my wallet, every game they've gotten onto steam is phenomenal. That being said, this review will be more comparing kiwami 2 to 0 and kiwami for reference, as to rate kiwami 2 in a vacuum is a clear must have.

-Plot of course is a rollercoaster in the best of ways. I don't know if I would say as good as 0, but I did enjoy it more than kiwami. Characters again are great and really fleshed out and its very cool to see their growth from kiwami 1 for those who play a part here.
-Combat is still serviceable, but the simplification of kiryu's moveset from 4 styles to switch between to 1 general style that mixes parts of each does reduce the depth and skill ceiling of fights, so I would say the other games did them better. Getting upgrades and unlockables is improved, however, as you gain varying amounts of 5 different exp stats that can be spent in different combinations to gain new heat moves or raise base stats.
-Side quests are fine, there's more variety than having your wallet stolen every 5 minutes like in kiwami and helping people usually results in them coming to work for you in a minigame or unlocking a special heat move that you can use if that npc is nearby.
-Kiwami 2 has quite a few returning minigames such as the cabaret club, gambling, claw grabbing machine, etc so those are still fun. New additions include a fun golf range and an rts style mode, as well as interactive urination.
-Graphically I feel like kiwami 2 does not quite stand up to the previous games on a mid-range pc. This engine is capable of some great things but without a beast of a computer it either looks strange or lacks performance. I never reached 60fps in kiwami 2 despite that being a constant in the others which really is unfortunate because while I did stay above 40 fps after settings tweaks, I personally felt this was a bad tradeoff to having physics on items in the main world and cutting out loading screens when entering shops.

All in all, some aspects were done better in previous titles but Yakuza Kiwami 2 is still a fantastic game

A great game almost on par with Yakuza 0. This is a remake of Yakuza 2 with a different game engine, which brings a fresh change to the combat system from previous titles. I will compare this game to Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1 in this review.

Combat:
With the new combat system, you only have one style of fighting and you pretty much have all you need to start beating enemies up from the beginning. The skill system has changed from either paying money or gaining a single exp to gaining 5 different types of exp which you spend to improve stats or learn new skills. For the most part, the skills you learn don't seem to add much since you can just click enemies to death. Combat has become a lot more active compared to the previous games, in that even the environment plays a part. Objects can be kicked around for damage, there are a lot more quicktime events, enemies usually have weapons, 3 weapons can be equipped and pulled out, and NPCs can assist in battle through heat actions.

Minigames:
Some new minigames have been added and some minigames have been removed. Pool, cee-lo, cho han, baccarat, roulette, bowling have been removed. But golf, gravure photo, cabaret club, and clan creator have been added.

Substories:
The substories have stayed about consistent from 0 and Kiwami 1.

Music:
The music is really great in this game. Easy to get pumped up for long fights.

Story:
This is a remake of the original, but the story is a lot more interesting than Kiwami 1. It is closer to the Yakuza 0 level of storytelling, but still has some gaps and leaps from the original. Also the Majima Saga was added to close any remaining loose ends from the end of Yakuza 0 and the events prior to Yakuza Kiwami 2.

Game Performance:
Unlike 0 and Kiwami 1, this game is more intensive on the graphic card. It took me a while to find the correct graphics settings to change from 20 fps to 40-50 fps. It is unbearable to play the game at 20 fps, but once you reach close to 40 fps, the game becomes very enjoyable to play. Also the cutscenes might run slow as well.

8/10

16 hours in, Kiwami 2 is everything I was hoping Kiwami 1 would be. The first thing you'll notice is the updated Dragon Engine. It looks spectacular, more often during regular gameplay and not during the showy cutscenes. Animations still seem to be getting the short end of the budgetign stick, but they're as charming as alwways. My only gripe with the updated engine is that they added that heavy sense of momentum/locomotion to Kyriua, which makes maneuvering him in corridors or other tight spaces tedious becase he reacts to geometry and breaks his speed.

That said, I'm having an absolute blast. I've finished all of the Cabaret content that I could and I was surprised by how much depth and characterization the different hostesses were given. A lot of love and care went into creating them.

Just landed back in Kamurocho after a short stint in Sotenbori. Can't wait to see what comes next. Lookign forward to seeing how Kyriu's relationship unfolds with Daigo, Ryiu, and Kaoru.

Final Thoughts:

An excellent installment in the series. Biggest highlights for me include the new Dragon Engine, which looks stunning, especially during the night time. I loved the VO, the heart and charm behind the characters. A lot of Makoto fan service in the side Majima story section (though that felt very rushed and slapped on, felt super railroaded and linear). Kaoru is a great character and it was fun seeing the story's twists and turns as you learn about her family and that of Ryuji.

Weaknesses: the game felt markedly easier and less skillful than 0 or Kiwami. I felt the Super Saiyan form Kyriu enters is WAY overpowered and trivializes any combat encounter. Also, there's only one fighting style, so the game relies on added Heat takedowns to spice things up. That said, after acquiring some movement upgrades, Kyriu feels much more nimble and less sluggish.

Once again, SEGA made another masterpiece.
This game is easily one of the best games I've ever played, just like Yakuza 0. Not only because of the story and the characters but how they renewed the fighting system and how alive they made the atmosphere feel on this one, it's crazy.

First of all, the story is incredible and reaaaally interesting, a lot of new characters you'll fall in love with, a lot of characters coming back and some really scary people.

Second, the atmosphere that SEGA achieved in this game is something else, a more lively city with more lights, places to go and the simple touch of not having to load every place you enter (pawn shop, poppo, restaurants, etc) makes it even better.
You'll FEEL like you are really walking down the streets of Kamurocho/Sotenbori

Third, the fighting system, this is something people coming from Yakuza 0 and 1 will struggle a little with. Atleast I, when I started playing, didnt like the new fighting system at all until I got used to it and I ended up reaaally liking it, it renews the whole formula and makes you try something new and fresh.

Fourth, You'll get to visit Sotenbori too not just Kamurocho and you'll have a looot of stuff to do there and a lot of people to meet

Fifth, just buy the damn game.

Only thing I didnt like (it doesnt affect gameplay, its irrelevant) its the ragdoll system. When you are fighting, you and your enemies will enter ragdoll mode when they get hit and makes it unrealistic af, not like Yakuza 0 and 1. But It wont affect the gameplay or anything.

My final score is a 10/10, its really worth it. Thank you SEGA for this.

This is a tricky game to recommend, but an easy game to review. The TL;DR? Amazing game and a spotty port.

Performance : If you're running modern hardware I don't doubt you're going to be able to run this game well. The technical issues are small but there's a lot. I'll detail a small fix for each one below.

Physics are tied to framerate - Cap to 60 FPS using Rivatuner to fix this.
In-Game Framerate Cap is Broken - Install SilentPatch (fan patch of the game)
Mini-Games running at 60 FPS instead of 30 FPS thus not working as intended - SilentPatch
Realtime Reflections causes problems for some - Turn off
Depth of Field causes heavy aliasing - Turn off OR set Anti-Aliasing to SSAA 2x (if your FPS can handle)

Those are the biggest issues currently. The gameplay, story, characters, and music are all just so good. If this port ran a bit better and didn't require a fanmade patch to fix the big problems, I'd recommend this in a heartbeat to anyone.

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
[b]Yakuza Kiwami 2[/b] is an action-adventure game developed by [b]Ryu Ga Gotoku Studios[/b] and is a complete remake of the PS2 version. The game has improved gameplay from [b]Yakuza Kiwami[/b] such as the improved [b]Dragon Engine[/b] that was used in the sixth installment. The graphics have also been improved and look as beautiful as ever and a new edition is the [b]Majima Saga[/b] that is about three chapters long and is a prequel to the main storyline.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[h3]Pros[/h3]
[list]
[*]Excellent story.
[*]Improved combat system.
[*]New special moves.
[*]Upgrade system is much better.
[*]Lots of substories and mini-games.
[*]Amazing graphics.
[/list]

[h3]Cons[/h3]
[list]
[*]Kaoru Sayama is mostly bland.
[*]The new combat system may take some time to get used to.
[*]Leveling up is easier than ever.
[*]The soundtrack is ok for the most part.
[/list]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story takes place one year after the events of the previous game. The [b]Tojo Clan[/b] is failing apart since the passing of [b]Akira Nishikiyama[/b] and because of that, eternal power struggles have been happing. [b]Kiryu[/b] was asked by the Fith Chairman [b]Yukia Terada[/b] to bring peace between them and the [b]Omi Alliance[/b]. However, [b]Ryuji Goda[/b], the dragon of [b]Kansai[/b] wants a war with both clans and stops at nothing to achieve his goal. The Fith Chairman is then assassinated and it is now up to [b]Kiryu[/b] to put a stop to it all and save the [b]Tojo Clan[/b]. [b]Tokyo Police[/b] sends a woman named [b]Kaoru Sayama[/b] to put [b]Kiryu[/b] into protective custody. However, her real goal is to get close to the [b]Tojo Clan[/b] to learn about her past.

The story is presented very well and is the best part of the game, every moment had a lot of hype put into it. The twists that the story shows felt amazing, especially near the end of the game as everything unfolds. The story has it‚Äôs charm and the characters are crafted very well like always, however, one character, unfortunately, does not stick well enough and that is [b]Kaoru Sayama[/b]. Now [b]Kaoru[/b] is not a terrible character by no means, it‚Äôs just she is not presented very well. The only thing that [b]Kaoru[/b] really wants to do is uncover her past but she comes off as very cold and off-putting. Her character does develop as the story progresses and does have a sweet side but she just does not do it right and at the end of the day, she is just is not likable to me. [b]Haruka[/b] who only appears in a few chapters has more character development then [b]Kaoru[/b] and is with you for the whole game. [b]Haruka[/b] is [b]Kiryu‚Äôs[/b] adoptive daughter and is willing to stay with him no matter what happens to her, despite having a father who used to be with the [b]Yakuza[/b].

[h3]Majima Saga[/h3]
The year is 2006 and [b]Yukio Terada[/b] will recruit someone new so the [b]Tojo Clan[/b] could be rebuilt since the 10 million yen incident from the previous game. [b]Terada[/b] states that the person to have deemed the most money would gain the spot. The two individuals who are trying to get the position are [b]Goro Majima[/b] and [b]Akinobu Uematsu[/b]. 

The [b]Majima Saga[/b] is quite short as it‚Äôs only about three chapters long. That being said, it is very enjoyable and I recommend doing all three chapters at the same time. To get the chapters you will have to progress through the game normally to get them.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game uses the new [b]Dragon Engine[/b] that was used in [b]Yakuza 6[/b] and the gameplay is completely different, the overworld has been improved completely. The entire map is a giant world where you can interact with many things. There is also a new way to upgrade your moves in the game as you don‚Äôt use the money you get to upgrade them instead, you must eat food. [b]Kiryu[/b] won‚Äôt get any upgrade points if his stomach is full however, so you can only get the upgrade points on an empty stomach. There are a bunch of wacky sub-stories for you to do and they are quite interesting for you to do as they break away from the series tone the story goes for. There are lots of mini-games for you to play like [b]Mojang[/b], a crane based game, and going to the [b]Batting Ranges[/b].

The only issue with the upgrading system that the game has brought in is that it is now easier to upgrade than before. Now [b]Yakuza[/b] did hand you a lot of money in the first two games but you did not have to go to restaurants. [b]Kiryu[/b] will get hungry if he gets into fights and getting into fights also grants you upgrade points as well so upgrading is pretty simple to do and can make the game easy if you farm a lot. I was playing on normal difficulty and you can increase it to make it harder. 

[h3]Combat[/h3]
Combat is different with the new engine and you can smash enemies through windows if giving the chance. Now I should note that when [b]Kiryu[/b] grabs people, he won‚Äôt be able to use his special moves as he would in the first two games instead it is just a normal grab but he can do pretty much every move. [b]Kiryu[/b] does not have his other fighting styles as he had in the first two games so he only has [b]Brawler[/b]. You can still grab weapons and other stuff and use them to help fight off the enemies. You will also have a partner with you for a large majority of the game and you can pull off combo moves to deal more damage to enemies.

The only issue with combat is that thanks to the new engine it may take some time to get used to combat. So if you just got done the first two games then you may have some trouble at the start of the game.

[b]Goro Majima[/b] is a water-downed version of [b]Kiryu[/b] in terms of combat and that‚Äôs not a bad thing as the chapters are new to the game. He does not get upgrade points like [b]Kiryu[/b] and he can only heal at restaurants but does carry the health and items that [b]Kiryu[/b] can get in his story.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The graphics in the game are honesty beautiful and have improved from the first two games, you can see the detail that has been shown in the overworld, especially when night comes. The graphics also do not change when it comes to the cut scenes which is another improvement that the game features.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2107886126

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
Unfortunately, the soundtrack is not as good in this game as there are not a lot of memorable songs in the game. The only song that was worth mentioning that was actually really good was [b]SiM-A[/b] which is from an actual band and tells a story about a guy fighting off the Yakuza so it‚Äôs fitting.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hdf7gIW_hls

[h1]Preformance[/h1]
The game was tested with a NIVIDA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, 16 GB of RAM storage, and an AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50. The game runs very smooth and I had no issues while playing the game at all, you may need a decent computer to run the game as it is demanding on the graphics.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
[b]Yakuza Kiwami 2[/b] improves on a lot of things the first two games had while bringing something new to the table. The game may be a little easy at times and the soundtrack is not the greatest but it‚Äôs a great [b]Yakuza[/b] game to play and is perfect for any [b]Yakuza[/b] fan.

Coming to Yakuza Kiwami 2 from 0 and Kiwami, I can say that this game is by far my favorite out of the bunch. 

Story: Great. Still falls victim to the same issues prevalent in the writing of Yakuza 0 and Kiwami such as abruptly cutting to side stories that vary in quality. Generally, the newly introduced characters are very interesting and are written pretty well. The plot is very interesting if not a bit all over the place. All in all, not enough Majima, but still good.

Gameplay: Unga bunga. I mash light attack and occasionally heavy and the enemies ragdoll all over the place. Almost impossible to "master" the combat in Kiwami 2 besides the parry and Komaki Tiger Drop. Most boss fights are laughable stat checks that are only challenging if the challenge is self imposed ([spoiler]For example, during the final fight in the game, I challenged myself to a bare-knuckle brawl with no healing items or weapons to make the final duel of the dragons more impactful[/spoiler]) The combat is much less skill based than the style system in the previous two games I played, but the ragdoll makes me laugh, so all in all, eh.

tldr: Personally, my favorite out of the 3 Yakuza games on Steam, combat has gone downhill from 0 and Kiwami but still fun in its own way. Story holds up and is possibly the best out of the trio thus far.

Another great Yakuza game on the PC.

Kiwami 2 is the first Ryu Ga Gotoku studios game using the new Dragon Engine that we got to try here on the PC and, as such, new small issues have appeared, and I want to start this review commenting a bit on those, and the overall quality of the PC version that QLOC has made.

Firstly, this new engine is obviously more advanced, everything looks a lot better, with more complex shading and lighting, character models also look better, etc. NPC density on the streets of both Kamurocho and Sotenbori is amazing, and overall the game runs quite well if we meet the recommended specs, at least for 2160p all maxxed, minus of course the very taxing Super Sampling.

Now, on the subject of Aliasing, this game is one of the worst in recent times, since the standard FXAA or SMAA barely do anything to make most complex surfaces look smooth, it‚Äôs the opposite: lots of the geometry in the game have an insane amount of shimmering and jaggies, even when doing 4K dowmsampling. I‚Äôve read it has to do with lighting effects and other stuff, and it‚Äôs on the developers‚Äô side to fix that, if they ever. Not even SSAA at max removes the annoying jaggies and shimmering completely and that‚Äôs a shame, because the ports of Yakuza 0 and Kiwami were excellent on this regard, the image looked clear and smooth, and the SSAA worked as intended on those games; granted, it was a different engine, and also a different studio doing the ports (Lab42), but well, it is what it is.

With that out of the way, well holy hell, this game is AMAZING. I still consider Yakuza 0 more complete overall, since the Kiryu/Majima stories are very well developed there, it felt like two games slapped together with a lot of character development for both characters and, for me personally, it was the 4th contact with the franchise, as I didn‚Äôt play the original.

Kiwami felt a bit lacking to me, but I expected it, being the very first game but with the new engine and some additions. The story was solid, intense but the game was considerably shorter‚Ä¶still a blast to play.

Now, Kiwami 2, it‚Äôs like in between those two for me, It‚Äôs an excellent game, there‚Äôre lots of improvements for sure, especially graphical ones, but I think I enjoyed the combat in the previous two games a bit more, with the style switching and all that. We can still do a lot of what was possible before, now in Kiwami 2, but it‚Äôs simpler and more streamlined, which to me is a little bit a step backwards, but nothing off putting, really.

Characters are a forte on this franchise, and Kiwami 2 has very interesting characters, some new, some old, and still quite a lot of character development for some of the oldies, while also introducing us to some new interesting faces that surely will play important roles in the future of the saga.

The scripts are well written, the expressions and animations on the characters are top notch, and it‚Äôs obvious that the Ryu Ga Gotoku studio know how to do their stuff.

Performance as I said earlier has been fine on my i9 9980XE and my rtx 2080 ti played capped at 240 FPS and 2160p, all maxxed, with SSAA, no slowdowns ever, in general pretty smooth.

There have been a couple patches that have ironed out some of the initial launch bugs, and it‚Äôs possible that there are still some to come, who knows. The game is fine right now, except the Anti Aliasing issue, so if you can live with that, don‚Äôt miss this amazing game and story, it‚Äôs another great chapter for this saga.

And of course‚Ä¶mini games, yeah, not much to say there, they‚Äôre addicting, some of them still too complex since I‚Äôm not familiar with Japanese games, but there sure are a lot of mini games, so we can spend a lot of time enjoying them, doing side quests, etc.

All in all, more Yakuza greatness on the PC, and again I thank SEGA for making it possible to enjoy these games on the PC, and at decent prices too. An amazing publisher, and I hope the trend continues, I‚Äôll keep supporting these good games as much as possible, for sure.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a game that learns only mildly from the mistakes of Kiwami 1. It's far more in favor of the player in combat, and the story is markedly more focused on details a player coming from Yakuza 0 might care more about.

The director of the Yakuza series has always described it as a "human drama", but the attempt at Greek tragedy in the previous game was poorly executed and needlessly abstract; at least, compared to how Yakuza 0 does the "human drama" element. Yakuza 1 PS2 succeeded because it was backed by the setting and the audience was left to imagine and interpret events as they went, allowing the seemingly flanderized elements shine through as creative, deserved escalation and interesting.

These elements, however, did not age that well. Especially not with the pace of Majima Everywhere. If you've found yourself taking more breaks playing YK1 than Y0, this is exactly why.

Enter Yakuza Kiwami 2. This game also nearly identically follows the plot of Y2 PS2, except with more sidecontent and a new combat system. Plot-wise, it's meanders similarly to Yakuza 1 but the elements it introduces are more focused and the presented stakes are more meaningful. It's generally accepted as better.

Gameplay-wise? Well, thematically- or in gameplay vs story relations, it makes sense. By the endgame, Kiryu is a heat god, spamming heat actions ad nauseum, seemingly unkillable a fraction of the time even without remaining HP, and his moveset is purely built for relying on raw stats and anti-crowd combat.

It also LOOKS nice. The ragdolls are hilarious and sometimes really satisfying. The attacks blend really well and compliment the nature of the new Dragon Engine's prowess in effects and physics. Kiryu behaves in a lot of realistic ways you'd expect, making the times he lands attacks feel impactful, and the nuances of his kicks have strong presentation.

To PLAY however, it feels bad. If you're not spamming heat moves and relying on your raw stats, you're doing it wrong. Trying to play this game with technique is frustrating, it's really nothing more than a glorified RPG at times because of how certain combat can play out. This can only be escaped if you get lucky or happen to be well-practiced enough with a section after many bad attempts to do it just slightly better.

Kiryu's moveset is built for physics finishing hold spam and mashing out heat moves. That's it.

The enemy design is built for physics finishing hold spam and mashing out heat moves. That's it.

It's very disappointing, because Yakuza Kiwami 1, for all of its outright offensive enemy design, had really good design sense in at least designing Kiryu's moveset. It gave you unparalleled mastery over at least his moveset, and the skill ceiling and depth was really high. It was rewarding.

Here? The only thing standing between you and failure is some EXP, and copious abuse of a few go-to mechanics. Charge attacks, finishing holds, the guard-parry evade and some management of Extreme Heat Mode are all you're expected to know how to do. In lieu of realism, the tech of flanking and outplaying opponents is gone. Kiryu can still be flanked and cheesed, but no enemy in the game works like this anymore.

While this loop is satisfying for a little while, it obviously does not hold a candle to the depth Y0 and YK1 exuded ultimately. While the moveset you're given here is a cute homage to the moves Kiryu had in Y0 and YK1 in the various styles, it's very style over substance. Where it lacks in single-target you're supposed to make up for in raw stats. Who cares about outplaying the opponent if your numbers are just bigger than theirs? And, in a way, while I can tell they wanted Kiryu to play powerfully in this game, since it was technically their last game with him as the mai n character, he really doesn't feel powerful to play.

He feels stronger in YK1 with the fully realized moveset, and with a few modifications made to the game to make it go down easier with the enemy movesets. All of that together blends together supremely. Here? Unless you play exactly as the developers intended, and even then, Kiryu's options are very, very limited, and he will see no success with any other strategy. Fights are a thing that happen, and you can't say they don't happen, but there's really nothing to write home about for this game's combat. I guess a well-placed Tiger Drop or two or a cool end of battle freeze frame are really the most spectacular things you'll see here.

That said, I still think it's worth at least one full playthrough of the story. Kamurocho has really never looked this beautiful.

The new physics engine and combat system really stands out to me coming from playing Yakuza 0 and Kiwami. While I did enjoy Tiger Dropping the shit out of people repeatedly in Dragon Style and it felt a lot more powerful in Kiwami, I really liked how smooth the combat system felt. Playing at a wider fov and having some manual control on camera angles and style definitely led to a lot of creative ways to attack the enemy, especially when playing on higher difficulty. It just feels so silky smooth when setting up combos and parries and dodges to counter and move around a bunch of opponents. Regretably, I haven't been able to play the Latter of the Yakuza series as I am bound to whatever releases on Steam, but if it actually kept this system I'd be very happy with that. 
I enjoyed the story a lot and felt there were a lot of memorable moments and some good drama. I personally thought 0 and Kiwami were better from a narrative and emotional standpoint, but it does bring some interesting ideas to the table and introduces some great characters. The fight scenes stick out especially; fighting Majima gave me chills cause he's just so awesome. I was dreading getting into the Clan Creator mini game but I actually really enjoyed it. It definitely gets harder at the end of the section but I honestly didn't have too much trouble with it. 
There was recently a huge sale on this series not too long ago. I bought the bundle about a week before the price dropped significantly. Since this is a $30 game, I'd suggest waiting to buy it at a discount; I think it was during SEGA's Anniversary Event or something similar. Just keep an eye out whenever the price drops, and I'd strongly recommend getting this after you beat the first two.

Kiwami 2 is a worth addition to the Yakuza series. The combat has a great flow, the story is engaging, most characters are well built and the graphics and soundtrack are amazing.

It picks off one year after 1/Kiwami 1 and quickly throws the player right in the action. The story can be a bit predictable when some characters and plot points are set, but there is enough drama, action and twists to keep you interested.
The game uses a better engine than Kiwami 1 and 0, making the game have far more detail, but also needing a better spec to run it.

The combat flow is far better than 0 and Kiwami, but the style switch system didnt return, which is a massive loss for me.
Kiryu now uses a mix of all his styles, with a few hints of Dragon and Beast when using the Super mode.
While really fun, it can get a bit repetitive to do the same moves over and over. This wouldnt be a problem if you could unlock new moves or change them up, but sadly most upgrades are related to increasing damage, using some heat actions or boosting stats.

That said, the upgrade system is NIGHTMARE. Gone is the universal xp from Kiwami (or the money system from 0). Now you have FIVE different xp types, where most skills need two or three of each type to be purchased.
Apparently, Kiryu forgot most of his moves in just one year between the games, along how to use Kali sticks and tonfas. While it makes sense for the gameplay, most skills arent that broken to have at the start of the game, Tiger Drop isnt the insane instakill that it was on 0/Kiwami.
It wouldnt be a problem since you get quite a lot of xp just playing, fighting and eating, but lots of skills (and good ones) are locked behind grind (like baseball) and insane hard challenges (All legendary Bouncer missions).
Not only that, even after you unlock the skill, you still have to purchase it.

Kiwami 2 is still the completionist hell like every other Yakuza game is, so you still have most minigames from previous games, but excluding a few like Bowling, Dancing and Billards, which is also a great downside.
Batting is changed once again and its quite easier than the previous games, but that is "balanced" by having to play 30-ish games in the hardest difficulty to get the skill unlocks. Darts is also better to play without the weird "precision" from the previous games.
Japanese card and board games are still there (like Koi Koi and Shogi) and there is an entire subquest related to Mahjong.
Virtua Fighter 2 and Virtual On are the Sega arcade games, but the AI is arcade hard.
Karaoke is still here, although Kiryu doesnt sings Bakamitai and Majima doesnt sings 24-Hour Cinderella on this one.

Other Minigames include the return of the Cabaret Club, with the return of some familiar characters. Its exactly the same as the one in 0, but with worse music in my opinion.
The other minigame is the Clan Creator missions, which is a simple RTS/Tower Defense game related to Majima. Its really boring and the story is pretty much the same as the Real State missions from 0.
They are not really worth doing aside for more money, a bit of unrelated story and gameplay, but the Clan Creator missions are required to unlock a new Coliseum tournament, which is required to unlock a skill.

Talking about money, the most you use it is to buy some weapons so you can sell them right back. One of the vendors (the fat weapon manic guy) sells more stuff the more weapons and armor you sell to him, but the game never tells you that.

The game also includes the Majima Saga, which is a massive lost opportunity. Its REALLY short, less than 1 hour (unless you spend time to defeat some random thugs and gather money to donate to Kiryu for the side mission) and Majima cant learn any new skills or boost stats. 
He is the one that feels the most impact of not having the extra styles, as his fighting moves are really limited and not as good as his unique moves from 0.
The story is about what happened to his family between the end of 1 and the start of 2. While pretty much no characters matter for the story of 2 AT ALL, there is a really nice closure for one character, which makes playing it worth it.

Overall, a great game. If you want something with good gameplay, story and graphics, this one has it all.

Yakuza Kiwami 2 is a stellar remake of an already fantastic game. In just about every way possible it improves upon what was established from the game it's a remake of. Yakuza 2 is a perfect fit for the Dragon Engine and it's combat engine. The game doesn't just stay consistent to its source material, it changes up a few segments to keep veteran players on their feet or help streamline some of the clunkier elements of the original game (e.g. the mandatory Shogi from Yakuza 2 being thankfully removed and that segment being completely revamped in Kiwami 2). 

Mini Games from the original are ultimately kept mostly in tact, with Mini Golf notably being just as enjoyable as it was in the original game. That said, some noteworthy side content from the original isn't present in Kiwami 2 (notably Host Club Adam, although it's location is still there). Kiwami 2 instead condenses that club along with several others that are now missing into a single Hostess Club you can manage which acts as a sequel, both in narrative and in terms of gameplay, to Club Sunshine from Yakuza 0. I see this as a positive and a negative: While managing Four Shine is fun and a great way to earn Yen while dealing with completion, and the new and familiar faces from 0 have an enjoyable story line, I wish the clubs from the original game could've gotten the same love. On top of that Four Shine's forced inclusion into the main story is tedious and leaves a bad first impression for whats to come, especially to someone looking for a pure Yakuza 2 experience.

Equally conflicting is Kiwami 2's other major mini game attraction: The Clan Creator. Just like Four Shine, The Clan Creator leaves an immediate bad impression by forcing itself sloppily into a somewhat arbitrary part of the main story. Unlike Four Shine, the rewards for doing the Clan Creator are middling and it isn't worth bothering with outside of the time you're forced to play it if you don't care about completion at all, even if you're a fan of Majima.

Aside from those two big new additions, this game almost exclusively draws from Yakuza 2. The Main Story is based on the original Yakuza 2 which is, in my opinion, the best main story in any of these games. For Yakuza 2 alone the development team at Sega's Entertainment Division brought a japanese crime novelist named Hase Seish≈´ in to write for the game and his unique writing style absolutely bleeds through this game and Yakuza 2's script. This is a Yakuza game whose main story takes itself far more seriously than usual. The stakes seem grander, the new characters more cold and cunning, or even outright vile at times and the story just manages to enrapture you with constantly developing plot points. Yakuza 2 has been critisized of having too many narrative points going on at once, but for the most part I feel that just makes repeat playthroughs even more enjoyable: Yakuza 2 and Kiwami 2's story is a well cooked steak dinner that will leave you chewing for a long time, but every bite is even more delicious than the last. There are some low points to the story however, notably the chapters involving the Colors Gangs and Takashi aren't so great (their appearances made even more baffling due to the fact that their stories seemed over with in Yakuza 1/Kiwami 1) but overall the good parts of this games story FAR outweigh any negatives.. The Sub Stories work from the same script as the original, with the added benefit of updated graphics and unique camera work which give what are some of the quirkiest sub stories in the series even more personality. The Music is entirely based on the original excluding hub world themes like what you'd hear inside restaurants which are ambient versions of now series staple songs like Baka Mitai that manages to sell the idea of whatever establishment you happen to be partaking in effortlessly. In general, you can tell a lot of love and care went into getting the games soundscape perfect, and it shows. Another thing that obviously had a lot of care put into it was the games visuals. Yakuza 6 was already a showcase of just how beautiful and accurate to life the modern Yakuza games could be with highly detailed cities and the ability to seamlessly go between buildings and the world outside, and this game goes further with that. Kiwami 2 lovingly recreating areas from Yakuza 2 down to little insignificant details, and even some details that would later be added to Kamurocho (such as the underground and shopping center by the coin lockers being present) and certain locations that 0 added to Sotenbori.

In summary, Yakuza Kiwami 2 is what every remake should strive to be: A direct improvement on the original. It doesn't invalidate Yakuza 2, but it simply improves upon it in almost every way possible. There are a few rough patches (namely Four Shine, The Clan Creator and their forced story inclusion) but they don't detract from the overall experience and are quickly forgiven. The effort that was put into making Kamurocho and Sotenbori as convincing as possible makes Kiwami 2 extremely easy to get entrapped by. It's one of those games that pulls you in to it's world and makes you forget you're playing a video game. Yakuza Kiwami 2 is easily my favorite Yakuza game, a title that previously belonged to the game it's a remake of.

[h1] [u]Kiwami 2 Review[/u] [/h1]

Amazing game. Gone through for the 100% on my first play-through and it has been fun. 
Absolutely love the Yakuza games. Taken me 84 hours to get all but Mahjong done. All the Yakuza games are worth the money. So much content (especially for 100%) and a great story.

[u]Pros:[/u]

- Yakuza Kiwami 2 has got a far better story than Kiwami but on-par if not then below Yakuza 0.

- I personally love the Dragon Engine but also miss the varied fighting styles. 

- The music is great but nothing compared to Yakuza 0. 

- Fun as hell Mini-games like Majima Construction, Toylets, Virtua Fighter, Darts, Poker and Blackjack.

[u]Cons:[/u]

- Repetitive fight music and most bosses don't have their own theme.

- Way too many Bouncer Missions

- Mahjong Competitions

-----------------------------------------------------------------

[spoiler] I love Majima. One of my favourite characters in the franchise. But Sega did him dirty by making his story that short and rushing his side of the story to why he left the Tojo Clan. They at least could have had 6 Chapters instead of 3 and maybe added some basic skills to upgrade along with a few sub-stories for completionists. [/spoiler]

[u]Just some advice:[/u]
Play the game on Hard straight from the start if you want a balanced challenge. Same goes for Y0 and Kiwami. Normal mode is way too easy and thus I would say go straight into the game with Hard difficulty like I did.

[u]Just to point out for 100% players:[/u]
Some annoying things about this game though is how there are so many bouncer missions and all of them besides the 3 last Legends are really easy. And f*cking Mahjong. I played it in Y0 and this. Many, many , many hours spent playing that bloody minigame and yet still I cannot understand it. Even if I did, why so many Mahjong Completion quests instead of more Shogi, Koi-Koi, Poker, Blackjack or Oicho-Kabu.
